(Ord. 13-O-48, 8-6-2013)
1-8-4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Title: This section may be called or referred to as the HIGHWOOD CITY
BOND ORDINANCE OF 2003.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bond Required: Pursuant to the requirements of law, currently 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-10-30, before entering upon the duties of
their respective offices, all officers of the city, except aldermen, shall
execute a bond with security, payable to the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Conditions Of Bond:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The bond shall include in it conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â That it is conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of the office and the payment of all monies received by the officer,
according to law and the ordinances of the city; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â That it is payable to the city in the penal sum of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00), except as to the city treasurer, in which case, the bond
shall be payable to the city in the penal sum of at least twenty thousand
dollars ($20,000.00).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The conditions of the bond may further provide that the obligation
of the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency,
failure, or closing of any bank or savings and loan association organized and
operating either under the laws of the state of Illinois or the United States
in which the officer has placed funds in the officer's custody, if the bank or
savings and loan association has been approved by the corporate authorities as
a depository for those funds.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Approval Of Bond: The exact form of the bond shall be approved by the
mayor, or his designee, and the city attorney; provided, that it is in
compliance with law and this section. (Ord. 2003-O-28, 5-6-2003)
ARTICLE A. CITY MANAGER
SECTION:
1-8A-1: Office Created
1-8A-2: Appointment; Term
1-8A-3: Removal From Office
1-8A-4: Duties
1-8A-5: Compensation
1-8A-6: Bond
1-8A-7: Temporary Absence Or Disability
1-8A-8: Vacancy; Manager Pro Tem
1-8A-9: Successor Office To City Administrator
1-8A-10: Conflicts With Other Ordinances
1-8A-1: OFFICE CREATED:
The office of city manager is created. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-2: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The city manager shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of
the city council for an indefinite term. The city manager shall be chosen on
the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special reference
to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the
duties of the office set forth in this article. The city council may in its
discretion choose to enter into an employment contract with the individual
chosen to be the city manager. The city manager shall be chosen without regard
to his or her political beliefs or affiliations and need not reside in the city
of Highwood. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-3: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The city manager may be removed at any time in accord with his or her
employment contract, if any, or in accord with section 3.1-35-10 of the
Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-10. (Ord. 2008-
O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-4: DUTIES:
The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the city and
shall be responsible to the city council for the proper administration of the
affairs of the city. The individual serving as the city manager shall devote
all of his/her professional time to the discharge of official duties and shall
have no other trade or business. The power and duties of the city manager shall
be to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Enforce all laws and ordinances of the city;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Attend all meetings of the city council. The city manager shall have
the right to take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the city
council, but shall have no right to vote. The city manager shall be entitled to
notice of all special and regular meetings of the city council. However, the
failure to notify the city manager of any meeting shall not affect the validity
of any action taken at such meeting;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Recommend to the city council adoption of such measures as may be
necessary or expedient;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Appoint, suspend or remove all employees of the city, except those
employees under the authority of the fire and police commission. Such
appointments, suspensions or removals shall be based upon the merit and fitness
of such employee, without regard to political belief or affiliation. The city
manager may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint, suspend or
remove subordinates in such department or office;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Exercise control of all departments and divisions thereof now in
existence, or that may hereafter be;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Make recommendations to the city council concerning compensation for
each appointive office and position in the city service, including minimum,
intermediate and maximum rates;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Recommend to the city council the creating, consolidating, combining
and eliminating of offices, positions and departments of the city;
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the
administration of the government of the city and services maintained by the
public utilities in the city and see that all franchises, permits and
privileges granted by the city are faithfully observed;
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Purchase all materials, supplies, equipment, personal services and
contracts for which funds are provided in the budget, but no item or personal
service which exceeds any budget appropriation may be purchased. The city
manager may make all budgeted purchases where the total cost is ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) or less. Any purchase of more than ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) must receive city council approval. For all purchases requiring
competitive bids as provided by law or ordinance, the city manager shall seek
bids and shall make recommendations to the city council with respect to all
such bids. Bidding requirements may be waived in accord with applicable law.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Issue rules and regulations governing requisitions and the transaction
of the business of the purchasing agent and the heads of departments, officers
and employees of the city. In case of circumstances creating an emergency, the
city manager may, without prior consent of the city council, award contracts
and make purchases for the purpose of meeting the emergency; but shall promptly
file with the city council a report of such emergency and the necessity of such
action, together with an itemized account of all such expenditures;
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Prepare a budget report indicating the funds necessary to defray the
estimated expenses of the city for the fiscal year; prepare the annual
appropriation ordinance in time for consideration and enactment by the city
council as required by statute; and prepare the annual tax levy;
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Submit to the city council, in accordance with state statute, following
the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and
administrative activities of the city for the fiscal year;
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â Present to the city council each month a joint statement with the city
treasurer showing the exact financial condition of the city as of the end of
the preceding month and showing amounts expended and unexpended balances for
each department in accordance with the annual budget;
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Keep a current inventory of all real and personal properties of the
city and the location of such property. The city manager shall be responsible
for the care and custody of all city properties which are not by statute or
ordinance assigned to some other officer or body for care and control;
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â Appoint to all boards, commissions and committees a staff individual to
act as a liaison and resource person, if necessary;
Â Â Â P.Â Â Â Authorize settlements and plea agreements, or the compromise and
satisfaction of judgments, in the prosecution of local ordinance violations; or
authorize another officer or attorney of the city to do so;
Â Â Â Q.Â Â Â Execute permit applications on behalf of the mayor and city council for
city of Highwood construction projects within Lake County rights of way;
Â Â Â R.Â Â Â Perform such other lawful duties as may be directed by motion,
resolution or ordinance of the city council. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-5: COMPENSATION:
The city manager shall receive such compensation as the city council shall fix
from time to time. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-6: BOND:
The city manager shall furnish a bond in such amount and with such surety as
may be approved by the city council, such bond shall be conditioned on the
faithful performance of duties and shall be conditioned to indemnify the city
for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the city manager.
The cost of the bond shall be paid by the city. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-7: TEMPORARY ABSENCE OR DISABILITY:
During the temporary absence or disability of the city manager, the city
manager shall appoint an acting city manager, with all the powers and duties of
the office. If the city manager is unable or fails to appoint an acting city
manager, the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council shall
appoint an acting city manager. The acting city manager may be removed from
office by a majority vote of the city council then holding office. If such an
appointment is of a person not already under bond to the city and such person
shall be acting city manager for more than thirty (30) consecutive days, such
appointee shall furnish a bond in accord with section
1-8A-6 of this article. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-8: VACANCY; MANAGER PRO TEM:
In case of a vacancy in the office of city manager, the mayor, with the advice
and consent of the city council, may appoint a manager pro tem who shall
possess the powers and duties of the city manager until such time as the office
is filled in accord with this article. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-9: SUCCESSOR OFFICE TO CITY ADMINISTRATOR:
With the repeal of ordinance 07-O-01, the office of city administrator is
eliminated. The individual holding the position of city administrator as of the
effective date hereof shall be the city manager subject to the terms of this
article and his or her employment agreement, if any, without further action of
the city council. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
1-8A-10: CONFLICTS WITH OTHER ORDINANCES:
Wherever the term city administrator or administrator appears in the ordinances
of the city, that term shall be deemed to mean the city manager upon the
effective date hereof. In the event of a conflict between this article and any
prior ordinance of the city, this article shall control to the extent allowed
at law. In the event any ordinance designates the mayor as the direct
supervisor of any employee, that ordinance is superseded by this article. The
mayor shall at all times retain his or her responsibilities as local liquor
commissioner. (Ord. 2008-O-24, 9-2-2008)
ARTICLE B. LEGAL SERVICES
SECTION:
1-8B-1: City Attorney
1-8B-2: City Prosecutor
1-8B-1: CITY ATTORNEY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Created; Appointment And Removal: There is hereby created the office of
city attorney, an executive office of the city. The city attorney shall be
appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, and
shall enjoy all of the emoluments of the office, whether appointed and holding
office as an independent contractor or as an employee. The city attorney shall
have direct communication with the mayor and city council and its members
individually as well as with other city officials. The city attorney may be
removed from office by the mayor in the manner provided by law.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Compensation: During his term, the city attorney shall receive such
compensation as may be fixed by contract from time to time.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Duties:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The city attorney shall be responsible for all legal matters
pertaining to the city. Upon request by the mayor, he shall render any given
legal opinion in writing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â From time to time, the city attorney may appoint additional counsel
to represent or advise the city on legal matters as special counsel. In the
event such special counsel is so appointed, compensation shall be recommended
by the city attorney.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The city attorney shall be the legal advisor to the boards and
commissions of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The city attorney shall prepare all ordinances and resolutions and
shall render opinions on city bond issues.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The city attorney shall perform such other duties as from time to
time directed by the mayor. (2009 Code)
1-8B-2: CITY PROSECUTOR:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Intent: No office is being created by this section nor shall any be
construed or implied by this section. It is the intent of this section to set
forth the scope of duties of any Illinois licensed attorney who will be acting
in his or her capacity as prosecuting attorney as an independent contractor,
"retained attorney", on behalf of the city. The mayor and city council
recognize that such "retained counsel", as has been deemed necessary by the
mayor acting in his capacity as the chief executive officer, has historically
been appointed by the mayor and hired as an independent contractor, "retained
counsel", who is terminable at will. Nothing contained in this section shall be
deemed to eliminate or restrict any powers of the mayor as may exist under the
law. (Ord. 2005-O-50, 9-20-2005)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Retained Attorney: The attorney or firm hired to act as city prosecutor
shall be governed in accordance with this section and specifically this
subsection. The retention of such attorney or firm and the regular duties of
any such attorney or firm shall be governed as follows: (Ord. 2005-O-50, 9-20-
2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Retention: The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city
council, may from time to time retain a city prosecutor to act as further set
forth herein and subject to the following conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The retained counsel hired to act as city prosecutor shall have
the status of an independent contractor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The city prosecutor shall be appointed by the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council, as provided by statute. The
qualifications and choice of attorney or law firm shall be the mayor's decision
to make in his executive capacity as set forth by statute.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The city prosecutor shall be retained until terminated by the
mayor, retained counsel resigns, and/or as otherwise provided by law, in which
event, a successor shall be appointed by the mayor to assume the duties called
for herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The city prosecutor shall be a licensed and practicing member of
the Illinois bar.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â A retainer agreement, spelling out the terms of hire as then
applicable, shall be executed by the city with the attorney or law firm
selected as city prosecutor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Duties: The duties of the city prosecutor shall include, without
limitation, the following: (Ord. 2005-O-50, 9-20-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Prosecuting suits or actions involving violations of ordinances,
traffic ordinances, including, but not limited to, driving under the influence,
and parking ordinances that arise in branch court, as well as citations
concerning driving under the influence. (Ord. 2005-O-50, 9-20-2005; amd. 2009
Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Providing advice to police officers and/or other officials
authorized by the city to issue citations, and on legal questions of criminal
traffic law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Filing with the mayor and city administrator a written monthly
report showing dates of court appearances, pending matters and final
dispositions for DUIs for the month in question.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Compensation: The city prosecutor shall be compensated in the manner
specified by the city salary ordinance and as set out in the retainer agreement
applicable to the city prosecutor's services, with the advice and consent of
the city council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Removal: The mayor alone may remove the city prosecutor on any
written charge whenever the mayor is of the opinion that the interests of the
city demand removal. (Ord. 2005-O-50, 9-20-2005)
ARTICLE C. COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-8C-1: Position Established
1-8C-2: Part Time Employees; Compensation
1-8C-3: Number Of Officers
1-8C-4: Supervision; Responsibilities
1-8C-1: POSITION ESTABLISHED:
In preparation of the annual budget for the upcoming fiscal year and following
years, the finance committee of the city council shall make provision for the
hiring of community service officers as specified in this article. (Ord. 92-O-
17, 4-21-1992)
1-8C-2: PART TIME EMPLOYEES; COMPENSATION:
Each community service officer shall be a part time employee of the city and
shall be compensated at the rate established by the city council. (Ord. 92-O-
17, 4-21-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
1-8C-3: NUMBER OF OFFICERS:
The chief of police shall hire such number of community service officers as are
necessary to ensure that a community service officer will be scheduled for duty
Monday through Friday of each week (exclusive of parking holidays) for
approximately six (6) hours per day. (Ord. 92-O-17, 4-21-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
1-8C-4: SUPERVISION; RESPONSIBILITIES:
The community service officers' day to day activities shall be supervised by
the chief of police and/or his designee. The community service officers'
primary responsibility shall be for enforcement of parking regulations in the
business and residential districts by the issuance of citations. Further, such
community service officers shall be responsible for enforcement of the city's
vehicle sticker ordinance and other related duties, as determined by the chief
of police. Enforcement of the parking and city sticker regulations shall be by
way of issuance of citation and/or public relations by the issuance of
information and other public relations measures to ensure maximum compliance
with the aforesaid city ordinances. (Ord. 92-O-17, 4-21-1992)
CHAPTER 9
ETHICS
SECTION:
1-9-1: State Regulations Adopted
1-9-2: Definitions
1-9-3: Interpretation
1-9-4: Prohibited Acts
1-9-5: Penalties
1-9-6: Ethics Advisor
1-9-7: Amendments
1-9-8: Unconstitutionality Of Provisions
1-9-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The regulations of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/5-15 and 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/10-10 through 430/10-40 of the state officials and
employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this chapter), are hereby adopted by reference and
made applicable to the officers and employees of the city to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, all the terms including, but not limited to,
"gift", "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c). (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
1-9-3: INTERPRETATION:
This chapter does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of officers and employees
(other than city ordinance 1999-O-40, "an ordinance prohibiting the
solicitation and acceptance of gifts and adopting the state gift ban act", (5
ILCS 425/1 et seq.; P.A. 90-737)). To the extent that any such existing
ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this chapter, however, the
provisions of this chapter shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5
Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a). (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Gifts:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Except as permitted under the act, the solicitation or acceptance of
gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act by any officer or
any employee of the city is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004; amd.
2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to
an officer or employee of the city under the act is hereby prohibited.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Political Activities: The participation in political activities
prohibited under the act by any officer or employee of the city is hereby
prohibited. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-5: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as those
penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-6: ETHICS ADVISOR:
To the extent authorized by law, the city attorney is appointed to serve as the
ethics advisor of the city. The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the
officers and employees of the city concerning the interpretation of and
compliance with the provisions of this chapter and state ethics laws. The
ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the
corporate authorities. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-7: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date hereof
shall be incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be applicable to
the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited
political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional
for adoption by the city shall not be incorporated into this chapter by
reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the city. (Ord.
2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)
1-9-8: UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OF PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In the event that the Illinois supreme court declares the act
unconstitutional in its entirety, then this chapter shall be repealed as of the
date that the Illinois supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject
to any further appeals or rehearings. This chapter shall be deemed repealed
without further action by the corporate authorities of the city if the act is
found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In the event that the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act,
or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as
adopted by this chapter shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this chapter relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of
the city. (Ord. 2004-O-40, 5-18-2004)

CHAPTER 11
EMERGENCY POWERS
SECTION:
1-11-1: Mayor's Authority To Declare A State Of Emergency
1-11-1: MAYOR'S AUTHORITY TO DECLARE A STATE OF EMERGENCY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Mayor is hereby authorized to render a declaration of a state of
emergency within the City based on the following findings and supporting facts:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â There has occurred, or there is an actual imminent danger of the
occurrence of, a natural disaster, catastrophe, pestilence, contagious disease
or other public health emergency, which is likely to cause loss of life, loss
of productivity, hardship or suffering to the persons residing in or doing
business in the City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The declaration of a state of emergency and the actions to be taken
pursuant to that declaration are specifically designed to, and likely to,
address and alleviate the potential loss of life, loss of productivity,
hardship and suffering.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The declaration of a state of emergency shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Be in writing and executed under oath;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Set forth the basis and underlying facts supporting the declaration
of a state of emergency;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Make reference to published statements of federal, state or county
agencies whose duty it is to address emergency matters;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â To the extent possible, specify the procedures and protocols to be
followed during the state of emergency;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â To the extent possible, make specific reference to any regulations
which may be subject to suspension during the state of emergency; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Consistent with subsection E. below, set forth the duration of the
state of emergency.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The declaration of a state of emergency shall be filed with the City
Clerk as soon as practicable after being issued.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â During said state of emergency, the Mayor shall be authorized to
exercise, by executive order, such powers of the Corporate Authorities as may
be reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any state of emergency declared pursuant to this section shall expire
no later than the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the Corporate
Authorities after the state of emergency has been declared.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â A declaration of a state of emergency, pursuant to this section, may
not suspend in any way the rights of residents of the City under the Illinois
Constitution or the United States Constitution. (Ord. 20-O-16, 8-4-2020)
TITLE 2
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Appointment And Terms
2-1-2: Residency Requirement
2-1-3: Organization
2-1-4: Meetings And Records
2-1-5: Removals
2-1-6: Powers And Duties
2-1-7: References In Zoning Ordinance
2-1-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERMS:
The planning and zoning commission shall consist of nine (9) members. The
members of the planning and zoning commission shall be appointed by the mayor,
subject to the confirmation of the city council. The members of the planning
and zoning commission shall serve respectively for the following terms: three
(3) for one year, three (3) for two (2) years, and three (3) for three (3)
years. The successor of each member so appointed shall serve for a term of
three (3) years. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
2-1-2: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT:
Members of the planning and zoning commission shall reside within the city or
within territory contiguous to the city and not more than one and one-half (11/
2) miles beyond the corporate limits and not included within any other
municipality. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Officers: On an annual basis, no later than the first meeting of the
planning and zoning commission after May 1 of each year, the members of the
planning and zoning commission shall organize by the election of a chair, vice
chair, secretary, and any such other officers as may, in their judgment, be
necessary or convenient. Such officers shall hold office until the first
meeting after May 1 of the following year.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bylaws: The planning and zoning commission shall adopt such bylaws
governing their procedures and regulating their business, from time to time, as
they deem proper and necessary. The adoption, amendment or revision of bylaws
shall be by majority vote of the commission; provided, however, that every
member of the commission shall be furnished a copy of such bylaws, amendments
or revisions within ten (10) days after the day of adoption. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-
17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
2-1-4: MEETINGS AND RECORDS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Meetings: All meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of
the chair and at such other times as the commission may determine. All meetings
and public hearings shall be noticed in accordance with applicable law. All
meetings and public hearings of the commission shall be open to the public.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Minutes And Records: The commission shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon every question or, if absent
or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its
examinations and other official actions. Findings of fact shall be included in
the minutes of each case, as required, and the reasons for the recommendations
concerning each application shall be specified. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff.
5-1-2015)
2-1-5: REMOVALS:
If any member of the planning and zoning commission fails to attend three (3)
consecutive meetings, or fails to attend one- half (1/2) of all commission
meetings scheduled or called during any twelve (12) month period, such failure
to attend shall constitute cause for the removal of such member of the
commission. Such member of the commission may be removed either by a
recommendation by a majority vote of the remaining members of the planning and
zoning commission, which recommendation shall be forwarded to the city council
for action; or by action of the city council without the recommendation or
action by the remaining members of the planning and zoning commission. Any
vacancy created shall be filled by the mayor for the duration of the term of
said member of the planning and zoning commission, with the advice and consent
of the city council. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
2-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The planning and zoning commission shall have the following powers and
responsibilities:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To prepare and recommend to the city council an official comprehensive
plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the city, which
plan shall be known as "The City Of Highwood Official Comprehensive Plan". Such
plan may be adopted in separate geographical or functional parts, each of
which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof,
of the city. The official plan may include reasonable requirements with
reference to streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements hereinafter
specified. The plan, as recommended by the plan commission and thereafter
adopted by the city council, shall be applicable, by the terms thereof, to
lands situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more
than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of the city, and
not included within the limits of any other city, village or incorporated town,
which shall be designated on the official map of the city. Any ordinances of
the city: 1) establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions or
resubdivisions of unimproved land and areas subject to redevelopment in respect
to public improvements as herein defined; or 2) establishing reasonable
requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public
streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs,
gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of
lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and
distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment shall
constitute part of the official plan of the city. The official plan may also
include a plan designating land suitable for annexation to the city and
recommending the zoning classification for such land upon annexation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To prepare and recommend to the city council, from time to time, such
changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the council or by the
planning and zoning commission.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â To prepare and recommend to the council, from time to time, plans for
specific improvements pursuant to the provisions of such official plan.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â To prepare and recommend to the council an official map of the city and
to prepare and recommend to the council from time to time revisions in said
map.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â To call upon any officials of the city for aid and advice upon any
matter properly within the scope of interest of the plan commission and to give
aid to the officials of the city charged with direction of projects for
improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the making of such
improvements and, generally, to promote the realization of the official plan.
If the planning and zoning commission shall deem it advisable to secure
technical advice or service, it may do so upon authority from and by the
council and appropriation by the council therefor.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities schemes
regulating or forbidding structures or activities which may hinder access to
solar energy necessary for the proper functioning of "solar energy systems", as
defined in section 1.2 of the comprehensive solar energy act of 1977, or to
recommend changes in such schemes.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â To conduct all hearings as required pursuant to the city zoning
ordinance.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â To hear applications for variations and special use permits, as
required by the city zoning ordinance, and appeals from and review any order,
requirement, decision or determination made by the zoning administrator charged
with enforcement of title 11 of this code.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by this
chapter as may, from time to time, be conferred by the city council.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Notwithstanding the above, the planning and zoning commission shall
have no powers or responsibilities which have been otherwise delegated to the
Fort Sheridan joint plan commission, pursuant to title 11, chapter 3, article A
of this code. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
2-1-7: REFERENCES IN ZONING ORDINANCE:
Any reference to the plan commission or zoning board of appeals contained in
title 11 of this code shall hereby be deemed a reference to the city of
Highwood planning and zoning commission. (Ord. 15-O-11, 3-17-2015, eff. 5-1-
2015)

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The board shall conduct and hold all entrance and promotional

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The board shall provide that, as a condition of appointment, an

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Demotion: Following written charges and a hearing as provided by

suspension that may be also be imposed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Discharge: Following written charges and a hearing, as provided by

Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The board shall have the power to perform such other duties as

CHAPTER 9
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PLANNING COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-9-1: Created; Membership
2-9-2: Responsibilities
2-9-3: Annual Report
2-9-4: Adoption Of Capital Improvement Program
2-9-5: Availability Of Report And Capital Budget
2-9-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP:
The capital improvement planning committee is created. The city council shall
establish and appoint a committee to be known as the "capital improvement
planning committee", composed of two (2) members of the city council and one
member of the finance committee. The city manager shall be an ex officio
committee staff member without the right to vote. The committee shall choose
its own chairperson. (Ord. 2008-O-28, 9-16-2008)
2-9-2: RESPONSIBILITIES:
The committee shall study proposed capital projects and improvements involving
major nonrecurring tangible assets and projects which: a) are purchased or
undertaken at intervals of not less than five (5) years; b) have a useful life
of at least five (5) years; and c) cost over ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
All department heads, boards and committees, including the city council, shall,
by October of each year, give to the committee, on forms prepared thereby,
information concerning all anticipated projects requiring city council action
during the ensuing five (5) years. The committee shall consider the relative
need, impact, timing and cost of these expenditures and the effect each will
have on the financial position of the city. No appropriation shall be voted for
a capital improvement requested by a department, board or commission unless the
proposed capital improvement is considered in the committee's report. (Ord.
2008-O-28, 9-16-2008; amd. 2009 Code)
2-9-3: ANNUAL REPORT:
The committee shall prepare an annual report recommending a capital improvement
budget for the next fiscal year and a capital improvement program, including
recommended capital improvements for the following five (5) fiscal years. The
report shall be submitted to the city council for its consideration and
approval. (Ord. 2008-O-28, 9-16-2008)
2-9-4: ADOPTION OF CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM:
The capital improvement program, after its adoption, shall permit the
expenditure on projects included therein of sums from departmental budgets for
surveys, architectural or engineering advice, options or appraisals; but no
such expenditure shall be incurred on projects which have not been so approved
by the city through the appropriation of sums in the current year or in prior
years, or for preliminary planning for projects to be undertaken more than five
(5) years in the future. (Ord. 2008-O-28, 9-16-2008)
2-9-5: AVAILABILITY OF REPORT AND CAPITAL BUDGET:
The committee's report and the city council's recommended capital budget shall
be published and made available in a manner consistent with the distribution of
the finance committee report. The committee shall deposit its original report
with the city clerk and provide a copy for review with the city public library.
(Ord. 2008-O-28, 9-16-2008)

TITLE 3
FINANCE AND TAXATION
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL FINANCE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Fiscal Year
3-1-2: City Depositories
3-1-3: Investment Policy
3-1-4: Fixed Asset Policy
3-1-5: Payment Of Bills To Avoid Late Charges
3-1-1: FISCAL YEAR:
As previously provided by the city, and as authorized and pursuant to 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1-2, the fiscal year for the city shall be from
May 1 of each year through April 30 of the following year. (Ord. 98-O-45, 5-19-
1998)
3-1-2: CITY DEPOSITORIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The city council shall, from time to time, by resolution, designate
depositories in which funds or monies belonging to the city shall be kept.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Such designated depositories shall be financial institutions that are
members of the FDIC system with asset size of five hundred million dollars
($500,000,000.00) or greater and a capital ratio ten percent (10%) or greater.
In addition, city funds shall not be maintained in any financial institution
that is not willing or capable of posting required collateral, or purchasing
private insurance for funds in excess of FDIC insurable limits.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In order to qualify as a depository for city funds, the financial
institution must furnish copies of the latest two (2) statements of resources
and liabilities that it is required to furnish to the commissioner of banks and
real estate, or to the comptroller of currency. (Ord. 12-O-16, 4-3-2012)
3-1-3: INVESTMENT POLICY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Policy: It is the policy of the city to invest public funds in a manner
which will provide the highest investment return with the maximum security
while meeting the daily cash flow demands of the city and conforming to all
state and local statutes governing the investment of public funds.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Scope: This section shall apply to all funds governed by the city
council.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Prudence:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under
circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and
intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for
speculation, but for investment, considering the probable safety of their
capital, as well as the probable income to be derived.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The standard of prudence to be used by investment officials shall be
the "prudent person" standard and shall be applied in the context of managing
an overall portfolio.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Objective:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The primary objective, in order of priority, shall be:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Legality: Conformance with federal, state and other legal
requirements.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Safety: Preservation of capital and protection of investment
principal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Liquidity: Maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet operating
requirements.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Yield: Attainment of market rates of return.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The city's portfolio should be reviewed periodically as to its
effectiveness in meeting the city's needs for safety, liquidity, rate of
return, diversification and its general performance.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Delegation Of Authority: Management and administrative responsibility
for the investment program is hereby delegated to the treasurer who, under such
delegation of the city council, shall establish procedures for the operation of
the investment program.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Ethics And Conflicts Of Interest: Officers and employees involved in
the investment process shall refrain from personal business activity that could
conflict with the proper execution and management of the investment program, or
that could impair their ability to make impartial decisions.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Authorized Financial Dealers And Institutions: The treasurer will
maintain a list of financial institutions authorized to provide investment
services. Further, the treasurer will maintain a list of approved security
brokers/dealers which shall be selected by credit worthiness.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Authorized And Suitable Investments: Investments may be made in any
type of security allowed for in Illinois statutes regarding the investment of
public funds. Investments shall be made that reflect the cash flow needs of the
fund type being invested.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Collateralization: Funds on deposit (checking accounts, certificates of
deposit, etc.) in excess of FDIC limits must be secured by some form of
collateral, witnessed by a written agreement and held at an independent third
party institution in the name of the city.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Safekeeping And Custody: All security transactions, including
collateral for repurchase agreements, entered into by the city shall be
conducted on a delivery versus payment (DVP) basis. Securities will be held by
an independent third party custodian designated by the treasurer and evidenced
by safekeeping receipts and a written custodial agreement.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Diversification: The city's policy is diversification of its investment
portfolio based on the type of funds invested and the cash flow needs of those
funds. Diversification can be by type of investment, number of institutions
invested in, and length of maturity.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Maximum Maturities:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To the extent possible, the treasurer shall attempt to match the
city's investments with anticipated cash flow requirements. Unless matched to a
specific cash flow, the treasurer will not directly invest in securities
maturing more than two (2) years from the date of purchase.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Reserve funds may be invested in securities exceeding two (2) years
if the maturity of such investments is made to coincide as nearly as
practicable with the expected use of the funds.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â Internal Control: The treasurer is responsible for establishing and
maintaining an internal control structure designed to ensure that the assets of
the city are protected from loss, theft or misuse. The internal control
structure shall be designed to provide reasonable assurance that these
objectives are met. The internal controls shall address the following points:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Control of collusion.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Separation of transaction authority from accounting.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Custodial safekeeping.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Written confirmation of telephone transactions for investments and
wire transfers.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Performance Standards: The investment portfolio will be managed in
accordance with the parameters specified within this section. The portfolio
should obtain a comparable rate of return during a market/economic environment
of stable interest rates. Portfolio performance should be compared to
benchmarks with similar maturity, liquidity and credit quality as the
portfolio, such as the IPTIP fund.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â Reporting: The treasurer shall prepare an investment report at least
quarterly. The report should be provided to the city council and shall be
available on request. The report should be in a format suitable for review by
the general public. An annual report should also be provided to the council.
Such report shall include a statement of the market value of the portfolio.
Â Â Â P.Â Â Â Adoption; Annual Review: This section is hereby adopted by the city
council. This section shall be reviewed on an annual basis by the treasurer,
and any proposed modifications shall be forwarded to the city council for
approval. (Ord. 99-O-77, 12-7-1999)
3-1-4: FIXED ASSET POLICY:
The fixed asset policy of the city contained in this section is hereby adopted.
The city shall implement such fixed asset policy and comply with its
requirements until such time as said policy is amended, rescinded, or updated.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Purpose: The purpose of this section is to provide guidance for the
control and accountability of fixed assets, and the collection and maintenance
of the information needed in the preparation of financial statements. The city
fixed asset policy is herein established to safeguard city assets and to ensure
compliance with GASB34 for governmental financial reporting.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Overview:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â This section is established to safeguard and address the city's
investment in property, which represents a significant resource. This section
is meant to ensure compliance with various accounting and financial reporting
standards including generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), and
governmental accounting, auditing, and financial reporting (GAAFR).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Further, this section is meant to reflect the city's desire to meet
the reporting requirements set forth in the governmental accounting standards
board (GASB) statement no. 34 (which is effective for fiscal year ending April
30, 2005). Specifically, the GASB statement no. 34 states that governments
should provide additional disclosures in their summary of significant
accounting policies including the policy for capitalizing assets and for
estimating the useful lives of those assets, which is used to calculate the
depreciation expense. The statement also requires disclosure of major classes
of assets, beginning and end of year balances, capital acquisition, sales/
dispositions, and current period depreciation expense.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Inventory, Valuation, Capitalization And Depreciation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Inventory:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Responsibility for control of fixed assets rests with the
operating department wherein the asset is located. The city administrator shall
ensure that such control is maintained by establishing an inclusive fixed asset
inventory schedule. Asset acquisitions that fall below the capitalization
threshold will not be included in the fixed asset inventory.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Each department will be responsible for control of fixed assets
for its department. The department head shall ensure that such control is
maintained by establishing a fixed asset inventory schedule. The inventory
schedule will include the following for each asset:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â A description of the asset including the serial number and
model number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Asset classification (land and land improvements, building
and building improvements, vehicles, machinery and equipment, or infrastructure
assets).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Department name and physical location of asset.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Date asset was purchased/acquired and/or disposed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Method of acquisition (purchased or donated).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Cost of asset.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Estimated useful life.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The inventory schedule will be maintained, updated, and reviewed
by the department head and provided to the city administrator on an ongoing
basis. (Ord. 2005-O-19, 4-6-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Capitalizing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â When To Capitalize Assets: Assets are capitalized at the time of
acquisition. To be considered a capital asset for financial reporting purposes,
an item must be at or above the capitalization threshold (see the fixed asset
schedule, subsection D of this section) and have a useful life of at least one
year.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â When Not To Capitalize Assets: Capital assets that are below the
capitalization threshold on a unit basis but have value and warrant "control"
are not capitalized. These assets shall be inventoried at the department level
and an appropriate list maintained by the owning department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Criteria: Capital assets should be capitalized if they meet the
following criteria:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The asset is tangible.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The asset has a useful life of more than one year (the
benefit exists for more than a single fiscal period).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Cost exceeds the designated threshold.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Classes Of Assets: Capital assets include the following major
classes of assets:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Land And Land Improvements: Capitalized value is to include
the purchase price, plus costs such as legal fees and filing fees. Improvements
are classified as items such as parking lots, fences, pedestrian bridges, and
landscaping.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Building And Building Improvements: Costs include purchase
price, plus costs such as legal fees and filing fees. Improvements include
structures and all other property permanently attached to or are an integral
part of the structure. These costs include building systems such as roofing,
electrical/plumbing, carpeting, and HVAC.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Vehicles: Costs include purchase price, plus costs such as
title and registration or other necessary equipment installed on the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Machinery And Equipment: Assets included in this category are
heavy equipment, operating or control systems, pumps, valves, and generators.
Office equipment is classified as nonexpendable items such as a phone system or
kitchen equipment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Infrastructure Assets: Infrastructure assets are long lived
capital assets that are stationary in nature and normally can be preserved for
a significantly greater number of years than most capital assets. Included in
this category are roads/streets, curbs, sidewalks, water systems, water tanks,
water towers, and sewer and drainage systems.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Depreciation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Depreciation will be computed using a straight line method with
depreciation computed on a monthly basis from the month of acquisition.
Additions and improvements will only be capitalized if the cost either enhances
the asset's functionality or extends the asset's useful life. As such, the
following costs for improvements are expensed as opposed to being capitalized:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Road resurfacing or sealing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Sidewalk or curb patching.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Realignment of sewer lines.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Manhole restorations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Water main repairs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Projects in process will be added to the asset base as the
projected expenses are incurred. However, the project first needs to meet its
individual threshold ($50,000.00 for building projects, $150,000.00 for
infrastructure projects).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Annexations (related land, rights of way, and infrastructure
including roads, water system, and sanitary and storm sewers) will be added to
the asset base in total on the date the annexation is accepted by the city (via
council action). Upon completion, the appropriate documentation will be
prepared and the component value of the annexation added to the books. In some
cases, parks may be added to the asset base before the rest of the annexation.
(Ord. 2005-O-19, 4-6-2005; amd. 2009 Code)

Â 
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Removing Fixed Assets From Inventory: Fixed assets are to be removed
from inventory once they are obsolete or claimed to be surplus property. The
item must be removed from the department inventory listing and reported by the
department head to the city administrator in order to update the inventory
listing.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Donations Or Transfer: Each department head will add additions and
deletions from donated or transferred assets to the inventory listing.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Surplus Property: Each department head will report all fixed assets
classified as surplus to the city administrator. The city will have a
negotiated sale, auction, or sealed bid as needed to sell the surplus property.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Lost Or Stolen Property: When suspected or known losses of inventoried
assets occur, the department owning the lost asset should conduct a search for
the missing property. The search should include the possibility that the
property was transferred to another department, placed in storage, scrapped,
and/or removed as surplus property. If the missing property is not found, the
department head must notify the city administrator of the lost property. (Ord.
2005-O-19, 4-6-2005)
3-1-5: PAYMENT OF BILLS TO AVOID LATE CHARGES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In the event a situation occurs, including, but not limited to,
cancellation of a city council meeting, when certain bills, as outlined below,
must be paid prior to formal city council approval in order to avoid incurring
additional late charges, the city manager, or his designee, is hereby
authorized to pay such bills in order to avoid any additional charges.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â This section shall apply to the following bills:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Utilities (telephone, natural gas, electric, sanitary sewer);
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Employee benefit payments;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Amounts related to contracts for professional services previously
approved by city council;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Debt service payments for all approved debt; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â All lease payments for leases previously approved by city council.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the event any bill is paid prior to formal city council approval in
accordance with this section, the bill shall be included on the list of bills
at the next regular city council meeting for ratification. (Ord. 13-O-32, 5-21-
2013)

3-2A-2: TIME OF PAYMENT; DELINQUENCIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Payment of the fees provided herein shall be made at the earlier of the
following:

provision related to fees, the most recent provisions shall control. (Ord.

3-2A-5: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, or corporation, or employee of same,
violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In addition to any penalty or fine levied under subsection A of this
section, any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation in violation of
any provision of this article shall pay, as an additional fine or penalty, any
and all reasonable attorney fees incurred by the City in enforcing this
article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the event the City deems it necessary to bring any court action to
enforce this article, there shall be assessed, as an additional fine or penalty
against any person, partnership, firm or corporation violating this article,
all reasonable costs, expenses and attorney fees incurred by the City in
bringing said action, in addition to the fine provided in subsection A of this
section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Further provided, that the total of all fines assessed under
subsections A, B and C of this section shall not exceed one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each offense, as defined herein.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity
or corporation for violation of the provisions of this article shall not
release such person from paying any fee due and unpaid at the time of such
conviction, nor shall payment of any fine prevent prosecution for violation of
any of the provisions of this article.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The amount of any fee due hereunder shall be deemed a debt to the City.
An action may be commenced in the name of the City in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent fee. All unpaid fees shall be
deemed delinquent after they are due and payable.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the City shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 2007-O-13, 5-1-
2007)

outside consultants that occur as a result of the proposed development. At no
time shall the amount on deposit be less than fifty percent (50%) of the
original deposit. In the event the deposit is depleted to fifty percent (50%)
of the original deposit, then the developer shall replenish the deposit to one
percent (1%) of the estimated cost of construction as determined by the

3-2B-26: STOP WORK ORDER:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Authority: The Building Official, Fire Chief, and/or the Fire Chief's
designee, or his authorized representative, is hereby empowered and directed to

proposed for unlawful purposes as regards location, intended use, or occupancy;
any work that in any other respect is being done contrary to the provisions of
this Code or to the requirements of any other laws of the City. This right
shall exist and be performed irrespective of any permit that may or may not
have been either required or issued for the work, building, structure, or any
portion thereof involved. (Ord. 2007-O-28, 8-21-2007; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Unlawful Continuance: Any person who shall continue any work in or
about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except
such work as he is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe
condition, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a
separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 2007-O-28, 8-21-2007)

Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The total of all fines assessed under subsections A, B and C of this

3-2B-28: PROFESSIONAL SERVICES ESCROW:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person requesting consideration or action, submitting applications
to, seeking review of projects or otherwise seeking appearance before the City
Council, Plan Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals, Appearance Review Committee,
or any other board, commission or committee of the City, shall be required
whenever practicable to deposit sufficient funds necessary to defray
anticipated professional consultant expenses to be incurred by the City.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The Community Development Director, Finance Director or City Manager
shall, upon receipt of a matter which may or will require professional
consultant services to be rendered or utilized by the City, whenever
practicable make an estimate of the amount of the cost of expected services
based on the nature of the matter, its complexity, the relative need for
professional consultant advice and the expected duration of processing the
matter. The Community Development Director, Finance Director or City Manager
shall so notify the individual applicant in writing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â With the estimate of the necessary funds to defray all professional
costs the City might incur in the course of reviewing the matter submitted by
the applicant or other individual, which estimate shall be derived from the
approved fee schedule in effect or when necessary by consultation with the
professionals who are expected to render services regarding the matter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â With notice to the individual or applicant that the application or
matter shall not thereafter be reviewed or acted upon unless and until said sum
is received by the Community Development Director or City Manager.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The Community Development Director, Finance Director or City Manager
shall periodically review the funds on deposit to ensure that adequate funds
are available to satisfy all professional statements referring to said matter,
in addition to any administrative fees as required by ordinance or fee
schedule. In the event the Community Development Director, Finance Director or
City Manager determines that sufficient funds are not available, the Community
Development Director, Finance Director or City Manager shall notify the
applicant or other individual and request a further amount to defray the
anticipated additional costs in accordance with the standards set forth in this
section. The professionals previously engaged will be advised not to do any
further work until said sum has been received and the individual or applicant
shall be given fourteen (14) days to deposit the additional funds. In the event
that said funds are not deposited, the City shall take no further action on the
matter and shall so notify the applicant or other individual.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Upon conclusion of the matter and after all outstanding professional
fees incurred by the City for review of said matter have been satisfied in
full, the Community Development Director, Finance Director or City Manager
shall cause any remaining balance in the escrow account, if any, to be remitted
to the person who had deposited the funds. (Ord. 2011-O-29, 9-6-2011)

3-2C-1: CURRENT RATE:
Users of ambulance services in the city of Highwood shall pay to the city of

SECTION:

3-2D-1: DEBT COLLECTION ESTABLISHED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The amount of any fee issued by the city and not paid by the due date
shall be deemed a debt to the city. An action may be commenced in the name of
the city for the amount of any delinquent fee. All unpaid fees shall be deemed
delinquent after they are due and payable.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The city may engage the services of a private debt collection agency to
collect delinquent fees.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The city manager may select the collection agency to be utilized by the
city and direct such agency to collect debts on behalf of the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 15-O-19, 4-21-
2015)
3-2D-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any debt thirty (30) days or more past due from the date of the
original invoice shall be submitted to the city's collection agency. The agency
shall collect such debts on behalf of the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Specific procedures surrounding the debt collection shall be governed
by state statute and the executed agreement between the city and the debt
collection agency.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The city manager may establish reasonable rules and regulations
governing the administration of the city's debt collection program. (Ord. 15-O-
19, 4-21-2015)
3-2D-3: PENALTIES AND FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Eligible debts as defined by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1 may
be collected by a third party collection agency.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A default in the payment of a fine or penalty or any installment of a
fine or penalty owed to the city may be collected by any means authorized for
the collection of monetary judgments. Any fees or costs incurred by the city in
the retention of private collection agencies for the collection of any fine or
penalty imposed shall be charged to the offender. This includes any default in
a fine or penalty or any installment of a fine or penalty that was previously
referred to an attorney or private collection agency and the payment of which
remains outstanding.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Upon delinquency, a thirty five percent (35%) cost of collection will
be added to any outstanding balance; the total debt may be reported to the
person's credit bureau file and submitted to the local debt recovery program.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Debts that are ineligible for participation under 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-2-1 will be recovered with a contingency fee of thirty percent
(30%) of the total debt. (Ord. 15-O-19, 4-21-2015)
3-2D-4: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this article and
any other provision related to debt collection, the most recent provisions
shall control. (Ord. 15-O-19, 4-21-2015)
CHAPTER 3
HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION AND SERVICE OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
3-3-1: Taxes Imposed
3-3-2: Exclusions
3-3-3: Administration And Enforcement By State
3-3-1: TAXES IMPOSED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax: Pursuant to 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1, a tax is hereby imposed effective July 1, 2015,
upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property
at retail in the city, other than an item of tangible personal property titled
or registered with an agency of the state, at the rate of one and three-fourths
percent (1.75%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of
such business while this chapter is in effect.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax: Pursuant to 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5, a tax is hereby imposed effective July 1, 2015,
upon all persons engaged in the city in the business of making sales of service
at the rate of one and three-fourths percent (1.75%) of the selling price of
all tangible personal property transferred by such servicemen, either in the
form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate, as an
incident to a sale of service. (Ord. 15-O-13, 3-17-2015)
3-3-2: EXCLUSIONS:
The home rule municipal service occupation tax and the home rule municipal
retailers' occupation tax shall not be applicable to the sales of food for
human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold
(other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared
for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines,
drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, and syringes
and needles used by diabetics. (Ord. 2007-O-11, 3-13-2007)
3-3-3: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT BY STATE:
The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the state department of
revenue. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and
enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-O-11, 3-13-2007)

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following meanings:
Â Â Â AMOUNT PAID: The amount charged to the taxpayer's service address in the
city regardless of where such amount is billed or paid.
Â Â Â DEPARTMENT: The Illinois department of revenue.
Â Â Â GROSS CHARGE: The amount paid for the act or privilege of originating or
receiving telecommunications in the city and for all services and equipment
provided in connection therewith by a retailer, valued in money, whether paid
in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and property of every
kind or nature, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the
cost of such telecommunications, the cost of the materials used, labor or
service costs or any other expense whatsoever. In case credit is extended, the
amount thereof shall be included only as and when paid. "Gross charges" for
private line service shall include charges imposed at each channel point within
this state, charges for the channel mileage between each channel point within
this state, and charges for that portion of the interstate interoffice channel
provided within Illinois. However, "gross charge" shall not include:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any amounts added to a purchaser's bill because of a charge made

internal revenue code; d) 911 surcharges; or e) charges added to customers'
bills pursuant to the provisions of section 9-221 or 9-222 of the public
utilities act 3 , as amended, or any similar charges added to customers' bills
by retailers who are not subject to rate regulation by the Illinois commerce
commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax liabilities or other
amounts specified in those provisions of the public utilities act;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Charges for a sent collect telecommunication received outside of the
city;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Charges for leased time on equipment or charges for the storage of
data or information for subsequent retrieval or the processing of data or
information intended to change its form or content. Such equipment includes,
but is not limited to, the use of calculators, computers, data processing
equipment, tabulating equipment or accounting equipment and also includes the
usage of computers under a timesharing agreement;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Charges for customer equipment, including such equipment that is
leased or rented by the customer from any source, wherein such charges are
disaggregated and separately identified from other charges;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Charges to business enterprises certified as exempt under section 9-
222.1 of the public utilities act 4 , to the extent of such exemption and
during the period of time specified by the department of commerce and economic
opportunity;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Charges for telecommunications and all services and equipment
provided in connection therewith between a parent corporation and its wholly
owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries when the tax imposed
under this section has already been paid to a retailer and only to the extent
that the charges between the parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries
or between wholly owned subsidiaries represent expense allocation between the
corporations and not the generation of profit for the corporation rendering
such service;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Bad debts ("bad debt" means any portion of a debt that is related to
a sale at retail for which gross charges are not otherwise deductible or
excludable that has become worthless or uncollectible, as determined under
applicable federal income tax standards; if the portion of the debt deemed to
be bad is subsequently paid, the retailer shall report and pay the tax on that
portion during the reporting period in which the payment is made);
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Charges paid by inserting coins in coin operated telecommunications
devices; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Amounts paid by telecommunications retailers under the

Â Â Â INTERSTATE TELECOMMUNICATIONS: All telecommunications that either originate
or terminate outside this state.
Â Â Â INTRASTATE TELECOMMUNICATIONS: All telecommunications that originate and
terminate within this state.
Â Â Â PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability
company, or a receiver, trustee, guardian, or other representative appointed by
order of any court, the federal and state governments, including state
universities created by statute, or any city, town, county, or other political
subdivision of this state.
Â Â Â PURCHASE AT RETAIL: The acquisition, consumption or use of
telecommunications through a sale at retail.
Â Â Â RETAILER: Means and includes every person engaged in the business of making
"sales at retail" as defined in this section. The department may, in its
discretion, upon application, authorize the collection of the tax hereby
imposed by any retailer not maintaining a place of business within this state,
who, to the satisfaction of the department, furnishes adequate security to
ensure collection and payment of the tax. Such retailer shall be issued,
without charge, a permit to collect such tax. When so authorized, it shall be
the duty of such retailer to collect the tax upon all of the gross charges for
telecommunications in this state in the same manner and subject to the same
requirements as a retailer maintaining a place of business within this state.
The permit may be revoked by the department at its discretion.
Â Â Â RETAILER MAINTAINING A PLACE OF BUSINESS IN THIS STATE (Or Any Like Term):
Means and includes any retailer having or maintaining within this state,
directly or by a subsidiary, an office, distribution facilities, transmission
facilities, sales office, warehouse or other place of business, or any agent or
other representative operating within this state under the authority of the
retailer or its subsidiary, irrespective of whether such place of business or
agent or other representative is located here permanently or temporarily, or
whether such retailer or subsidiary is licensed to do business in this state.
Â Â Â SALE AT RETAIL: The transmitting, supplying or furnishing of
telecommunications and all services and equipment provided in connection
therewith, for a consideration, to persons other than the federal and state
governments, and state universities created by statute, and other than between
a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, or between wholly owned
subsidiaries for their use or consumption and not for resale.
Â Â Â SERVICE ADDRESS: The location of telecommunications equipment from which
telecommunications services are originated or at which telecommunications
services are received by a taxpayer. In the event this may not be a defined
location, as in the case of mobile phones, paging systems, and maritime
systems, "service address" means the customer's place of primary use as defined
in the mobile telecommunications sourcing conformity act 6 . For air-to-ground
systems and the like, "service address" shall mean the location of a taxpayer's
primary use of the telecommunications equipment as defined by telephone number,
authorization code, or location in Illinois where bills are sent.
Â Â Â TAXPAYER: A person who, individually or through his or her agents,
employees, or permittees, engages in the act or privilege of originating or
receiving telecommunications in the city and who incurs a tax liability as
authorized by this section.
Â Â Â TELECOMMUNICATIONS: In addition to the meaning ordinarily and popularly
ascribed thereto, includes, without limitation, messages or information
transmitted through use of local, toll, and wide area telephone service,
private line service, channel service, telegraph service, teletypewriter,
computer exchange service, cellular mobile telecommunications service,
specialized mobile radio, stationary two-way radio, paging service, or any
other form of mobile and portable one-way or two-way communications, or any
other transmission of messages or information by electronic or similar means,
between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio,
satellite, or similar facilities. As used in this section, "private line" means
a dedicated nontraffic sensitive service for a single customer that entitles
the customer to exclusive or priority use of a communications channel or group
of channels from one or more specified locations to one or more other specified
locations. The definition of "telecommunications" shall not include value added
services in which computer processing applications are used to act on the form,
content, code, and protocol of the information for purposes other than
transmission. "Telecommunications" shall not include purchases of
telecommunications by a telecommunications service provider for use as a
component part of the service provided by such provider to the ultimate retail
consumer who originates or terminates the taxable end to end communications.
Carrier access charges, right of access charges, charges for use of
intercompany facilities, and all telecommunications resold in the subsequent
provision of, used as a component of, or integrated into end to end
telecommunications service shall be nontaxable as sales for resale. Prepaid
telephone calling arrangements shall not be considered "telecommunications"
subject to the tax imposed under this section. For purposes of this section,
"prepaid telephone calling arrangements" means that term as defined in section
2-27 of the retailers' occupations tax act 7 . (Ord. 2002-O-48, 8-6-2002, eff.
1-1-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Tax Imposed; Exemptions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Effective January 1, 2011, a tax is hereby imposed upon any and all
the following acts or privileges:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The act or privilege of originating in the city or receiving in

(6%) of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at retail from a
retailer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The act or privilege of originating in the city or receiving in
the city interstate telecommunications by a person at a rate of six percent
(6%) of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at retail from a
retailer. To prevent actual multistate taxation of the act or privilege that is
subject to taxation under this subsection D1b, any taxpayer, upon proof that
the taxpayer has paid a tax in another state on such event, shall be allowed a
credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this section to the
extent of the amount of such tax properly due and paid in such other state
which was not previously allowed as a credit against any other state or local
tax in this state. (Ord. 2002-O-48, 8-6-2002, eff. 1-1-2003; amd. Ord. 10-O-19,
6-1-2010)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The tax imposed by this section is not imposed on such act or
privilege to the extent such act or privilege may not, under the constitution

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Collection Of Tax By Retailers:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The tax authorized by this section shall be collected from the
taxpayer by a retailer maintaining a place of business in this state and shall
be remitted by such retailer to the department. Any tax required to be
collected pursuant to or as authorized by this section and any such tax
collected by such retailer and required to be remitted to the department shall
constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the state. Retailers shall collect
the tax from the taxpayer by adding the tax to the gross charge for the act or
privilege of originating or receiving telecommunications when sold for use, in
the manner prescribed by the department. The tax authorized by this section
shall constitute a debt of the taxpayer to the retailer until paid and, if
unpaid, is recoverable at law in the same manner as the original charge for
such sale at retail. If the retailer fails to collect the tax from the
taxpayer, then the taxpayer shall be required to pay the tax directly to the
department in the manner provided by the department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whenever possible, the tax authorized by this section shall, when
collected, be stated as a distinct item separate and apart from the gross
charge for telecommunications.
