4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any electronic or mechanical device which, upon the insertion
of a coin, token or slug, operates or may be operated as a game or contest of
skill or amusement of any kind or description, and shall include, but not be
limited to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any device which, in its operation, shoots or propels an electrical
light, ray or impulse from a device operated by the player to a target which
contains a receiving photoelectric cell.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any mechanical bowling or shuffleboard device which is designed to be
played for amusement and which, in operation, delivers to the player one or
more balls or other projectiles which must be rolled from or impelled by the
hand of the player or by a mechanical device into a cup or receptacle or over
scoring devices.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any video booth or video game, being a game using electronic or
computer technology and a type of video display.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Pinball machines or marble machines.
BOWLING ALLEY PREMISES: A premises at which bowling is made available to the
public, and contains no less than ten (10) bowling lanes with automatic pin
setting devices permitting the public to participate in the sport of bowling.
CITY: The city of Highwood.
COUNCIL, MAYOR AND CLERK: Shall mean, respectively, the city council, mayor and
city clerk of the city.
GAMBLING DEVICE: Any incidental mechanical grab devices and all other types of
games or devices which simulate games of chance and/or card games. "Gambling
devices" shall also include any mechanism that has been judicially determined
to be a "gambling device" in any way contrary to law, or that may be contrary
to any future laws of the state of Illinois.
MUSICAL DEVICE: Any machine vending to the public recorded music or a period of
radio or television entertainment upon the insertion of a coin, token or slug.
OPERATOR: Any person, partnership, firm, corporation, or association who owns
or who leases any device or public pool or billiard table or who places same
within the premises of another, or who is responsible for the maintenance or
repair of same.
PUBLIC POOL OR BILLIARD TABLE: Such a table of any conventional type, with or
without bumpers, located in any place of public entertainment or accommodation,
or any location licensed to serve or sell alcoholic beverages. This definition
shall include, but not be limited to, "bumper pool" tables.
VENDING DEVICE: Any machine vending cigarettes, cigars or other products
containing tobacco, or any beverage, candy, food product, or any items of
personal property, whatsoever, upon the insertion of a coin, token or slug.
(Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
4-3-2: OPERATOR LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Licenses Required; Fees; Exemptions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Vending Devices:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, corporation or
association to permit or cause to be displayed for use by the public four (4)
or more vending devices within the corporate limits of the city, unless such
person, partnership, firm, corporation or association shall first obtain from
the city an operator's license for such vending devices. Subject to the
provisions of subsection A5 of this section, each application for each
operator's license for vending devices under this subsection A1, or renewal
thereof hereunder, shall be accompanied by an annual license fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â No operator's license shall be required for any person,
partnership, corporation or association which permits, or causes to be
displayed for use by the public, less than four (4) vending devices within the
corporate limits of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â No operator's license shall be required for any person,
partnership, corporation or association which permits or causes to be displayed
for use by the public any number of vending devices within the corporate limits
of the city; provided, that said vending devices are not made available for use
of the general public and are located in an area of the premises not open to
the general public.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â No operator's license shall be required for any school or not for
profit organization which permits or causes to be displayed any number of
vending devices within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-
2000)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Amusement Devices: It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership,
corporation or association to permit, or cause to be displayed for use by the
public, any amusement device within the corporate limits of the city, unless
such person, partnership, firm, corporation or association shall first obtain
from the city an operator's license for amusement devices. Subject to the
provisions of subsection A5 of this section, each application for each
operator's license for amusement devices under this subsection A2, or renewal
thereof, shall be accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Musical Devices: It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership,
corporation or association to permit, or cause to be displayed for use by the
public, any musical device within the corporate limits of the city, unless such
person, partnership, firm, corporation or association shall first obtain from
the city an operator's license for musical devices. Subject to the provisions
of subsection A5 of this section, each application for each operator's license
for musical devices under this subsection A3, or renewal thereof, shall be
accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Pool And Billiard Tables: It shall be unlawful for any person,
partnership, corporation or association to permit, or cause to be displayed for
use by the public, any public pool or billiard table within the corporate
limits of the city, unless such person, partnership, firm, corporation or
association shall first obtain from the city an operator's license for public
pool or billiard tables. Subject to the provisions of subsection A5 of this
section, each application for each operator's license for public pool or
billiard tables under this subsection A4, or renewal thereof, shall be
accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â More Than One Category Of Devices: In the event any person,
partnership, corporation or association is desirous of obtaining an operator's
license for two (2) for more categories of devices licensed under this chapter,
and notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the operator shall be
required to pay only the fee for the most costly operator's license sought by
said operator.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Application For License; Ineligibility:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In order to obtain an operator's license, the applicant shall file
with the clerk a written statement setting forth the full name and address,
date and place of birth of the applicant; or the names and addresses, dates and
places of birth of the partners if the applicant is a partnership; or the name
and address of each of the directors, officers and shareholders of the
corporation, if the applicant is a corporation; and the present or last
occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the application. In
the case of a corporation, the application shall disclose the number and class
of shares owned by each shareholder. The application shall be in substantially
the same form as is attached to the ordinance codified herein as exhibit A. The
application shall be signed and notarized under oath by the applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The application shall be referred by the clerk to the license
committee of the council, who shall investigate the applicant and shall make
its report and recommendations on the application to the city council. Said
application shall be presented to the city council within a reasonable time for
approval by the council; provided, however, that no operator's license shall be
issued by the city to any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state or of the United States within the immediately preceding five (5) years
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted within the immediately preceding
five (5) years of being the keeper of or who is keeping a house of ill fame
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor or ordinance violation opposed to decency and morality within the
immediately preceding five (5) years (unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â A person who, at the time of application for renewal of an
operator's license hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a
first application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â A partnership, unless all of the partners of said partnership
shall be individually qualified to obtain a license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â A corporation, unless all officers, managers, and directors
thereof, or any shareholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the shares of the corporation, shall each be individually qualified to
obtain a license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â A person who is an officer of the city or a member of the city
council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The city reserves the right to reject any and all applications for
an operator's license hereunder or for the renewal of any operator's license
previously issued by the city, and upon such rejection, the annual license fee
tendered by the applicant shall be returned.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Types Of Devices Allowed: Each operator's license issued by the city
shall be valid for any and all types of devices covered under this chapter
except as provided in subsection B of this section. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-3: DEVICE LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Application For Licenses; Fees:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Within five (5) days after any duly licensed operator shall display
any amusement device or musical device or public pool or billiard table for use
by the public, such operator shall file with the clerk an application for a
license for each such device. The application for a device license shall be
properly sworn to under seal and oath, with a brief description of each such
device and the premises where such device is located, together with the such
other relevant data as the council may require. Each application for a device
license under this subsection A1 for any amusement device or musical device or
renewal thereof shall be accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this code. Each application for a device license hereunder for a
public pool or billiard table or renewal thereof shall be accompanied by an
annual license fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. The city shall issue for each such device on which an
application is approved a license stating the year for which it is issued. The
city reserves the right to deny or to revoke the license of any such device
which cheats its patrons of money or amounts to a gambling device.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Within five (5) days after any duly licensed operator or any person,
partnership, corporation or association shall display any vending device for
use by the public, such operator or any person, partnership, corporation or
association shall file with the clerk an application for a license for each
such device. The application for a device license shall be properly sworn to
under seal and oath, with a brief description of each such device and the
premises where such device is located, together with such other relevant data
as the council may require. Each application for a device license under this
subsection A2 or a renewal thereof shall be accompanied by an annual license
fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. The city shall issue for each such device on which an
application is approved a license stating the year for which it is issued. The
city reserves the right to deny or to revoke the license of any such device
which cheats its patrons of money or amounts to a gambling device. (Ord. 2000-
O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Transfer Of License: All device licenses herein provided for shall be
transferable from one device to another device, regardless of whether the
devices are of the same type. Any such transfer must be reported within two (2)
working days from the date of transfer, in writing, to the city. The
notification of transfer must include the name, serial number and location of
each device or table transferred. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-4: ARCADE LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required; Number Of Devices; Fee:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, corporation, firm
or association to operate, maintain or conduct an amusement arcade or shooting
gallery within the city without first obtaining an arcade license pursuant to
the terms of this section. An "amusement arcade" is hereby defined as a
premises (other than a bowling alley premises) which contains more than eight
(8) amusement devices or public pool or billiard tables, or any combination
thereof, exceeding eight (8) in number. Further provided, that as to any
bowling alley premises, same shall not be considered an amusement arcade unless
said bowling alley premises contains more than ten (10) amusement devices or
public pool or billiard tables, or any combination thereof, exceeding ten (10)
in number. However, the limitation on public pool or billiard tables set forth
in section
4-3-9 of this chapter shall still apply to the bowling alley premises. The
application for an arcade license shall be made by the person, partnership,
corporation or association which desires to operate such arcade.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No operator shall place or allow to be placed upon any premises more
than eight (8) amusement devices or public pool or billiard tables, or any
combination thereof, as herein defined, unless an arcade license has been
obtained for the premises where said devices are to be placed. (Ord. 16-O-50,
11-15-2016)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â License Fee: Subject to the provisions of subsection C of this section,
each application for each arcade license under this chapter, or renewal
thereof, shall be accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Application For License: In order to obtain an arcade license, the
applicant shall file with the clerk a written statement setting forth the full
name and address, date and place of birth of the applicant; or the names and
addresses, dates and places of birth of the partners, if the applicant is a
partnership; or the name and address of each of the directors, officers and
shareholders of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation; and the
present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the
application. In the case of a corporation, the application shall disclose the
number and class of shares owned by each shareholder. The application shall be
in substantially the same form as is attached to the ordinance codified herein
as exhibit A. The form application shall be supplemented with a brief
description of the types of amusement devices, general description of the
operation contemplated, and a diagram of the game area showing the layout of
the various amusement devices, dimension of the premises and location of games
to be located on the arcade premises, together with such other relevant data as
the city council may require. The application shall be signed and notarized
under oath by the applicant.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Security Plan:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The application shall contain a detailed security plan setting forth
a plan for the safety of the patrons of the arcade, both within the premises,
and in parking lots and adjacent premises, for all times during which the
arcade is in operation. The plan shall specifically detail all steps which the
applicant intends to implement to ensure the health and safety of minors within
the premises. The proposed security plan shall be forwarded to the chief of
police for his review and approval prior to the issuance of any arcade license.
If the chief of police does not approve of the security plan, the applicant
shall be so notified and shall submit an alternate or revised security plan
which is adequate in the opinion of the chief of police. In the event the
applicant feels aggrieved by any denial of the security plan by the chief of
police, the applicant may appeal the police chief's decision to the city
council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Further provided, that if, in the sole opinion of the city, upon
commencement and continued operation of the arcade premises, the security plan
is deemed to be insufficient, inadequate or in need of modification, the
applicant shall amend its security plan to provide such additional security as
is deemed adequate in the opinion of the chief of police as set forth herein.
In the event the applicant feels aggrieved by any denial of a security plan by
the chief of police, the applicant may appeal the police chief's decision to
the city council. Failure by the applicant to provide and fully implement the
security plan shall be grounds for revocation or denial of any arcade license
hereunder. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Conditions: Any applicant for an arcade license must meet the following
conditions prior to the issuance of an arcade license:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An application must be simultaneously submitted for a device license
for each amusement device.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No gambling devices, including video, electronic or other types of
games which simulate games of chance and/or card games, shall be permitted in
any arcade premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The applicant must have first obtained from the city a variance from
the application of the city zoning regulations for the operation of an arcade
or entertainment center. The applicant must fully comply with all applicable
provisions of all city ordinances including building codes, property
maintenance code and zoning regulations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â No arcade license shall be issued for any arcade premises which is
within a radius of three thousand seven hundred fifty feet (3,750') of any
preexisting school.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â No more than fifty (50) amusement devices shall be allowed within
any arcade premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â No arcade license shall be issued for any premises or business that
does not comply with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable
governmental regulations. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Investigation Of Applicant; Ineligibility: The application shall be
referred by the clerk to the license committee of the council who shall
investigate the applicant and shall make its report and recommendations on the
application to the city council. Said application shall be presented to the
city council within a reasonable time for approval by the council; provided,
however, that no arcade license shall be issued by the city to any of the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state or of the United States within the immediately preceding five (5) years
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted within the immediately preceding
five (5) years of being the keeper of or who is keeping a house of ill fame
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor or ordinance violation opposed to decency and morality within the
immediately preceding five (5) years (unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A person who, at the time of application for renewal of an
operator's license hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a
first application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A partnership, unless all of the partners of said partnership shall
be individually qualified to obtain a license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A corporation, unless all officers, managers, and directors thereof,
or any shareholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the
shares of the corporation, shall each be individually qualified to obtain a
license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A person who is an officer of the city or a member of the city
council.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Authority To Reject Licenses: The city reserves the right to reject any
and all applications for an arcade license hereunder or for the renewal of any
arcade license previously issued by the city, and upon such rejection, the
annual license fee tendered by the applicant shall be returned.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Issuance Or Denial Of License: With respect to such arcade licenses,
the city council shall review each application for said license and shall have
the authority to issue or not to issue any such license and to impose such
specific rules and conditions on the licensee based on the unique nature of his
establishment. This subsection shall apply upon any renewal or extension of any
said license. The city reserves the right to deny or to revoke the license of
any arcade which contains any amusement devices which cheat its patrons of
money or amount to a gambling device.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Number Of Licenses: The maximum number of arcade licenses which may be
issued shall not exceed none.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Annual Review Of Arcade Licenses: Arcade licenses shall expire and be
renewable as set forth in section
4-3-7 of this chapter. Upon application for renewal of same, current
information of the same type required by this chapter for the issuance of the
initial license shall be provided by the applicant at the time of renewal.
Further, the chief of police shall provide a report on the prior year's
operation of the applicant's establishment. The city council shall have the
authority to issue the arcade license, terminate the license or continue the
license subject to specified rules and conditions. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-5: ADDITIONAL FEES FOR FAILURE TO OBTAIN LICENSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Device License: Any person, partnership, corporation or association
failing to obtain or display a device license within the required time period
(5 days) set forth in this chapter shall pay, in addition to the device license
fee, the sum as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Operator's License: Any person, partnership, corporation or association
failing to obtain an operator's license as required pursuant to this chapter
shall pay, in addition to the operator's license fee, the sum as provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Arcade License: Any person, partnership, corporation or association
failing to obtain an arcade license as required pursuant to this chapter shall
pay, in addition to the arcade license fee, the sum as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
4-3-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF OPERATOR AND ARCADE LICENSES:
An operator's license or arcade license issued under this chapter shall be
nonassignable and nontransferable. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-7: LICENSE FEE PAYMENTS; RENEWAL OF LICENSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The operator's license fee and arcade license fee and renewal fees for
said licenses shall be due and payable on or before July 1 of each year, and
the device fee herein provided for shall be due and payable on or before July 1
of each year. Any licenses in force within thirty (30) days prior to the
effective date hereof shall remain in force until June 30 next.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The issuance of any license hereunder shall not be construed as
creating any future right in the applicant to receive a renewal therefor. The
licenses issued hereunder expire on an annual basis, and the person making
application for a license under this chapter acknowledges that, upon expiration
of the annual license, the city shall not be obliged to renew or extend said
license, and the granting of the license hereunder is a privilege granted to
the applicant and creates no property right in the applicant and no expectation
of continued renewal thereof. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-8: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
All such licenses described herein shall be at all times kept and placed in
plain view of all persons who may frequent or be in any place of business or
other place where such devices are kept or used. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-9: NUMBER OF POOL AND BILLIARD TABLES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, no person, partnership,
corporation, firm or association shall operate, maintain or allow within or
upon any premises within the city more than two (2) public pool or billiard
tables. This limitation shall apply to all premises within the city including
amusement arcades as provided in subsection 4-3-4A of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No operator shall place or allow to be placed upon any premises more
than two (2) "public pool or billiard tables", as defined in section
4-3-1 of this chapter. This limitation shall apply to all premises within the
city, including amusement arcades as provided in subsection 4-3-4A of this
chapter. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-10: MISREPRESENTATION BY APPLICANT:
No person, or agent of any partnership, firm or corporation, shall state or
imply to any other person, including, but not limited to, any employee,
proprietor, manager, or owner of a restaurant, bar, tavern or other place open
to the public where devices licensed pursuant to this chapter are placed, that
said person must use the devices controlled by the applicant or holder of any
license hereunder. Further, no person shall assert that any applicant or holder
of a license hereunder has a monopoly or exclusive franchise or exclusive
license for any device permitted under this chapter. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-
2000)
4-3-11: MINORS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Minors On Premises; Days And Hours Prohibited:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No person, partnership, firm or corporation, or employee of same,
controlling an establishment containing any amusement device or public pool or
billiard table, including premises for which an arcade license has been
granted, shall permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, unless
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, to remain in the arcade or area
where the games are available before three o'clock (3:00) P.M. on any day
during which public school in the school district in which the city is located
is in regular session nor after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any day of the
week. No physical force shall be used to enforce this requirement, but the
establishment shall immediately notify the city police department and the
school district truant enforcement officers, if applicable.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Each licensee under this chapter shall display a sign with
substantially the following wording, or with other wording giving substantially
the same meaning:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â NOTICE
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â IF YOU ARE UNDER EIGHTEEN (18) YEARS OF AGE, YOU WILL NOT BE ALLOWED
TO REMAIN IN THIS ARCADE ON SCHOOL DAYS DURING THE HOURS WHEN SCHOOL IS IN
SESSION. FURTHER, YOU WILL NOT BE ALLOWED IN THIS ARCADE AFTER THE HOUR OF 9:00
P.M.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall enter or remain
within any bowling alley premises or premises for which an arcade license is
issued, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, on any day during
which public schools in the school district in which the city is located are in
regular session, nor after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on any day of the week.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Days And Hours Of Operation Generally:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary,
no premises for which an arcade license is issued shall be open to the public
other than the following days and hours:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Monday through Thursday, ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:
00) P.M.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Friday, ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Saturday, nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Sunday, nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any applicant to which an arcade license is issued acknowledges that
the hours of operation may be further limited or restricted in the future by
the city. The issuance of an arcade license does not in any way restrict the
city's privilege to modify this chapter to curtail or extend hours of operation
during the term of the license. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-12: GAMBLING DEVICES PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nothing in this chapter shall be in any way construed to authorize,
license, or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has
been judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to
law, or that may be contrary to any future laws of the state of Illinois. No
such gambling devices or other such devices shall be permitted or displayed
within the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the chief of police shall have reason to believe any amusement
device is a gambling device or is used as a gambling device, such device may be
seized by the police and impounded, and if, upon trial of the cause for
allowing said device to be used as a gambling device, the device is determined
to be a gambling device, such device shall be destroyed by the police
department.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If the mayor or chief of police, or any of their duly authorized
enforcement officers, shall have reasonable basis for believing any amusement
device is operated unlicensed, or is being used as a gambling device or for
gambling purposes, said device may be seized by any duly authorized law
enforcement official, followed by an administrative hearing to determine the
appropriateness of the seizure, and held until such time as the owner of such
device pays the delinquent fee, and reimburses the department of police for
actual cartage costs incurred in the seizure and pays the city the sum of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per day for each day or part of day said device has
been in storage.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â It shall be the responsibility of the owner to pay for any cartage for
the return of any device to its original location. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-13: GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Any person, partnership, firm, or corporation, or employee of same, shall be
subject to the following rules and regulations:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No amusement device, vending device, or musical device shall be placed
in any required exit path of travel.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An adult manager shall be required to be present on the premises of
each premises possessing an arcade license.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any licensee or its employee to permit
gambling on any premises.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any licensee or employee who observes any gambling on the premises, or
who has any reasonable grounds to suspect that gambling is taking place, shall
immediately cause the removal from the premises of such persons as are involved
in the gambling activity.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any licensee or employee to allow a degree of
noise to develop which would cause a disturbance to the adjacent or surrounding
uses such that normal use of said adjacent or surrounding uses would be damaged
or unreasonably disturbed.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any licensee or employee to permit any
individual under the influence of alcohol or drugs to remain on the premises.
Any licensee or attendant who observes any individual on the premises to be
under the influence of alcohol or drugs or who reasonably suspects such
individual to be under the influence shall immediately cause removal of said
individual from the premises.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Any licensee or employee thereof shall have the affirmative duty to
report to the police department any or all incidents or reports of any
disorderly conduct or disturbance of the peace as defined and regulated by the
laws of the state of Illinois or the ordinances of the city, and which takes
place within the licensed premises or within two hundred feet (200') from the
entrance. This includes incidents either observed by or reported to the
licensee or any employee thereof. Failure to report any incident shall be
deemed sufficient cause to revoke all licenses issued hereunder.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â All licensees shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Keep their premises in a clean and sanitary condition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Provide adequate waste receptacles.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Provide adequate and orderly parking for bicycles and motor
vehicles.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Ensure that all sidewalks and/or walkways outside the premises are
clear, unobstructed and open to pedestrian traffic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Open and operate the premises only during hours which are permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Maintain and keep all machines in good repair and operating
condition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â In the event of a malfunction of a device, furnish a refund to the
device user.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â As to any premises for which an arcade license has been issued, there
shall be no sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor allowed by the licensee, or
any employee thereof, within the premises.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â As to any premises for which an arcade license has been granted, no
ingress or egress to the premises shall be allowed directly from any
establishment which holds any type of liquor license issued by the city. (Ord.
2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-14: INSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Right Of Entry: The city, through its officers, agents and employees,
shall have the right to enter at all times any establishment, place or building
in which any of such devices as described herein are operated or set up for
operation for the purposes of inspecting, testing and investigating such
devices.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Annual And Regular Inspections:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be the duty of the chief of police or such person as is
designated by the chief of police to inspect any vending device, amusement
device, musical device or public pool or billiard table no less than once each
year. The chief shall specifically inspect for any violations of this chapter
and further to confirm that each device conforms with all applicable
requirements of the state of Illinois.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Further, the chief of police or any person designated by the chief
of police shall conduct regular inspections to ensure compliance with all
requirements of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Nonliability Of City For And Effect Of Failure To Inspect: Neither the
chief of police nor the city, nor their agents or assigns, shall be liable to
any person, partnership, corporation, firm or association for failure to
conduct the inspections required under this chapter. Further, the failure of
the chief of police, the city, or its agents or assigns to comply with the
inspection requirements of this chapter shall not affect the required license
fee nor the validity of the license issued hereunder. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-
2000)
4-3-15: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued hereunder shall be subject to revocation or suspension for
just cause by the city council. Any person making application under this
chapter shall be deemed to recognize and acknowledge that said license may be
revoked pursuant to the terms of this chapter, including the violation of any
of the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-16: DISPOSITION OF FUNDS; RECORDS KEPT:
The clerk shall deposit all funds received under this chapter in the general
fund of the city. In addition, the clerk shall cause to be kept a record of all
operator's licenses, arcade licenses and device licenses issued pursuant to the
terms of this chapter, showing the names and addresses of all persons to whom
operator's licenses and arcade licenses are issued and the description of the
device and location for each device issued hereunder, as well as any other
information deemed essential. (Ord. 2000-O-49, 8-15-2000)
4-3-17: PENALTY:
Any person, partnership, firm or corporation, or employee of same, violating
any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)

4-4-1: TITLE:
This chapter may be called or referred to as the HIGHWOOD RAFFLES ORDINANCE OF
2002. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
4-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct any raffle or sell or distribute
any raffle chance within the city, except as provided by the Illinois raffles
act 1  and this chapter, and pursuant to a license issued hereunder. (Ord.
2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)

Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq.
4-4-3: ELIGIBLE ORGANIZATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Licenses shall only be issued pursuant to this chapter to bona fide
religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal, educational, or veterans'
organizations that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Operate without profit to their members; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5)
years immediately before making application for a license hereunder; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Which have had, during such entire five (5) year period, a bona fide
membership engaged in carrying out their objects.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In addition, licenses hereunder may be issued to a nonprofit
fundraising organization that the mayor determines is organized for the sole
purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual or group
of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an
illness, disability, accident or disaster. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
4-4-4: INELIGIBLE PERSONS:
The following are ineligible for any license pursuant to this chapter:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person who has been convicted of a felony; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter; and
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person who is not of good moral character; and
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection A, B,
or C of this section has a proprietary, equitable, or credit interest, or in
which such a person is active or employed; and
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any organization in which a person defined in subsection A, B, or C of
this section is an officer, director, or the like, or an employee, whether
compensated or not; and
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Any organization in which a person defined in subsection A, B, or C of
this section is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle.
(Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
4-4-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Forms for requesting a raffle license hereunder shall be made available
at city hall and shall be filed by any organization seeking a license
hereunder.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The application shall contain a sworn statement attesting to the not
for profit character of the applicant organization, which shall be signed by
the presiding officer and secretary of that organization.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The application shall specify, among other things:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All persons who are in any position of authority within the
applicant organization, such as, but not limited to, director, officer,
employee, or agent;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All persons who shall participate in the management of the raffle in

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The single raffles manager required by subsection 4-4-9G of this

Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The person who shall account for gross receipts, expenses and net

Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise to be
awarded by the licensee in a single raffle;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The maximum retail value of each prize to be awarded by the licensee
in a single raffle;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance to be
issued or sold;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or
sold;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The area or areas within the city in which raffle chances will be
sold or issued;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â The time of determination of winning chances and the location or
locations at which winning chances will be determined; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â The method of determining winning chance(s). (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-
2002)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The fee for the initial filing of an application shall be as provided
in section
3-2A-1 of this code, which may, however, upon good cause shown, be waived by
the mayor. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
4-4-6: GRANT OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
The applications shall be acted upon by the mayor within thirty (30) days of
being filed. However, such action may include returning the application to the
applicant for correction, modification, addition, or the like. The mayor, at
his sole discretion, shall decide whether or not to grant any license pursuant
to this chapter and need not specify any reason whatsoever for denying any
application hereunder. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
4-4-7: CONTENTS AND EFFECT OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nothing in this chapter shall require that any license be issued
hereunder, but the same shall be issued at the sole discretion of the mayor.
The mayor may, but need not, establish special categories of licenses and
promulgate rules relating to the various categories, which shall be published
and made available to the public during normal business hours at city hall. Any
license issued hereunder shall specify, among other information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise to be
awarded by the licensee in a single raffle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The maximum retail value of each prize to be awarded by the licensee
in a single raffle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance to be
issued or sold; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or
sold; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The area or areas within the city in which raffle chances will be
sold or issued; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued;
and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The time of determination of winning chances and the location or
locations at which winning chances will be determined; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The method of determining winning chance(s).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â This information shall be a condition of the license, and any violation
of any of these conditions shall be a violation of this chapter. Licenses
issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for one raffle or a specified
number of raffles to be conducted during a specified period, not to exceed one
year. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
4-4-8: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Licenses issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the mayor for any
violation of the Illinois raffles act or this chapter. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-
2002)
4-4-9: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
All raffles conducted pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to the
following restrictions:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Net Proceeds: The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively
devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization licensed hereunder to
conduct that game; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Members Only: No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring
licensed organization may participate in the management or operation of the
raffle; and
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Nonprofit Nature: No person may receive any remuneration or profit for
participating in the management or operation of any raffle; and
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Rented Premises: A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine
the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is
also licensed pursuant to this chapter; and
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Location Restrictions: Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within
the area specified on the license, and winning chances may be determined only
at those locations specified on the license; and
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Persons Under Eighteen: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances only with the
permission of a parent or guardian. A person under the age of eighteen (18)
years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only
when accompanied by his parent or guardian; and
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Manager:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All operation of and conduct of raffles shall be under the
supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the licensed
organization. The manager shall give a fidelity bond:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â In an amount to be specified by the mayor in the license;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â In favor of the licensed organization;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â With terms providing that notice shall be given in writing to the
mayor not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation; (Ord. 2002-O-
36, 5-21-2002)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the members of the licensed organization have voted unanimously
to request waiver of the bonding requirement in this subsection, and the mayor
and city council decide to waive such requirement in the license, this
subsection shall not apply to that license; and (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002;
amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Records:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Each licensee hereunder shall keep complete records of its gross
receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at
which winning chances are determined;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or
occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the net
amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the
deduction, and the recipient;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee,
purpose, amount and date of payment;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of each licensed organization, including bingo
gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit
organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the state department of
revenue, and placed in a separate account;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The
person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the
operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other
revenues of the licensed organization; (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Promptly, after the conclusion of each raffle, each organization
licensed hereunder shall report its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds
from raffles and the distribution of net proceeds to its membership and the
mayor, itemized as required by this subsection; (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002;
amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Records required by this subsection shall be preserved for five (5)
years, and licensed organizations shall make their records relating to
operation of raffles available for public inspection at reasonable times and
places, and shall immediately forward accurate written copies of the same to
the mayor upon request; and
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Drawings: Any determination of winning chances may only be conducted as
specified in the license for the raffle, at the time and place specified, and
shall be made publicly known throughout the entire time any chances are sold or
distributed, and until all determinations are completed. All such
determinations of winning chances shall be open to the public where all persons
present may observe the complete procedure utilized to select the winning
chances. The mayor shall be permitted to inspect and examine all raffle
materials at any time that any winning chance is being determined, even if to
do so would delay such determination. (Ord. 2002-O-36, 5-21-2002)

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity

CHAPTER 7
USED CAR LOTS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: Scope; Records Kept
4-7-3: Application For License
4-7-4: Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance, Denial, Revocation Of License
4-7-5: License Fees
4-7-6: Number Of Licenses
4-7-7: Restrictions And Regulations
4-7-8: Inspections
4-7-9: Penalties
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
CONSIGNMENT: Accepting possession without purchasing, with the objective of
selling and receiving a sum of money, commission or percentage when the sale is
made.
USED CAR LOT: Any lot, plot or parcel of land, vacant or improved, where used
or secondhand motor vehicles of whatever description are stored, kept or
offered for sale, trade, disposal, exchange or otherwise, by any person, firm,
corporation or entity. The presence of a vehicle without current state license
plates or any current city of Highwood vehicle license or sticker shall be
prima facie evidence that the vehicle is offered for sale if said vehicle is in
the possession of or held or controlled by a merchant, auto mechanic, bank, or
garage.
USED CAR SALES OPERATION: Any business where used or secondhand motor vehicles
are held for sale, trade, exchange, disposal or otherwise to the public, from
time to time, or which has sold at least three (3) such vehicles during the
twelve (12) months immediately preceding. Any person, firm, corporation or
entity selling, trading, exchanging, disposing or otherwise disposing of used
or secondhand motor vehicles in the city shall be deemed to be engaged in the
business of a "used car sales operation", regardless of whether vehicles are
displayed at the premises. Further provided, that any individual making an
isolated sale of his own motor vehicle shall not be deemed to be engaged in a
"used car sales operation" or a used car sales lot. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
4-7-2: SCOPE; RECORDS KEPT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The provisions of this chapter shall apply to any person, firm or
corporation accepting used motor vehicles for sale on consignment. Each person,
firm or corporation accepting motor vehicles for sale on consignment shall keep
accurate records of the names, addresses and descriptions of persons placing
motor vehicles for sale on consignment. Such records for each motor vehicle
shall be kept for at least one year after the motor vehicle is sold or
withdrawn from sale.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The provisions of this chapter shall apply to lots displaying motor
vehicles for sale under other arrangements, such as rental of spaces in a lot
to display motor vehicles for sale. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
4-7-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
No person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation shall operate or maintain a
used car lot or conduct a used car sales operation in the city until and except
upon proper application being made to the city clerk in substantially the same
form as attached to the ordinance codified herein as exhibit A and approved by
the mayor. Such applications shall be kept for a period of five (5) years by
the collector as public documents. The application shall be signed and
notarized under oath by the applicant. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
4-7-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; ISSUANCE, DENIAL, REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The application shall be referred by the clerk to the mayor, who may cause the
applicant to be investigated and may thereafter issue the license; provided,
that the license shall not issue unless the applicant has complied with the
provisions hereof and is found to be a person of good character and reputation
in the city. The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm,
entity or corporation for violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be
grounds for the revocation of any license issued hereunder and shall be grounds
for the denial of any other license. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
4-7-5: LICENSE FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Fees Established: The annual license fees for the operation of a used
car lot shall be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. Said license fees are payable on or before April 1 of each
calendar year. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No Proration: There shall be no proration for periods of less than
twelve (12) months. The full amount of the annual license fee shall be tendered
with the application therefor. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Late Filing Fee: Any renewal application or fee received after April 1
shall be accompanied by a late filing fee as provided in section
3-2A-2 of this code. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
4-7-6: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
As the operation of a used car facility is not a permitted use within the city
(other than in conjunction with new car sales), the number of licenses issued
hereunder shall not exceed two (2). Further, upon the failure of any existing
license holder to timely renew any existing license (as evidenced by the filing
of an application, and payment of the license fee no later than April 1 of each
year), said license shall be, and the number of licenses permitted pursuant to
the terms of this chapter shall be, automatically reduced to preclude the
issuance of said license. Any application for a license in excess of the number
of licenses permitted hereunder shall be referred to the city council for
consideration and determination of such application and the creation of a new
license, if found to be in the best interest of the city. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-
2003)
4-7-7: RESTRICTIONS AND REGULATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to store, park, or keep or display for sale or
otherwise any used motor vehicle which is not in good running and safe
operating condition, as required by the ordinances of the city and the laws,
rules, regulations, and administrative provisions of the state of Illinois and
the United States of America relating to motor vehicles, or whose odometer
reflects mileage less than the actual mileage of the vehicle unless the
accuracy of the odometer is disclaimed as provided for by state or federal law.
(Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All motor vehicles offered for sale shall be parked in an orderly
fashion, in stalls which are delineated clearly by pavement striping, and
having a stall size of not less than nine feet by eighteen feet (9' x 18') and
at least two feet (2') between each vehicle and any other vehicle, wall, fence,
structure, obstruction or dumpster. Further provided, that any person, firm,
corporation or entity to which a license has been previously issued shall be
granted thirty (30) days from the effective date hereof to comply with the
provisions of this subsection. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any used car lot shall be well lighted at night. Said licensee shall
further comply with all ordinances of the city, the laws, rules, regulations,
and administrative provisions of the state of Illinois, and any other
applicable laws, rules or regulations of any applicable jurisdiction,
including, but not limited to, those relating to fire regulations, safety and
sanitation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No motor vehicle shall be repaired or dismantled, or left in a
dismantled state, upon the used car lot. Provided, that this subsection shall
not prohibit the repair or servicing of any motor vehicle within the confines
of a garage or indoor service bay of a filling station or such of the indoor
servicing units being operated in connection with used car lots.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any person, firm, corporation or entity engaged in a used car lot or
used car sales operation shall cause to be kept a record of all motor vehicles
offered for sale, trade, disposal, exchange or otherwise, which record shall
show the make of said motor vehicle, the year of its manufacture, its serial
number and the engine number, which record shall always be kept available for
the chief of police, his designee, or any patrol officer within the city and
open to inspection at any time. It shall be the further duty of every such
person, firm, corporation or entity operating a used car lot or used car sales
operation to immediately report to the chief of police the presence in his
place of business of any motor vehicle on which the serial or engine number has
been defaced or altered.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In addition to any other requirements of this chapter, or of law,
statute, regulation or other applicable governmental regulation, including, but
not limited to, those of the United States federal government and its agencies,
every used car lot and every used car sales operation within the city, or
subject to this chapter, shall, at all times, fully and completely comply with
all federal trade commission rules and regulations applicable thereto,
including, but not limited to, the consumer sales window form mandated by
section 455.2 of title 16 of the United States code of federal regulations, or
any successor regulations thereto, which form shall be prominently displayed at
all times.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to store, park, or keep, or display for sale or
otherwise, any used motor vehicle otherwise than in the delineated stalls set
forth above, and no such vehicles shall be stored, parked, or kept for display,
for sale or otherwise upon any street, parkway or public parking area. (Ord.
2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
4-7-8: INSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any used car lot or used car sales operation shall be subject to
inspection by the police, building and health officials at such times as are
deemed necessary by the municipal authorities, and by submitting an application
pursuant to the terms of this chapter, the applicant consents to all
inspections required or permitted by the terms of this chapter or to otherwise
ensure that the premises and records are in full compliance with all laws,
regulations and ordinances.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Further, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or such person as
is designated by the chief of police to inspect any licensed used car lot no
less frequently than six (6) times per year. The chief shall specifically
inspect for all violations of this chapter and further to confirm that each
vehicle offered for sale is equipped with serviceable mirrors, lights and horn
and otherwise conforms with all applicable requirements for motor vehicles used
on public roadways or offered for sale within the state. Further, the chief
shall confirm by inspection that the person, firm or corporation which operates
the used car lot complies with all state and federally mandated title and
odometer disclosures.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Neither the chief of police nor the city, nor their agents or assigns,
shall be liable to any person, firm, corporation or entity for failure to
conduct the inspections required under this section. Further, the failure of
the chief of police or the city, or their agents or assigns, to comply with the
requirements of this section shall not affect the required license fee nor the
validity of the license issued hereunder. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-2003)
4-7-9: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation violating any
provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In the case of any violations of this chapter, any enforcement officer
may institute an appropriate action or proceeding to exact the penalty provided
above. Also, such enforcement officer shall refer such matter to the mayor or
the city council. The mayor or city council may direct the city attorney to
proceed at law or in equity against any person, partnership, firm, entity or
corporation determined to be in violation of this chapter for the purpose of
ordering said person, firm, entity or corporation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To restrain, correct or remove the violation or refrain from any
further violation of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â To cease the continued operation of such facility permitted
hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â To require the removal of any vehicle or items found to be in
violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â For such other actions as may be necessary and proper for full
enforcement of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity
or corporation for violation of the provisions of this chapter shall not
release such person from paying any fee due and unpaid at the time of such
conviction, nor shall payment of any fee prevent prosecution for violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The amount of any fee due hereunder shall be deemed a debt to the city.
An action may be commenced in the name of the city in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent fee and/or tax. All unpaid fees
shall be deemed delinquent after they are due and payable.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 2003-O-19, 4-2-
2003)
CHAPTER 8
VALET PARKING SERVICES
SECTION:
4-8-1: Purpose
4-8-2: Definitions
4-8-3: Permit Required
4-8-4: Application For Permit
4-8-5: Issuance Of Permit; Conditions Imposed
4-8-6: Transfer Zone
4-8-7: General Regulations
4-8-8: Specified Storage Areas
4-8-9: Nonliability Of City
4-8-10: Violations; Penalty Options
4-8-1: PURPOSE:
The general purposes of this chapter are:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To provide for the safe operation of valet parking services where the
transfer and temporary parking of motor vehicles between customers and valet
parking services takes place on public streets or public property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To prohibit the obstruction of the ordinary flow of traffic and
designated "no parking" zones in the course of operating a valet parking
service.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â To designate those places where valet parking services may be legally
provided by a business or its duly authorized parking contractor. (Ord. 2006-O-
11, 3-21-2006)
4-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall be applicable as to this chapter:
BUSINESS: Any commercial establishment which makes valet parking services
available to its customers and which receives or stores motor vehicles within
the city of Highwood.
CUSTOMER: Any person granting temporary custody of a motor vehicle to a valet
operator for the purpose of valet parking.
DESIGNATED PARKING AREA: Those areas of the city as specified in this chapter
where a valet operator may store customer motor vehicles.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, company, corporation, association,
joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal
entity, or its legal representative, agents or assigns.
PROHIBITED PARKING AREA: Those areas of the city as specified in this chapter
where a valet operator is prohibited from storing customer motor vehicles.
TRANSFER ZONE: Any area used as the pick up, loading, unloading or discharge
points for valet parking services.
VALET OPERATOR: Any person who employs one or more attendants for the purpose
of providing a valet parking service or who contracts his own services, but not
in the capacity of employee, to any business establishment for the purpose of
providing a valet parking service to such establishment.
VALET PARKING OPERATION: The performance of valet parking services by any
business or valet operator.
VALET PARKING PERMIT: A permit issued pursuant to this chapter to an operator
for the conduct of valet parking services.
VALET PARKING PLAN: A plan approved for operation of valet parking services as
provided in this chapter.
VALET PARKING SERVICES: A parking service provided to accommodate customers of
any business establishment, which service is incidental to the business of the
establishment and by which a person on behalf of the establishment takes
temporary custody of the customer's motor vehicle and moves, parks, stores or
retrieves the vehicle for the customer's convenience. Provided, "valet parking
service" does not include such parking service where all activities, including
loading, unloading, transfer, transport and storage, are conducted entirely
upon private, nonresidentially zoned property.
VALET TAG: An identification ticket to be displayed on all motor vehicles while
under the control of the valet operator stating the name of the business being
served, the name of the valet company and its phone number. At a minimum, the
valet tag shall measure at least four inches by six inches (4" x 6").
VIOLATION ESCROW: An escrow as provided in this chapter to pay any violations
incurred by a valet operator. (Ord. 2006-O-11, 3-21-2006)
4-8-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to offer or provide valet parking services
in the city without a valid valet parking permit issued in accordance with this
chapter. A separate permit shall be required for each business served. (Ord.
2006-O-11, 3-21-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
4-8-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An application for a valet parking permit shall be filed with the city

Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Copies of any leases or other written agreements pursuant to which a

Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â If a valet parking operation will be performed for the business by a

business and the valet operator. (Ord. 2006-O-11, 3-21-2006)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Every valet operator shall procure and maintain insurance coverage

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The valet operator shall name the city as an additional named

4-8-5: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; CONDITIONS IMPOSED:
Upon receipt of a completed application form, payment of all required fees or
fines that may be due pursuant to this chapter and compliance with all other
applicable requirements of this chapter, upon approval by the city, the city
shall issue a valet parking permit. Such valet parking permit may contain such
conditions and limitations as are necessary to promote safe and sound passenger
loading and unloading, vehicle transfer and traffic movement as may be
determined by the city. (Ord. 2006-O-11, 3-21-2006)
4-8-6: TRANSFER ZONE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No valet parking permit, or renewal thereof, shall be issued unless the
applicant provides proof to the city that the business for which the valet
parking service is to be provided has made available a transfer zone of at
least one parking space and a maximum of two (2) parking spaces unless a
request has been made and approval given for additional parking spaces
immediately adjacent to its premises for the pick up and delivery of the
customers' vehicles.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No on street transfer zone shall be approved or utilized unless and
until all required signage has been established.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All vehicles accepted for valet parking service shall be immediately
removed from the transfer zone and moved to the storage area specified in the
valet parking permit. (Ord. 2006-O-11, 3-21-2006)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The chief of police may authorize the extension of valet parking
loading zones if deemed in the best interest of public safety under special
circumstances, such as special events. Request must be made in writing no less
than seventy two (72) hours in advance. (Ord. 14-O-10, 6-3-2014)
4-8-7: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance Required: The holder of a valet parking permit shall at all
times conduct valet parking operations in accordance with this chapter and in
accordance with an approved valet parking plan.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Nontransferability Of Permit: Each valet parking permit issued shall be
nontransferable and shall be valid for one year, commencing on July 1, and
shall have designated thereon the name and address of the valet operator and
the business to be served by the valet operator.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Responsibility Of Operator For Employees: Operators shall be
responsible for the acts of their employees and agents in the conduct of the
valet parking service.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Violation Escrow: A separate violation escrow in the amount of two
hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be established and maintained by each valet
operator for each business served. To that end, any valet operator shall be
notified of a deduction from the violation escrow as provided in this chapter
and shall, within ten (10) days, replenish the violation escrow back to the
required two hundred dollar ($200.00) level.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Signs: Every business establishment for which a valet parking permit is
issued shall, during the hours of service, display a valet parking sign
approved by the city. Every valet operator must post its name and the rates, if
any, onto the valet parking sign in four inch (4") lettering. All valet parking
signs shall comply with the following specifications and requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The entire sign assembly must be no larger than twenty four inches
by thirty six inches (24" x 36"), and the actual surface of the sign shall not
exceed six (6) square feet in size;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The sign must be constructed of durable, weatherproof materials;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The sign cannot have sharp edges or any protrusions or features that
could be a hazard to pedestrians;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The sign must be properly designed and heavy enough to withstand
typical winds without tipping over, rocking or sliding;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The sign cannot have moving parts or electrical devices, including
lights;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The sign cannot use any images resembling official signs or anything
else that can cause it to be confused with an official traffic control device;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Only one sign is allowed per place of business;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The sign shall only be displayed during hours when the valet parking
service is offered;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The sign must be placed within the designated transfer zone but in
no case shall it be more than eight feet (8') from the curb; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â No signs may be placed in the street (including on street parking
spaces) or right up against the curbs after a two inch (2") snowfall.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Valet Tag: Every valet operator shall place or cause the valet tag to
be placed so as to be conspicuously visible through the windshield of the
patron's vehicle.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Attendant Insignia: Each attendant of a valet parking operation shall,
while on duty, wear, conspicuously placed on the attendant's clothing, an
insignia which identifies the valet parking operator or business for whom the
attendant is working.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Receipt Issued: All valet parking attendants must, upon taking custody
of a patron's vehicle, issue a numbered receipt to each customer containing the
name, address, and telephone number of the company providing the valet service,
a statement that the company has liability insurance as required by this
chapter and the charge for the valet service.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Transfer Zone Revoked Or Moved: The city council may, in its sole
discretion, revoke or move a transfer zone at any time, if it determines that
the transfer zone or its location has increased traffic congestion or traffic
hazards in the public streets, or otherwise has impaired the public health,
safety or welfare.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Traffic Regulations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The licensee and its agents, at all times, shall comply with all
traffic rules and regulations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No person may park any vehicle in any manner which violates the
provisions of this chapter or any other duly adopted city parking regulation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â In conducting a valet parking operation, no person may obstruct the
normal flow of traffic or block or occupy a "no parking zone". (Ord. 2006-O-11,
3-21-2006)

used as a designated parking area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Designated parking areas on private property shall be limited to

Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Downtown Highwood Commuter Metra Parking Lot.

Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â East side of Green Bay Road (north of Burchell Avenue).

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Motor vehicles accepted for valet parking service shall not be parked

4-8-10: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY OPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as specified herein, any person violating any provision of this
chapter shall, upon a finding of guilty, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2006-O-11, 3-21-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The valet operator shall be responsible for any parking fines and

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the event the police chief determines that an operator has violated
any provision of this chapter, the chief may, in lieu of seeking sanctions as
provided in subsection A of this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Impose a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Recommend the suspension or revocation of the valet parking permit
to the city council, who may, by majority vote, revoke or suspend a valet
parking lot permit.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any operator notified of any deduction from the operator's violation
escrow may appeal such action to the mayor within ten (10) days of receipt of

CHAPTER 9
POLICE TOWING OPERATIONS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: License And Agreement Required
4-9-3: Ineligibility For License
