4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings:
CALL ROTATION OR CALL ROTATION LIST: A list of licensees maintained by the
Highwood police department and utilized for the consensual and nonconsensual
towing of vehicles within the city limits of Highwood.
POLICE TOW: A tow requested by the Highwood police department for:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Vehicles that are disabled where the person in charge of the vehicle
has no preference for any particular tow service or is unable to make such
decision.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â City owned vehicles.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Vehicles impounded by the Highwood police department for evidentiary,
investigative or seizure purposes, or arrests.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Abandoned vehicles that are towed pursuant to Highwood police
department procedures.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Illegally parked vehicles that pose a traffic hazard.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â At the request of the vehicle owner.
POLICE TOWING LICENSE OR LICENSE: A license issued by the city of Highwood
authorizing a person or firm to engage in the business of vehicle towing at the
request of the Highwood police department.
POLICE TOWING LICENSEE OR LICENSEE: A person or firm engaged in the business
of, or offering the services of, vehicle towing, whereby motor vehicles are or
may be towed or otherwise relocated from one place to another, or serviced on
scene, by use of a tow truck and by request of the Highwood police department,
and approved by the Highwood police department.
TOW DRIVER: An agent that works for a licensee, driving or operating a tow
truck, or working at the scene of a license call.
TOW TRUCK: As defined in the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-205.1, as amended. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-2: LICENSE AND AGREEMENT REQUIRED:
Any person/business desiring to perform police towing work at the request of
the police department shall submit and obtain a police towing license and
police towing license agreement. Application forms may be obtained from the
police department. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-3: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No person shall be approved as a licensee or a tow driver, nor shall any
licensee knowingly permit such a person to be a tow driver pursuant to a
license call, who:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Has any felony conviction within the last five (5) years in any state;
or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Is a "sex offender", as defined in Illinois law, 730 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 150/2, as amended; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Has been convicted under the laws of Illinois or any other state of an
offense that, under the laws of the state of Illinois, would be a felony theft
of a vehicle or vehicle parts.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Is indebted to the city and is more than sixty (60) days late in
payment of such debt. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-4: PROCESSING APPLICATION; APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The police department will conduct an investigation to determine the
truth and accuracy of the information contained in the application. The police
department will also check to determine whether the location(s) meets
applicable requirements of this chapter as well as city building, zoning and
fire codes. The towing equipment and business will be inspected. Upon
completion of the investigation, the applicant will be notified in writing that
the application is either approved or disapproved, and if disapproved, the
notification will state the reasons for such disapproval. Reasons for
disapproval include, but are not limited to, the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The applicant has furnished false or misleading information or has
failed to provide relevant information on the application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The applicant has not obtained insurance as required by this
chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The location(s) where the applicant will conduct business fails to
meet applicable zoning and/or fire codes or the requirements of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The applicant or any of the owners/partners have been permanently
removed from the police towing licensee list for cause.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The applicant otherwise does not meet all of the requirements of
this chapter or the towing license agreement.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any applicant deemed ineligible by the chief of police will have the
right to appeal the decision of the chief of police to the mayor, or designee.
Appeals must be made by filing a written notice of appeal with the mayor within
ten (10) days of notice of the decision of the chief of police. The mayor will
hear the appeal within fourteen (14) days after the appeal is filed, unless
otherwise agreed. The mayor will notify the applicant of the decision within
seven (7) days after the decision is made. The mayor may affirm or overrule the
decision of the chief of police. The mayor's decision will be final. (Ord.
2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-5: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The licensee shall obtain and maintain general liability, automobile
liability, garage keeper's legal liability and workers' compensation insurance
throughout the period of the agreement as determined by the city. Provided, the
general liability policy shall provide not less than seven hundred fifty
thousand dollars ($750,000.00) of single limit coverage. The insurance policies
shall be with insurance carriers authorized for business in the state of
Illinois.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The city will be named as an additional insured by the licensee on each
insurance policy.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The licensee will provide certificates of insurance to the city which
indicate coverage for the above mentioned insurances and which carry the
provision that said insurance will not be canceled without giving the city at
least thirty (30) days' notice of cancellation or material change. The licensee
shall provide updated certificates as needed. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
Any license granted pursuant to this chapter shall be personal to the
individual or entity to whom issued and may not be transferred to any other
person or entity. Such license shall not be sold, leased, transferred,
assigned, or otherwise disposed of, either in whole or in part, whether by
forced sale, merger, consolidation, bankruptcy, reorganization under bankruptcy
laws, or otherwise, without reapplication. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-7: DUTIES AND REQUIREMENTS OF LICENSEE AND TOW DRIVERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All applicants issued a license, and their agents, will enter into a
towing license agreement with the city, with separate signatures for each
licensee and agent. The written agreement will be in a form approved by the
city attorney.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each licensee will defend, indemnify and hold harmless the city, the
city council, and city officers and employees from any suits, claims, or
actions brought, or disease or illness or damages sustained or arising out of
the operation of towing services and storage of vehicles, and arising out of
the performance of any requirement of this section by the licensee or in
consequence thereof.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All tow trucks shall have working two-way communication equipment with
their base station located at the point where calls are received.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â All tow trucks (except flatbed car carriers) shall carry at least one
set of wheel dollies at all times.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All licensees shall be able to safely transport motorcycles.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Each licensee shall provide twenty four (24) hour per day service each
day of the year. There shall be an attendant or answering service on duty at
all times for the purpose of receiving calls, and there shall be a person on
call as provided herein for the purpose of releasing stored vehicles or for
receiving vehicles. An attendant shall be available at the storage facilities
to release vehicles Monday through Friday, seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. In addition, the attendant shall be on call to release
vehicles from five o'clock (5:00) P.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., Monday
through Friday. On Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, an attendant shall be on
call from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. In addition,
the towing contractor shall provide dispatch with the telephone number of an
employee who will be available for emergency vehicle releases. (Ord. 2006-O-19,
6-6-2006)
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â No vehicles will be released unless a completed and signed vehicle
release form from the city is presented to claim the vehicle. Before issuance
of such form, an administration fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code shall be paid to the city for any vehicle seized as part of
a criminal investigation, including vehicles seized in relation to arrests for
driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs or reckless driving. This fee
shall not apply to vehicles towed for unpaid parking violations or vehicles
removed from the roadway as a result of mechanical failure or accident not
involving charges of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, reckless
driving or felony charges. Persons attempting to claim a vehicle without a
release form will be directed back to the police department to obtain the
necessary release form. A sample release form will be provided for verification
purposes to each towing company. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â All tow trucks shall be equipped with warning lights and all other
equipment required by federal, state or city laws.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Licensee must immediately, and in writing, inform the police department
regarding any changes of the information on the original application for
license. Failure to comply with this requirement may constitute grounds for
removal from the police towing licensee list.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Every licensee or tow driver shall remove or cause to be removed all
glass and debris deposited on any street or highway by the vehicle being
serviced. The licensee or tow driver shall also spread oil-dry upon that
portion of any street or highway where any fluids have been deposited by the
vehicle being serviced, unless the fire department has taken charge of the
cleanup, at which point, the licensee will follow the instructions of fire
department personnel regarding cleanup.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â While at the scene of any call for a license tow, every licensed tow
driver will wear outer apparel that clearly identifies the company for which
the tow driver works and the tow driver's first name.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Each licensee shall maintain a fenced and secure storage lot within two
(2) air miles of the city of adequate size to store all towed vehicles safely,
but in no event shall the capacity be smaller than twenty five (25) vehicles.
In addition, the licensee must have space for at least four (4) cars for long
term storage of approximately six (6) months or more to be utilized at the
discretion of the police department (forfeitures/seizures). The licensee shall
maintain an office at said storage lot that is staffed and open to the public
as provided herein and during normal business hours. When instructed by the
police department that a vehicle in storage must be secured from tampering, the
operator shall store said vehicle so that it is not accessible to any person
except upon specific approval of the police department. The licensee will not
allow anyone but police department personnel to access the vehicle. This
storage will be at the licensee's storage facility and can be within the fenced
lot or within a building at the storage lot, at the discretion of the licensee.
(Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-8: OPERATION OF ROTATION LISTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The police department utilizes the rotation list for all police tows
within the city. The police department will endeavor to ensure that licensees
are called in rotation as far as is reasonable and practicable. Except upon
request of the owner, operator or person legitimately in possession of the
vehicle to be serviced, the police department will not call any tow truck not
on the police towing licensee list unless all such licensees are unavailable.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The police department may deviate from the order of normal rotation if,
in the police department's judgment, deviation is necessary to protect the
public health, safety, and/or welfare or to ensure proper traffic, incident, or
accident management. The police department may also deviate from the order of
normal rotation if the licensee next on rotation is, in the police department's
sole discretion and judgment, incapable or improperly equipped for handling a
specific task.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If a licensee is unable to respond to a request for service within the
time frames required in the towing license agreement, the licensee or employee
thereof shall advise the police department that they are not available due to
an extended response time. The licensee will then be placed at the bottom of
the list. No substitute tow company or licensee will be allowed. The next
licensee on the list shall then be called.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â When a request for service is canceled after being dispatched off the
police towing licensee list, the licensee will be put back at the top of the
list.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The city reserves the right to terminate or modify its license
procedure unilaterally at any time without any notice and without recourse.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The police department may inspect any licensee to determine compliance
with this chapter and applicable agreements and regulations. This inspection
may include the physical location of the business and any place where towed
vehicles are stored, all records associated with license calls, a check of
employees for criminal and traffic records, and anything else related to the
license as deemed appropriate.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â The chief of police may establish reasonable rules and regulations not
inconsistent with this chapter governing the administration and operation of
the tow rotation program. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-9: REMOVAL FROM ROTATION LIST:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Removal From List: The chief of police, or designee, may remove any
licensee temporarily or permanently when it is determined that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The license was secured by fraud or concealment of a material fact
which, if known, would have caused disapproval of the application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter,
rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of police, or the police
department towing license agreement.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The service provided by the licensee has been substantially
inadequate, which shall include, but not be limited to, failing to be available
for or not accepting calls, slow response time, excessive damage claims, theft,
repeated complaints from citizens, or inadequate service or towing equipment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â During the term of the license, any licensee or a tow driver:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Is convicted of any felony in any state;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Is determined to be a "sex offender", as defined in Illinois law,
730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 150/2, as amended; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Is convicted under the laws of Illinois or any other state of an
offense that, under the laws of the state of Illinois, would be a felony theft
of a vehicle or vehicle parts.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â During the term of the license, any licensee is indebted to the city
and is more than sixty (60) days in arrears.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Temporary Removal: If the removal of the licensee from the police
towing licensee list is temporary, such temporary removal shall not be for more
than thirty (30) days at any one time.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Pending Suspension/Removal: If the chief of police, or designee,
determines the alleged offense does not constitute an immediate threat to the
health, safety or welfare of the public, the chief of police shall provide the
licensee with written notice at least fifteen (15) days prior to the effective
date of the temporary or permanent removal by delivering said notice to the
licensee's place of business. Said written notice shall include:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The effective date of the removal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whether the removal is temporary or permanent.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The allegations which form the basis of the removal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The actions, if any, the licensee may take to prevent the removal
from occurring.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The procedure that the licensee must follow to request a hearing to
appeal the removal.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Immediate Suspension/Removal: If the chief of police, or designee,
determines that a licensee presents an immediate threat to the health, safety
or welfare of the public, or if the licensee has not provided proof of valid
insurance in the amounts required by ordinance, the chief of police shall
provide the licensee with written notice that the licensee is being removed
from the police towing licensee list immediately. Said written notice shall be
delivered to the licensee's place of business on the first day the removal is
effective and shall state:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â That the removal is effective immediately.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whether the removal is temporary or permanent.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The allegations which form the basis of the removal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The actions, if any, the licensee may take to be reinstated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The procedure that the licensee must follow to request a hearing to
appeal the removal.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Hearing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If a hearing is requested, the mayor, or the mayor's designee, shall
act as the hearing officer. The hearing shall be informal and provide both
sides with the opportunity to present all evidence relevant to the removal. The
hearing officer shall issue a written decision based upon a preponderance of
the presented evidence within seven (7) days of the hearing. The opinion shall
be sent to the licensee's business address with a copy retained in the
licensee's application file at the police department. If the decision favors
the licensee, the hearing officer shall notify the police department so that
license towing privileges may be reinstated as soon as possible. The city or
the licensee may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner
provided by law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A licensee must request a hearing by calling the mayor's office
within ten (10) days of receiving a notice of suspension or removal and
scheduling a hearing. Leaving a message with the mayor's office will not
satisfy this requirement. The mayor's office must provide a time for the
hearing that is within seventy two (72) hours of the request, provided there is
one complete business day within the seventy two (72) hour time period. If
there is no complete city business day in the seventy two (72) hour period, the
hearing shall be held on the first city business day after the seventy two (72)
hour time period. If the licensee is unavailable at the time provided by the
city, the city shall not be bound by the seventy two (72) hour time period, and
the removal will not be stayed. If the city is unable to provide a hearing time
within the applicable time period, all action on the removal shall be stayed
until the hearing. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-10: FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Towing: Fees for towing will be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code for the primary relocation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Vehicle Storage:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Fees for vehicle storage will be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code for all vehicles. The first twenty four (24) hours of
storage will be at no charge.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The only exception to this will be for police long term storage due
to forfeiture/seizures which will be capped at that fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code, to include the original tow from the date and time of
arrest.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Road Service: Road service (jump starts and tire changes) and towing of
city police vehicles to either a city facility or designated repair shop will
be made free of charge, as is provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
4-9-11: MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Tow trucks will not have any signs indicating city affiliation. The
city reserves the right to contract for additional tow trucks with other
companies during special situations such as snow emergencies, vehicles beyond
the ability of the towing company due to size or weight, etc.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Proper demeanor towards the public will be maintained at all times. All
complaints received will be investigated by the police department and may
result in the towing company being suspended from the list. Excessive or
repeated complaints will not be tolerated. (Ord. 2006-O-19, 6-6-2006)
4-9-12: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. (Ord.
2006-O-19, 6-6-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 10
PRIVATE SCAVENGERS; REFUSE COLLECTION

4-10-1: PRIVATE SCAVENGERS AUTHORIZED:
The mayor may, from time to time, upon application, grant a license to any
qualified person, firm or corporation to remove and dispose of refuse, rubbish,
animal and vegetable matter, swill and offal, usually known as garbage
(hereinafter "garbage"), and discarded materials from hotels, restaurants,
cafes, and other places in the business districts or residential districts, not
otherwise provided by the city, or for the removal and disposal of ashes and
cinders, and for the removal and disposal of such other refuse and waste, where
such matter may accumulate. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-2: RESIDENTIAL SCAVENGERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required: No person, firm or corporation shall carry on the
business of private scavenger or shall be permitted to remove and dispose of
garbage, or any other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, from any residential property, including multi-family
residences, without first having obtained a scavenger license as set forth in
this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â One License Only; Contract For Service:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Only one scavenger license shall be issued for the purpose of
performing refuse collection (other than construction materials) from all
residential property, including multi-family residences (hereinafter
"residential scavenger license"). That person, firm or corporation shall be
awarded a contract or franchise with the city and shall be solely permitted to
remove and dispose of garbage, or any other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, upon obtaining a residential scavenger license.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The residential scavenger license shall be issued to the person,
firm or corporation which has been awarded the contract or franchise for the
collection or removal of all residential waste and shall also be subject to all
conditions established in said contract. Said contract or franchise shall be
subject to the approval of the city council.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â License Fee: The city may, by ordinance, waive any license fee
otherwise required hereunder and/or impose additional or different fees for the
granting and administration of said license. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-3: COMMERCIAL/INSTITUTIONAL SCAVENGERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required: No person, firm or corporation shall carry on the
business of private scavenger or shall be permitted to remove and dispose of
garbage, or any other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, from any business or any commercial/institutional
facility without first having obtained a scavenger license as set forth in this
section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â One License Only; Contract For Service:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Only one scavenger license shall be issued for the purpose of
performing refuse collection (other than construction materials) from any
business or any commercial/institutional facility (hereinafter "commercial/
institutional scavenger license"). That person, firm or corporation shall be
awarded a contract or franchise with the city and shall be solely permitted to
remove and dispose of garbage, or any other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, upon obtaining a commercial/institutional scavenger
license.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The commercial/institutional scavenger license shall be issued to
the person, firm or corporation which has been awarded the contract or
franchise for the collection or removal of all waste from any business or
commercial or institutional facility and shall also be subject to all
conditions established in said contract. Said contract shall be subject to the
approval of the city council.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â License Fee: The city may, by ordinance, waive any license fee
otherwise required hereunder and/or impose additional or different fees for the
granting and administration of said license. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-4: ELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE; VEHICLE LICENSES:
The scavenger licenses granted hereunder shall only be issued to a qualified
applicant who presents evidence that it has adequate and proper equipment and
approved disposal facilities. Each licensee will be issued vehicle licenses as
are necessary. Such licenses shall be provided by the city and displayed on
each vehicle of the licensee used in the city. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All applications for scavenger licenses shall be made pursuant to the
terms of this chapter and such further requirements as may be directed by the
mayor. The mayor, or his designee, shall review the application and approve or
deny each such license. No such license shall be issued except on the order of
the mayor. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every application for license to carry on the business of private
scavenger shall state the number of vehicles which the applicant intends to
operate or use in said business. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The mayor shall have the right to deny a scavenger license, and may
require any reasonable proof necessary for assurance as to the applicant's
compliance and ability to comply with the provisions of this chapter and any
other ordinance of the city. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-6: LICENSE FEE:
Every person, firm or corporation applying for a scavenger license shall pay
annually to the city collector the sum as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code for each and every vehicle used in the service. (Ord. 2002-
O-58, 12-3-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
4-10-7: TERM OF LICENSE:
All scavenger licenses will be valid for a period of one year, which shall
begin July 1 of the year for which such license is issued and shall terminate
on June 30 of the following year. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-8: INDEMNITY, BOND AND INSURANCE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Indemnity: By the acceptance of any scavenger license hereunder, the
licensee shall be deemed to have agreed to defend, save, and hold the city, its
mayor, officials, employees, directors, attorneys, and agents, harmless (to the
greatest extent permissible by law) and indemnify the same against any and all
claims, suits, causes of action, losses, and taxes of any kind or nature
whatsoever, resulting from or in any way related to the granting of said
scavenger license, or otherwise related to the execution or implementation of
any contract, franchise or agreement with any scavenger holding such scavenger
license.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bond: No licenses which have been otherwise approved shall be issued
until the applicant furnishes a bond in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00), executed by a responsible surety company, for the period of the
license, which bond shall guarantee that the scavenger shall perform scavenger
service in accordance with the regulations of the city as ordered from time to
time and shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage resulting from any
failure of the scavenger to so perform.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Insurance: No license shall be issued until the scavenger has filed
with the city clerk a certificate or other evidence that the scavenger carries
insurance of the following types of at least the limits specified below:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Workers' compensation: Statutory, as amended for time to time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Employer's liability: Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Bodily injury lability except automobile: Five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) for each occurrence; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
aggregate.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Property damage liability except automobile: Five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) for each occurrence; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
aggregate.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Automobile bodily injury liability: Five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for each person; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each
occurrence.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Automobile property damage: Five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for each occurrence. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The mayor shall have the right to revoke any scavenger license granted
hereunder where the mayor finds that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of this chapter and any other ordinance of the city, or violated any
applicable governmental regulation, or improperly procured the license. (Ord.
2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-10: EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Every scavenger must demonstrate that he has adequate and sufficient
trucks and refuse containers to render service to any customer requesting
service in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 2002-O-58,
12-3-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All scavenger trucks and refuse containers shall be subject to
inspection and approval by the director of environmental health or his
authorized representatives.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â No scavenger truck shall be operated unless it is a modern, enclosed,
leakproof truck with a load packer. Such equipment shall be cleaned at
sufficient frequency to prevent nuisance and insect breeding and shall be
maintained in good condition and repair. All scavenger trucks will be clearly
identified with the name of the scavenger. Lettering must be at least four
inches (4") in height. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Refuse containers 1  must have a tightfitting cover, be in a state of
good repair, be leakproof, free from rust and periodically painted. The name
and phone number of the scavenger must be clearly visible on the container. All
containers must meet all applicable safety standards as established by the
appropriate health official. Covers for the storage of trade and construction
waste shall not be necessary. The use of drums as refuse bins is prohibited.
(Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002; amd. 2009 Code)

4-10-11: SERVICE STANDARDS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance Required: All licensed scavengers shall fully comply with
all terms and provisions of this chapter or any service agreement with the city
or customer.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Disposal Of Refuse: All applicants and licensed scavengers shall
provide evidence that all materials collected are being deposited at a lawful
site designated and maintained for such purposes under the laws of the state.
The city reserves the right to designate specific sites or locations.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Office Telephone; Hours: All licensed scavengers shall maintain an
office telephone for the receipt of service calls or complaints and shall be
available for such calls on all business days from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
until four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., and between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Saturdays.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Container Lid Closed; Site Maintenance: All licensed scavengers shall
be responsible for the closing of all container lids after emptying and shall
immediately clean up in a neat and workmanlike manner any refuse that it may
have caused to spill anywhere in the city.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Employees:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All licensed scavengers shall furnish capable employees for use in
the crews performing the disposal services.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The scavenger will prohibit any drinking of alcoholic beverages or
use of illegal narcotics by his drivers and crew members while on duty. (Ord.
2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)
4-10-12: COLLECTION DAYS AND HOURS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Residential Scavengers: Each scavenger which is allowed to operate
pursuant to the terms of a residential scavenger license shall remove the
garbage, and any other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, from the residential dwellings in all zoning districts
of the city on Wednesday of each week between the hours of six thirty o'clock
(6:30) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Removal of garbage, or any other matter
enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, is not to be permitted on any other day of the week, or
time, in the above enumerated zones by such scavenger without a special permit
having been first issued by the mayor, upon application by the scavenger and
for good cause shown.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Commercial/Institutional Scavengers: Each scavenger which is awarded a
commercial/institutional scavenger license shall remove the garbage, or other
matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, in the B-1, B-2 and B-3 zoning districts, and from all
business and commercial or institutional facilities, other than residential
units therein, on Monday through Saturday of each week between the hours of six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. Removal of garbage, or any
other matter enumerated in section
4-10-1 of this chapter, is not permitted at any other day or time by a private
scavenger without a special permit having first been issued by mayor, upon
application by the private scavenger and for good cause shown. (Ord. 2002-O-58,
12-3-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
4-10-13: RECEPTACLES 1 :
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Location, Placement And Removal:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In all zoning districts of the city, other than the business zoning
districts, all garbage and refuse receptacles ninety (90) gallons or less in
size, garbage and refuse bags, recycling containers, and all other items of
garbage, trash, refuse, brush, cuttings, or any other matter enumerated in
section
4-10-1 of this chapter, for collection by private scavenger from residential
dwellings shall be placed upon the parkway adjacent to the curbside
(hereinafter "curbside") for collection. However, no person shall place such
items for collection at the curbside sooner than six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on
Tuesday. Further, any recycling containers, garbage, trash or refuse
receptacles, or uncollected items, shall not be allowed to remain at the
curbside later than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. the immediately following
Wednesday. No owner or occupant of a residential dwelling shall allow said
recycling containers and/or garbage, trash or refuse receptacles, or any other
items of garbage, trash, refuse, cuttings, or any other matter enumerated in
section
4-10-1 of this chapter, to remain at the curbside other than from six o'clock
(6:00) P.M., Tuesday, until nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. the immediately following
Wednesday. Further, all garbage and trash receptacles and recycling containers,
when not at the curbside, shall be maintained or stored by the owner or
occupant of any residential dwelling in such a location as to assure that they
are not visible from the streets or sidewalks adjacent to the residential
dwelling.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â In the B-1 zoning district of the city and in all zoning districts
in which a business, commercial, or multiple-family use exists, where a refuse
enclosure area, as set forth herein, is provided, all garbage and refuse
receptacles, garbage and refuse bags, recycling containers, and all other items
of garbage, trash, refuse, brush, cuttings, or any other matter enumerated in
section
4-10-1 of this chapter, for collection by private scavenger, which are not
placed at the curb for collection as set forth in subsection A of this section
shall at all times be kept in the enclosed and screened area designated for
their use as required by the terms of the city appearance code (hereinafter
"refuse enclosure area") except when the refuse is actually being collected.
Any scavenger providing service shall place all garbage and refuse receptacles,
recycling containers, and all other items for storage of garbage or trash in
the refuse enclosure area and secure and close any gate or door to such refuse
enclosure area. Further, no garbage or refuse receptacles, recycling
containers, or other items for storage of garbage or trash, or uncollected
items shall be allowed to remain outside the refuse enclosure area or the gate
or door thereto unsecured or open. No scavenger providing service to a premises
or owner or occupant of a premises shall permit any garbage or refuse
receptacles, recycling containers, or other items for storage of garbage or
trash, or uncollected items to remain outside the refuse enclosure area, or the
gate or door thereto unsecured or open.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Failure by any entity providing scavenger services to comply with
any provision of this chapter shall constitute cause for cancellation of the
scavenger's license, in addition to any other penalty hereunder.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notification Stickers: It shall be the duty of every licensed private
scavenger to affix upon each garbage, refuse or trash receptacle and recycling
container in use in the city an adhesive notification sticker advising each
owner and occupant that trash receptacles, recycling containers, trash bags,
refuse, and all items for collection shall not be placed at the curbside
collection point sooner than six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on Tuesday evening and
shall be removed from the curbside collection point by nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.
the immediately following Wednesday. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-3-2002)

4-10-14: BILLS FOR SERVICE; DELINQUENCIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Should the charges for refuse services be billed by the city, and in

the bill amount as a late payment penalty; provided, however, that an
additional late charge of five percent (5%) per month of the outstanding bill
shall accrue thereafter as a penalty for failure to make prompt payments.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the invoice for such services is not paid within sixty (60) days
after the rendition of the bill, such services may be discontinued without
further notice and shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled. In the
event that refuse service is cut off or terminated to any consumer for failure
to make payment for services required hereunder, refuse services shall be
restored to the consumer only upon payment of the consumer's bill, all accrued
late charges and an administrative fee.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Further, the consumer shall pay any and all fees incurred by the city
in effectuating and administrating the termination of services, including, but
not limited to, administrative fees.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In addition to any sum due to the city under the provisions of this
chapter, any consumer who fails to pay the invoices set forth in this section
within twenty (20) days from the date of mailing shall pay any and all
reasonable attorney fees incurred by the city in enforcing the provisions of
this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In the event the city deems it necessary to bring any court action to
enforce this chapter, there shall be assessed against any such consumer all
reasonable costs, expenses and attorney fees incurred by the city in bringing
the action in addition to the other sums set forth herein. (Ord. 2002-O-58, 12-
3-2002)

self-service dry cleaners or dry cleaners in the city without first having
obtained a license therefor. (Ord. 88-O-4, 3-15-1988)

amd. 2009 Code)

4-11-5: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Premises: The licensed premises must be kept in a clean and sanitary

Code)
4-11-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the appropriate health official to inspect or cause to
be inspected every establishment licensed under this chapter at least once
every six (6) months. Any violations under the terms of this chapter which are
discovered shall be reported to the chief of police. (Ord. 88-O-4, 3-15-1988)
4-11-7: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMPLIANCE:

4-12-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No person may conduct or otherwise hold any such sale at any location
within the B-1, B-2 or B-3 zoning district of the city, except as provided in

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Within the B-1 district, such sales may be held and a permit issued

visible from the street. (Ord. 97-O-25, 7-15-1997)
4-12-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE; ISSUANCE OR DENIAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The city clerk shall provide application forms to request permits

needed by city departments to evaluate necessary city planning and response
incident to the conduct of such sale. The application form shall be submitted

commencement of the sale.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each application for a permit for a sale at a residence shall include
full payment of a filing fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any application which is not fully completed and accompanied by full

Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The city clerk shall issue a permit for each application hereunder
which has been properly filed, unless the issuance of such permit would violate

other state, federal or local law or regulation. No permit shall be issued
which, in combination with any other permit, would appear to permit any such

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In the event of inclement weather during the scheduled garage sale
dates, the city manager, or his designee, may allow for a reschedule for the

Any permit issued hereunder shall be prominently posted at the premises where

4-12-5: RESTRICTIONS ON SALES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Number: Not more than one sale shall be conducted at or from any
property within the city within any single calendar year.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Duration: No sale shall extend more than two (2) consecutive days.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Items Prohibited From Sale: Items purchased for the purpose of resale
are not allowed to be sold at garage sales. The sale of large quantities of a
particular item is considered the retail sale of goods and is not allowed in
residential districts.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Sale Items: Sale items shall be placed on paved surfaces or inside a
structure. No item shall be visible from the public way prior to a sale or
after a sale has concluded.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Time Of Posting: Signs in connection with or relating to any such
sale shall be posted only during the day(s) such sale is permitted, and for one
and one-half (11/2) hours before and after the actual conduct of such sale.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Removal: All such signs shall be promptly removed and properly
disposed of or stored at the end of the last day of any such sale.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Prohibited Locations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â No signs or any other item shall be posted in, upon, or in any
way connected to any tree, live plant, street or utility pole, official traffic
control device or traffic sign, fire hydrant, or similar structure or item.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â No such sign shall be located so as to constitute any hazard to
traffic or so as to obstruct or obscure, in any way, any official traffic
control device.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Size: No such sign shall exceed four (4) square feet nor more than
four feet (4') in height.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Prerequisites To Posting Signs: No person may otherwise post, allow
or cause to be posted within the city any sign for a house sale, garage sale,
rummage sale, or the like, unless a permit has been applied for, and until
approval for the same has been granted by the issuance of a permit by the city
hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Prima Facie Proof: For purposes of this chapter, the responsible
person for the improper posting of signage shall be presumed to be the occupant
(s) of the premises advertised in any posted sign. (Ord. 14-O-38, 11-18-2014)
4-12-6: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation violating any
provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity

CHAPTER 13
COMMERCIAL KENNELS
SECTION:
4-13-1: Definitions
4-13-2: License Required
4-13-3: License Fee And Expiration
4-13-4: Nontransferability Of License
4-13-5: Sanitary Conditions
4-13-6: Revocation Of License
4-13-7: Responsibility For Compliance
4-13-8: Penalty
4-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the
purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in
this chapter, except when the context otherwise requires:
COMMERCIAL KENNEL: Any lot, premises or portion thereof on which more than four
(4) dogs, cats, and other household domestic animals over four (4) months of
age are kept, or on which more than two (2) such animals are maintained, bred,
cared for or boarded for compensation or kept for sale.
DOG: Any animal, male or female, of any kind, age and description, of the
canine species, which is more than two (2) months of age.
PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation or association.
PROPRIETOR: The person operating a commercial kennel or in charge of said
business. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a commercial kennel within the
city unless such person shall first have obtained from the city clerk a license
therefor as herein provided. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-3: LICENSE FEE AND EXPIRATION:
The fee for a license shall be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. All licenses expire on May 1 of each year. No refund shall
be granted for portions of any year. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-4: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
The license shall not be transferable. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986)
4-13-5: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
Commercial kennels shall be kept free of dirt and filth and kept in an all
around sanitary condition both inside and outside said establishment and shall
be operated so as not to be offensive to the health, safety and general welfare
of the public, or the residents of the vicinity in which they are located. Upon
written complaint filed with the city council, the chief of police shall make
an inspection to determine the conditions of said business and shall report
same to the city council. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked by the mayor whenever it
is determined that any person is operating and maintaining an establishment in
violation of any of the terms and provisions of this chapter. Within ten (10)
days of notice of intent to revoke the license, licensee may request a hearing
before the city council to determine whether the said establishment is in
violation of any of the terms and provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-
15-1986)
4-13-7: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMPLIANCE:
The proprietor of any commercial kennel shall be responsible to provide
compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 86-O-11, 4-15-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall,
upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
CHAPTER 14
TELECOMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS REVIEW
SECTION:
4-14-1: Definitions
4-14-2: Proposal For Telecommunications System
4-14-3: Review Fees
4-14-4: Nonliability Of City
4-14-5: Penalty
4-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
APPLICANT: Any person or entity who applies to the city of Highwood for review
of a telecommunications system proposal.
REVIEW FEE: A nonrefundable fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code, or such lesser amount as is provided for herein.
STREET: Any area in the city boundaries established for vehicular or public
access or use and includes, but is not limited to, a highway, avenue, road,
alley, right of way, lane, boulevard, concourse, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway,
waterway, and overhead.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM: Any communication equipment or facility of any type
or composition which is proposed to be developed within the city of Highwood,
including any such facility which in any manner is located in or over, or
connected with, to or under, or which utilizes any public way or other city
owned land in any fashion, or which now or hereafter is within the corporate
limits of the city. (Ord. 99-O-06, 1-19-1999; amd. 2009 Code)
4-14-2: PROPOSAL FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM:
Any person or entity that desires to construct, or route through, commence
operation of or modify a telecommunications system with the city shall submit
twelve (12) copies of any written proposal (including any and all attachments)
describing such telecommunications system in detail for review to the office of
the city collector, with a copy of same to the office of the city attorney. The
city collector shall promptly forward such information to the mayor. The mayor
shall forward the information and application to such city departments and
staff as he may deem appropriate for review of same and negotiation of
modifications as may be required. All proposals shall include all the
information requested in a form provided by the city collector's office. The
city may request additional information, from time to time, from the applicant
and may, in the course of review, arrange for appropriate professional
services, which may include engineering, consulting, or legal. Upon completion
of the review by the designated city staff, the staff shall prepare a written
recommendation to the city council for its consideration and final action. No
person or entity may construct, commence operation of or modify a
"telecommunications system", as defined in section
4-14-1 of this chapter, without obtaining approval of the city authorities as
provided herein. (Ord. 99-O-06, 1-19-1999)
4-14-3: REVIEW FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Fee Imposed: Upon submission of the proposal to the city collector's
office, the applicant shall pay the review fee to reimburse the city for the
administrative costs and any professional fees associated with the review of
the proposal, or the negotiation of any agreement or modifications for
implementation of same. In the event the city's costs to review the proposal
exceed the review fee, the city shall notify the applicant detailing said
additional costs, and the applicant shall pay such additional fees at such
times as are required by the city collector.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Waiver Of Fee: The city council may waive or modify the review fee for
any proposal as to which the city council determines will require minimum
review by the city. An applicant may request a waiver or modification of the
review fee by submitting a request in writing to the city stating the reasons
for such waiver or modification.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Proposal Modification Fee: Any change or modification to the proposal
submitted for review by an applicant following the inception of the review
process may require, in the discretion of the city, that the applicant pay to
the city an additional review fee hereunder. Any such additional costs will be
identified as described in subsection A of this section. (Ord. 99-O-06, 1-19-
1999)
4-14-4: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â This chapter or the review of any telecommunications system proposal or
the collection of a review fee shall not be construed to create or hold the
city responsible or liable for any damage to persons or property by reasons of
any inspection, reinspection or review authorized herein or failure to inspect,
reinspect or review, nor shall the approval of any application authorized
herein constitute any representation, guarantee or warranty of any kind by, nor
create any liability upon, the city or any official, agent or employee thereof.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Further, this chapter or the review of the telecommunications systems
proposal or the collection of the review fee shall not be construed to create
or imply any agreement by the city to grant the application or permit for the
proposed telecommunications system. (Ord. 99-O-06, 1-19-1999)
4-14-5: PENALTY:
Any person, partnership, firm, or corporation, or employee of same, violating
any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)

CHAPTER 17
VIDEO GAMING PROHIBITION
SECTION:
4-17-1: Authority
4-17-2: Definitions
4-17-3: Prohibition
4-17-4: Enforcement
4-17-5: Penalties
4-17-1: AUTHORITY:
This chapter is promulgated pursuant to the authority to prohibit "video
gaming" (as defined below) in the city, as contained in 230 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 40/27, all as may be amended from time to time. (Ord. 2011-O-01, 1-11-
2011)
4-17-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
VIDEO GAMING: The ownership, placement, maintenance, operation or use of a
"video gaming terminal" (as defined herein) in a licensed establishment,
licensed fraternal establishment or licensed veterans establishment, as said
terms are defined within the video gaming act 1  (hereinafter the
"establishment(s)"), within the city.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including,
but not limited to, video poker, line up and blackjack, as authorized by the
Illinois gaming board, utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which
the player may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The
term does not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash or tokens
or is for amusement purposes only. (Ord. 2011-O-01, 1-11-2011)
Â 
Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
4-17-3: PROHIBITION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Video gaming is prohibited within the city of Highwood.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A video gaming license issued by the state of Illinois is not effective
within the city of Highwood.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A prohibited video gaming terminal shall be immediately removed by the
owner or operator from the establishment(s).
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for a person, firm or corporation to permit or
allow any video gaming terminal to be played or remain within any establishment
(s) within the city of Highwood. (Ord. 2011-O-01, 1-11-2011)
4-17-4: ENFORCEMENT:
Authorized representatives of the city of Highwood police department, including
sworn peace officers and other individuals as the chief or deputy chief of the
city's police department may designate from time to time, may make inspections
of the premises of establishment(s) or any premises where there is cause to
believe video gaming occurs, for the purpose of determining whether a violation
of this chapter is taking place. These inspection rights are in addition to any
other statutory or common law powers of the city's police department. (Ord.
2011-O-01, 1-11-2011)
4-17-5: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In lieu of prosecution under subsection A of this section, any person,
firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter may be subject
to prosecution under the gambling provisions of the Illinois criminal code, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1 et seq. (Ord. 2011-O-01, 1-11-2011)

4-18-2: AGGREGATION OF ELECTRICAL LOAD:

electricity aggregation program pursuant to the act and for that purpose may
solicit bids and enter into service agreements to facilitate the sale and
purchase of electricity and related services and equipment for those loads
