6-4-3: DOG RABIES TAGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Rabies Vaccination Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Every owner of a dog within the City limits shall obtain a rabies
vaccination and tag from Lake County Health Department pursuant to the Lake
County, IL Code of Ordinances chapter 172.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Rabies Tag And Collar:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Rabies Tag And Collar Required: The owner of a dog shall keep a
collar upon the dog's neck with a metallic or plastic tag securely fastened
thereto that identifies the dog and provides the date of the rabies
vaccination. Any dog found within the City without a tag so fastened upon its
neck shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be disposed of as provided in this
chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Removing Collar And Tag Prohibited; Expired Tags: No person shall
remove or take away the collar or tag from any dog, or entice or decoy any dog
out of any house or enclosed lot or from without the City limits to within the
City for the purpose of impounding such dog. When any dog is at large within
the City and a tag for any preceding year is attached to the dog, the owner of
the dog shall be notified where possible and required to procure a current tag.
(Ord. 19-O-04, 4-16-2019)
6-4-4: DOGS AT LARGE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Leash Required: No owner of a dog shall permit the dog to run at large
in any part of the City at any time. Any dog off the premises of the owner and
not under the control of the owner or a member of his immediate family over ten
(10) years of age, by leash, shall be considered "at large". "Leash" means a
cord, thong or chain, not more than ten feet (10') in length, by which a dog is
controlled by the person accompanying it. A dog within the car of its owner
shall be deemed to be upon the owner's premises.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Removal Of Excrement: It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or
permit a dog to be on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed
by such person unless such person has in his immediate possession a device for
the removal of excrement and a depository for the transmission of excrement to
a receptacle located upon property owned or possessed by such person. Further,
it shall be unlawful for any person in control of, causing or permitting any
dog to be on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed by such
person, to fail to remove excrement left by such dog to a proper receptacle
located on property owned or possessed by such person.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Impoundment: Any dog found at large on any street of the City contrary
to the provisions of this section shall be impounded according to the
directions of the Chief of Police. (Ord. 2006-O-12, 3-21-2006)
6-4-5: IMPOUNDMENT, REDEMPTION AND DISPOSITION OF DOGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Impoundment: Any dog found within the City not having a collar upon its
neck and a current rabies tag attached thereto shall be caught and impounded at
the direction of the Chief of Police.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Records; Notice Of Impoundment; Failure To Redeem: The City official,
upon receiving any dog, shall make a complete registry, entering the breed,
color and sex of such dog, and whether tagged. If tagged, he shall enter the
name, address, and telephone number of the owner and the number of the tag.
Tagged dogs shall be separated from untagged dogs. Not later than eight (8)
hours after the impounding of any dog, the owner shall be contacted by phone.
If the owner does not retrieve the dog, or if the owner of the dog is unknown,
the County Animal Control Office will be contacted to retrieve the animal.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Redemption: The owner of any tagged dog so impounded or the person
claiming to be the owner of any untagged dog may redeem such dog in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter upon payment of an impounding fee and a
maintenance charge, all as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code. All fees and charges shall be paid to the City Collector,
and upon presentation of a proper receipt from the City Collector, the City
official in possession of the dog shall release such dog in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 19-O-04, 4-16-2019)
6-4-6: DANGEROUS DOGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Confinement Requirements: Any person who keeps or harbors a dangerous
dog shall keep such dog confined, except as set forth hereinafter. "Confined",
as that term is used in this section, shall mean such dog is securely kept
indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or dog run area made of, at
least, 9-gauge chainlink with no more than one inch (1") spacing. Said pen or
run must be locked with a key or combination lock whenever such dog or dogs are
within the structure. Said pen or dog run area must have sides at least six
feet (6') high and be secured over the top. If the pen or dog run area has no
bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less
than one foot (1') deep.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Unconfined; Muzzle And Chain Required: Any person keeping or harboring
a dangerous dog, at any time said dog is not confined, shall ensure such dog is
securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a minimum tensile strength
of three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three feet (3') in length.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Warning Sign: Any person keeping or harboring a dangerous dog shall
display, in a prominent place on the premises where the dog is kept, a sign,
easily readable by the public, using the words "Beware Of Dog". In addition, a
similar sign shall be posted on the pen or run of such animal.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Destruction Of Dog: In addition to any penalties the court may
prescribe for violation of this section, if the court finds, after notice to
the keeper or harborer and an opportunity for hearing, that such dangerous dog
represents a continuing threat of serious harm to human beings or other
domestic animals, the court may order such animal destroyed. (Ord. 2006-O-12,
3-21-2006)
6-4-7: ANIMALS THAT BITE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall allow any dog to run at large which has previously
bitten any person.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If any person is bitten by a dog or other animal, the Police Department
shall forthwith cause the animal to be examined for rabies at the expense of
the owner or keeper thereof, and if the animal is so afflicted, it shall be
immediately destroyed. (Ord. 2006-O-12, 3-21-2006)
6-4-8: KEEPING OF CHICKENS IN RESIDENTIAL ZONING DISTRICTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Chickens are permitted in all residential zoning districts on
properties with single, two, or three-family residences only.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The total number of chickens permitted on any residential zoning lot is
five (5).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Roosters (male adult chickens) are prohibited.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Chickens shall not be allowed in any residence or attached garage.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Chickens must be confined in a coop in the backyard of the residence
with a minimum of one (1) square foot per bird.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The maximum coop size is eight (8) square feet.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â An outside, screen enclosed run is permitted. Said run shall be no
larger than sixty-four (64) square feet, and shall be attached to the coop.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The coop and run shall be a minimum of five (5) feet from any property
line and at least fifteen (15) from any neighboring residence.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â The owner shall dispose of waste materials (feed, manure, and litter)
in an environmentally responsible manner. The materials may be composted or
bagged and disposed of in the trash. Piling waste materials on the property is
prohibited.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Owners shall store all feed supplies in rodent-proof containers and
promptly dispose of dead birds and waste eggs.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â The owner must feed and water the chickens on a daily basis.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Sales of eggs is prohibited. (Ord. 21-O-27, 11-2-2021)
6-4-9: NOISY ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall keep or harbor any dog or other animal shut up or tied
up in any yard, enclosure, stable, house or other place, which animal, by
barking, howling, bawling or by any other noise, disturbs the peace and quiet
of any family, individual or neighborhood.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No person shall keep or harbor any chicken, hen, rooster, or other
poultry or other birds which animal, by crowing, squealing, escaping,
attacking, pecking, chasing or by any other noise or activity disturbs the
peace and quiet of any family, individual or neighborhood. (Ord. 2006-O-12, 3-
21-2006; amd. Ord. 21-O-27, 11-2-2021)
6-4-10: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as provided herein, any person, firm or corporation violating
any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 19-O-04, 4-16-2019)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any person, firm or corporation violating section
6-4-6 of this chapter shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, and
a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2006-O-12, 3-21-2006)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person violating section
6-4-9B of this chapter shall remove the offending animal within ten (10) days'
notice by the City of Highwood. (Ord. 21- O-27, 11-2-2021)
CHAPTER 5
CRIMINAL CONDUCT CODE
SECTION:
6-5-1: Title
6-5-2: State Criminal Code Adopted
6-5-3: Penalty
6-5-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the CITY OF HIGHWOOD CRIMINAL CONDUCT CODE OF
1977. (Ord. 77-O-11, 10-7-1977)
6-5-2: STATE CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and
sections of the Illinois criminal code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1 et
seq., as amended, are hereby adopted by the city. Any and all violations
thereof shall be considered violations of this chapter and each such violation
shall subject the violator thereof to penalty provisions under this chapter.
(2009 Code)
6-5-3: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person, partnership, firm,
entity or corporation in violation of any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
ARTICLE A. OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY

Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Provisions of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-3 shall apply. Said

1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Entry upon the land or any part thereof of the municipal water

6-5A-9: DEPOSITING DANGEROUS SUBSTANCES UPON STREETS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall throw or deposit upon any highway any glass bottle,

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any person who drops or permits to be dropped or thrown upon any

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a highway or
street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the

6-5A-10: DAMAGE TO STREET SURFACES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven a vehicle of
any description in or upon any portion of the highway or street or alley
immediately after the same has been dragged and before such portion of the
highway or street shall have partially dried out or frozen; provided, that
nothing in this section shall apply in those instances where it is impossible
to drive with safety at one side of said dragged portion of the road, or where
a vehicle does not make a rut on such dragged portion of the road, injurious to
the work accomplished by use of the road drag or where a vehicle does not make
a rut nearer than nine feet (9') from the center of the dragged portion of the
road. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-1975)
6-5A-11: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully injure or damage any public
highway or street or any bridge, culvert, sign, signpost, or structure upon or
used or constructed in connection with any public highway or street for the
protection thereof or for protection or regulation of traffic thereon by any
wilful unusual, improper or unreasonable use thereof, or by wilful careless
driving or careless use of any vehicle thereon, or by wilful mutilation,
defacing or destruction thereof. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-1975)
6-5A-12: RECORDKEEPING REQUIREMENTS FOR RESALE DEALERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â "Resale dealer" is defined as anyone engaged in a for profit business
which buys, sells, or trades jewelry, stamps, electronics, or any precious
metals previously owned by a consumer. The following are exempt: residential
garage sales, sales conducted by governmental, civic, religious, educational or
benevolent organizations that are exempt from taxation under 501(c) of the
federal internal revenue code, automobile dealers, consumer shows or
exhibitions, auctioneers, pawnbrokers, recyclable metal sales, coin dealers,
and providers of commercial mobile service as defined in 47 USC 332(d).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All resale dealers must keep records in accordance with the provisions
of the resale dealers act, 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 398/1 et seq. The
records must include accurate descriptions of each sale, including the goods
purchased, the name and address of the seller, and serial number or
identification number of the item received. The records must also identify each
item received by the resale dealer from any source, the time of the receipt,
and the name and address of the source. These records must be maintained in a
manner approved of by the Highwood police department, and must be kept for
three (3) years.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All resale dealers are required to deliver an exact copy of the
previous day's record, in a daily report to the Highwood police department by
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon each day. The daily report must contain an accurate
account and description, in the English language, of all goods, articles, and
other things purchased, the amount of money, value or thing loaned thereon, the
time of sale and the name and address of the person selling such item, include
the serial number or identification numbers of the items received, shall be
printed, typed, or written in ink, and must otherwise comply with the resale
dealers act, 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 398/1 et seq.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The records may be hand delivered to the Highwood police department
each day in hard copy, or they may be delivered through LeadsOnlineÂ©, an
internet based software program that is fully funded by the Highwood police
department and free for resale dealers to use. (Ord. 15-O-44, 7-7-2015)

6-5B-9: CURFEW FOR JUVENILES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: In this section, the following words and terms shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
Â Â Â  EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting
state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited
to, a fire, a natural disaster, a motor vehicle accident, or any situation
requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life.
Â Â Â PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and
the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings,
transport facilities, and shops.
Â Â Â SERIOUS BODILY INJURY: Bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of
death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss
or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Offenses:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of seventeen (17)
years to be upon any public street, highway, road, alley or other public ground
or public place between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday,
Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the
following day, and between the hours of eleven fifty nine o'clock (11:59) P.M.
on Friday and Saturday and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the following day. (Ord.
2004-O-24, 4-6-2004)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person
having the care and custody of a minor child under the age of seventeen (17)
years to knowingly permit such a minor to go or be in or upon any of the public
streets, highways, roads, alleys or other public ground or public place in the
city during the days and times set out in subsection B1 of this section. (Ord.
2004-O-24, 4-6-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Defenses: It is a defense to prosecution under subsection B of this
section that the minor was:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person
having the care and custody of the minor; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of the state of
Illinois authorize a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to perform,
or going to or returning home from such employment activity, without detour or
stop; or (Ord. 2004-O-24, 4-6-2004)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â On an errand, directed by his or her parent, guardian or other adult
person having the care and custody of the minor, without any detour or stop; or
(Ord. 2004-O-24, 4-6-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Involved in an emergency; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the
residence of a next door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the
police department about the minor's presence; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational
activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization,
or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to
or returning home from such an activity, without any detour or stop; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States
constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the
right of assembly; or (Ord. 2004-O-24, 4-6-2004)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Married or has been married or is an emancipated minor under the
emancipation of minors act 1 , as amended. (Ord. 2004-O-24, 4-6-2004; amd. 2009
Code)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Enforcement: Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a
police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in
the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest
under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has
occurred and that, based upon any response and other circumstances, no defense
in subsection C of this section is present. (Ord. 2004-O-24, 4-6-2004)

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A mandatory requirement shall be imposed by any court finding a
person guilty of violating the provisions of this subsection as a condition to

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Removal Of Graffiti; Restitution:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be duty of each person, firm, corporation, partnership or

otherwise repair or restore the structure or wall to its prior condition within
five (5) days of receipt of a written request from the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The owner of the property shall be entitled to restitution and
compensation for the direct costs incurred in the repair and restoration of his
property from any person convicted of the prohibited activity upon the
submission of receipts evidencing payments of such costs and provided the court
entering the finding or conviction for the offense shall so order. (Ord. 92-O-

ARTICLE D. OFFENSES INVOLVING ALCOHOL AND DRUGS
SECTION:

6-5D-1: CANNABIS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Possession Of Cannabis Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
to knowingly possess cannabis within the limits of the city. This section shall
not be construed as conflicting with or limiting the enforcement of the
Illinois cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., as
amended from time to time.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Possession Of Less Than Ten Grams Of Cannabis:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any person who violates this section by possessing not more than ten
grams (10 g) of cannabis shall be issued a notice of violation directing the
individual to appear before the city's administrative hearing officer for an
administrative adjudication hearing in accordance with the provisions of title
1, chapter 5 of this code, as may be amended from time to time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any person appearing before the administrative hearing officer and
found to have violated this section by possessing not more than ten grams (10
g) of cannabis shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation, and in the
discretion of the hearing officer, may be referred to a suitable drug
education, counseling, or rehabilitation program, and/or ordered to perform
community service.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Possession Of More Than Ten Grams Of Cannabis: Persons possessing more
than ten grams (10 g) of cannabis and who are cited for violations of this
section will have such citations adjudicated in the circuit court of the 19th
judicial circuit, Lake County, Illinois. Any person found to have violated this
section by possessing more than ten grams (10 g) of cannabis shall be fined not
less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each violation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Annual Report: The chief of police shall make an annual report and
evaluation to the city council of the disposition of all violations of this
section. (Ord. 14-O-18, 7-1-2014)
6-5D-2: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
Provisions of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/1 et seq., shall apply. Said
statute can be enforced as an ordinance violation subject to the penalty
provisions of section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
6-5D-3: POSSESSION OF LIQUOR:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definition: As used in this section, the term "alcoholic liquor" means
any spirits, wine, beer, ale or other liquid containing more than one-half of
one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume, which is fit for beverage purposes.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Unlawful Possession:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to be in possession of any alcoholic liquor in
or upon a public way or other public place within the city unless the alcoholic
liquor is in its original container with the seal unbroken, or unless the
possession is on the premises of an establishment holding valid classes 1, 2
and 4 city liquor licenses. For the purpose of this subsection B1, a public way
or other public place shall include, but is not limited to, all city streets
and alleys, city owned parking facilities, all drives, parking lots and common
areas serving commercial establishments, and all drives, parking areas and
common areas serving multi-family residential structures containing four (4) or
more dwelling units; provided, that this prohibition shall apply to such multi-
family drives, parking areas, and common areas only if the owner, manager or
owners' association has stated, in writing, that it is the intention of the
ownership of such drives, parking areas and common areas that such prohibition
be applicable thereto. The written statement may reserve the right of
management to give one day permits for residents or tenants to hold social
gatherings in a common area at which alcoholic liquor is consumed. The
provisions of this subsection B1 shall not apply to block parties for which the
city clerk has issued a one day permit. (Ord. 93-O-26, 8-3-1993; amd. 2009
Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, transfer, consume,
or sell any alcoholic beverage in or upon the grounds of the municipal water
treatment plant. (Ord. 88-O-12, 6-21-1988)

6-5F-7: FALSE IDENTIFICATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â For purposes of this section, the following words and terms shall have

Â Â Â  FALSE INFORMATION: Includes, but is not limited to, any information

Â Â Â GOVERNMENTAL STYLE IDENTIFICATION: One which is, or purports to be, an

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Purports to be a governmental style identification, but which has
not in fact been issued by the purported entity; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Has been canceled, suspended, revoked, or the like; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Was issued or belongs to any other person.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to display or cause

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Was issued to a person other than the individual presenting such
identification.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to:

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Scope:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â This subsection shall apply to any proceeding, judicial or

ARTICLE G. TOBACCO CONTROL
SECTION:
6-5G-1: Definitions
6-5G-2: License Requirements
6-5G-3: Location Restrictions
6-5G-4: Prohibitions Regarding Minors
6-5G-5: Additional Prohibitions
6-5G-6: Tobacco Accessories And Smoking Herbs
6-5G-7: Administration And Enforcement
6-5G-8: Penalties
6-5G-1: DEFINITIONS:
BIDI CIGARETTE: A product that contains tobacco that is wrapped in temburni or
tendu leaf or that is wrapped in any other material identified by rules of the
department of public health that is similar in appearance or characteristics to
the temburni or tendu leaf.
CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service
device which, upon insertion of money, coins, tokens or any other form of
payment, dispenses tobacco products.
CITY: The city of Highwood, Lake County, Illinois.
LICENSEE: Any individual, sole proprietor, firm, entity, partnership,
association, limited liability company or corporation to whom a license has
been issued for the sale of tobacco products.
PERSON: Any individual, sole proprietor, firm, entity, partnership,
association, limited liability company or corporation.
SMOKING HERBS: All substances of plant origin and their derivatives, including,
but not limited to, broom, calea, California poppy, damiana, hops, ginseng,
lobelia, jimson weed and other members of the Datura genus, passion flower and
wild lettuce, which are processed or sold primarily for use as smoking
materials.
TOBACCO ACCESSORIES: Any cigarette papers, pipes, holders of smoking materials
of all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items designed primarily
for the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products, or of substances made illegal
under any ordinance or statute, or of substances whose sale, gift, barter, or
exchange is made illegal by this article or any statute.
TOBACCO OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including,
but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, smokeless tobacco,
chewing tobacco, dipping tobacco and/or tobacco in any of its forms. (Ord.
2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)
6-5G-2: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, at
retail, to give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at
retail, giving away or delivering tobacco products within the city, without
having first obtained a license therefor. Said license shall be required
regardless of the method of sale or dispensing and shall include sales and
dispensing by self-service, manual service, mechanical service or coin operated
device.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â In the event the licensee chooses to offer such materials for sale
by means of a cigarette vending machine device exclusively, the provisions of
this section shall not be interpreted to require an additional license and fee
for the premises whereon such device is located.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The license shall authorize the licensee named therein to sell
tobacco products only at the place designated therein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Application For License: In order to obtain a license, the applicant
shall file with the city collector a written statement setting forth the full
name and address, date and place of birth of the applicant; or the names and
addresses, dates and places of birth of the partners, if the applicant is a
partnership; or the names and addresses of each of the directors, officers and
shareholders of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation; and the
present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the
application. In the case of a corporation, the application shall disclose the
number and class of shares owned by each shareholder. The application shall be
in substantially the same form as is attached to the ordinance codified herein
as exhibit A. The application shall be signed and notarized under oath by the
applicant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Investigation Of Applicant; Ineligibility For License: The application
shall be referred by the city collector to the mayor, who shall cause an
investigation of the applicant to be made by the chief of police who shall make
his report and recommendations on the application to the mayor. Said report
shall be presented to the mayor within a reasonable time for approval by the
mayor; provided, however, that the mayor may opt not to issue license to any of
the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state or of the United States within the immediately preceding five (5) years
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted, within the immediately preceding
five (5) years, of violations of law regarding the sale of tobacco products or
tobacco accessories, unless the mayor finds that a repeat offense is unlikely.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of keeping a place of prostitution,
pandering or other crime or misdemeanor or ordinance violation opposed to
decency and morality within the immediately preceding five (5) years (unless
pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A person who, at the time of application for renewal of a license
hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A partnership, unless all of the partners of said partnership shall
be individually qualified to obtain a license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A corporation, unless all officers, managers, or directors thereof,
or any shareholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the
shares of the corporation, shall each be individually qualified to obtain a
license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A limited liability company, unless all the members thereof, or any
shareholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the shares
of the company, shall each be individually qualified to obtain a license
hereunder.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Authority To Reject License: The city reserves the right to reject any
and all applications for any license hereunder or for the renewal of any
license previously issued by the city, and upon such rejection, the annual
license fee tendered by the applicant shall be returned. (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-
2002)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â License Fees: The license fee to sell tobacco within the city shall be
as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. The license fee for each additional cigarette vending
machine at the same premises operated by the same licensee shall be determined
by title 4, chapter 3 of this code. (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Expiration Of License: Each license issued hereunder shall expire on
June 30 following its issuance. The license fee shall be due and payable on or
before July 1 of each year.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Renewals: The issuance of any license hereunder shall not be construed
as creating any future right in the applicant to receive a renewal therefor.
The licenses issued hereunder expire on an annual basis, and the person making
application under this article acknowledges that, upon expiration of the annual
license, the city shall not be obliged to renew or extend said license, and the
granting of the license hereunder is a privilege granted to the applicant and
creates no property right in the applicant and no expectation of continued
renewal thereof.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Posting License: The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in
the premises designated therein.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Transfer Of License: The license shall be nonassignable and
nontransferable by the licensee, but may be transferred from one cigarette
vending machine to a replacement device within the same premises. Any such
transfer must be reported within two (2) working days from the date of
transfer, in writing, to the city. The notification of transfer must include
the name, serial number and location of each device transferred.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Disposition Of Funds; Records Kept: The city collector shall deposit
all funds received under this article in the general fund of the city. In
addition, the city collector shall cause to be kept a record of all operator
licenses, arcade licenses and device licenses issued pursuant to the terms of
this article, showing the names and addresses of all persons to whom operator
licenses and arcade licenses are issued and the description of the device and
location for each device issued hereunder, as well as any other information
deemed essential. (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)
6-5G-3: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or
deliver tobacco products within one hundred feet (100') of any school,
childcare facility or other building used for education or recreational
programs for persons under the age of eighteen (18) years. Such restriction
shall not apply to such businesses in existence prior to the effective date
hereof; provided, that such businesses continue to provide the same service and
remove all tobacco advertising from the premises. This exemption shall apply to
any new owner at the same location providing the same service. (Ord. 2002-O-20,
3-19-2002)
6-5G-4: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING MINORS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products to any person under the age of
eighteen (18) years.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to distribute or
cause to be distributed to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years,
without charge or at nominal cost, any tobacco product.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver any smokeless tobacco product to any person under
the age of eighteen (18) years.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to distribute or
cause to be distributed to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years,
without charge or at nominal cost, any smokeless tobacco product.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For any person, including a licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to engage, employ
or permit any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products
in any licensed premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â For any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase
tobacco products or to misrepresent his/her identity or age or to use or
display any false, forged or altered identification for the purpose of
purchasing tobacco products.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products to any person without performing an
identification check to determine that the sale or delivery of tobacco products
is not permitted to that person by reason of age. The age shall only be
ascertained from a valid driver's license, Illinois identification card,
military identification card, or other identification card issued by a federal,
state or local government agency. In the event the identification was not
issued by an agency of the state of Illinois, the licensee shall institute any
other procedures which are necessary to ensure that the person is of
appropriate age, which procedure, at a minimum, shall include the presentation
of a second identification card.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â For any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age to
possess any tobacco products; provided, that the possession of tobacco by a
person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age under the direct supervision
of a parent or guardian of such minor in the privacy of the parent's or
guardian's home shall not be prohibited hereunder. In addition to any other
penalty for violation hereof, all tobacco products found in the possession of
any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age in violation hereof
shall be confiscated and destroyed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to fail to post and
maintain signs on the premises and as required in this subsection A9, informing
the public of the age restrictions provided for herein at or near every display
of tobacco products and on or upon every cigarette vending machine which offers
tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall
state: "THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW". The text of such sign shall be in red letters on a white
background; said letters to be at least one inch (1") high.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. In addition to any other penalty, a
licensee convicted of violating any provision of this section may be subject to
having his/her license revoked, suspended or not renewed by the mayor. (Ord.
2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)
6-5G-5: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products to any person without having
obtained a license from the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â For any person, including a licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell or offer
for sale, give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving
away or delivering tobacco products by use of a cigarette vending machine. Such
cigarette vending machines located in the following areas are exempt from this
provision:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Factories, businesses, offices, private clubs, and other places
not open to the general public.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Places to which minors under the age of eighteen (18) years of
age are not permitted access.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Places where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on the
premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Places where the vending machine is under the direct supervision
of the owner of the establishment or an employee over eighteen (18) years of
age. The sale of tobacco products from a vending machine under direct
supervision of the owner or an employee of the establishment is considered a
sale of tobacco products by that person. As used in this article, "direct
supervision" means that the owner or employee has an unimpeded line of sight to
the vending machine.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Places where the cigarette vending machine can only be operated
by the owner or an employee over the age of eighteen (18) years, either
directly or through a remote control device, if the device is unaccessible to
all customers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â For any person, including a licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, or any person in
the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting, or advertising
tobacco products, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of the person, in the course of such licensee's or person's business,
to distribute, give away, or deliver tobacco products free of charge to any
person on any sidewalk, street, road, right of way, park, playground, public
property, or other property owned by the city, any school district, any park
district or any public library.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to fail to post and
maintain signs on the premises and as required in this subsection A4, informing
the public, as provided herein, in plain view on or upon every cigarette
vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be
plainly visible and shall state: "SURGEON GENERAL'S WARNING: SMOKING BY
PREGNANT WOMEN MAY RESULT IN FETAL INJURY, PREMATURE BIRTH, AND LOW BIRTH
WEIGHT". The text of such sign shall be in red letters on a white background;
said letters to be at least one-half inch (1/2") high.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to fail to post and
maintain signs on the premises and as required in this subsection A5, informing
the public, as provided herein, in plain view at or near every display of
tobacco products. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
"SURGEON GENERAL'S WARNING: SMOKING BY PREGNANT WOMEN MAY RESULT IN FETAL
INJURY, PREMATURE BIRTH, AND LOW BIRTH WEIGHT". This subsection A5 does not
apply to sales of cigarettes through cigarette vending machines to which
subsection A4 of this section applies. The text of such signs shall be in red
letters on a white background; said letters to be at least one-half inch (1/2")
high.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A separate offense shall he deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. In addition to any other penalty, a
licensee convicted of violating any provision of this section may be subject to
having his/her license revoked, suspended or not renewed by the mayor. (Ord.
2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)
6-5G-6: TOBACCO ACCESSORIES AND SMOKING HERBS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, barter,
exchange, deliver, or give away, or cause or permit or procure to be sold,
bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away, tobacco accessories or smoking
herbs to any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, barter,
exchange, deliver, or give away, or otherwise furnish a bidi cigarette to
another person, nor shall a person cause or permit or procure a bidi cigarette
to be sold, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away to another person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, barter,
exchange, deliver, or give away, or cause or permit or procure to be sold,
bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away, tobacco accessories or cigarette
paper, or cause, permit or procure tobacco accessories or cigarette paper to be
sold, offered, bartered, exchanged, delivered or given away except from
premises or an establishment where other tobacco products are sold. (Ord. 2002-
O-20, 3-19-2002)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to offer, sell,
barter, exchange, deliver, or give away tobacco accessories or cigarette paper
or cause, permit, or procure tobacco accessories or cigarette paper to be sold,
offered, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away by use of coin operated
machines or devices. For purposes of this subsection A4, "cigarette paper"
shall not include any paper that is incorporated into a product which a tax
stamp must be affixed under the cigarette tax act 1  or the cigarette use tax
act 2 . (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-2002; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase
tobacco accessories or smoking herbs or to misrepresent his/her identity or age
or to use or display any false, forged or altered identification for the
purpose of purchasing tobacco accessories or smoking herbs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco accessories or smoking herbs to any person
without performing an identification check to determine that the sale or
delivery of tobacco accessories or smoking herbs is not permitted to that
person by reason of age. The age shall only be ascertained from a valid
driver's license, Illinois identification card, military identification card,
or other identification card issued by a federal, state or local governmental
agency. In the event the identification was not issued by an agency of the
state of Illinois, the licensee shall institute any other procedures which are
necessary to ensure that the person is of appropriate age, which procedure, at
a minimum, shall include the presentation of a second identification card.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â For any person, including any licensee, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, operating a place
of business where tobacco accessories and smoking herbs are sold or offered for
sale, to fail to post and maintain signs on the premises and as required in
this subsection A7, informing the public as provided herein, in plain view at
or near every display of such products. Each such sign shall be plainly visible
and shall state: "SALE OF TOBACCO ACCESSORIES AND SMOKING HERBS TO PERSONS
UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A
SALE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW". The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a
white background; said letters to be at least one- half inch (1/2") high.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. In addition to any other penalty, a
licensee convicted of violating any provision of this section may be subject to
having his/her license revoked, suspended or not renewed by the mayor. (Ord.
2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)

6-5G-7: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Administration And Enforcement Official: The mayor or his designee is
charged with the administration of tobacco sales licenses.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Inspections:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The inspection of all places where tobacco products are licensed to
be sold within the city may be conducted by the mayor or his designee or any
other enforcement officer of the city. The city, through its officers, agents
and employees, shall have the right to enter at all times any establishment,
place or building in which any license as described herein has been issued for
the purpose of inspecting the premises for compliance with all requirements of
this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Neither the chief of police nor the city, nor their officers, agents
or employees, shall be liable to any person, partnership, corporation, firm or
association for failure to conduct the inspections required under this article.
Further, the failure of the chief of police or city, or their officers, agents
or employees, to comply with the inspection requirements of this article shall
not affect the required license fee nor the validity of the license issued
hereunder.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Fine In Lieu:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Suspension Or Revocation: Any license issued hereunder shall be
subject to revocation or suspension for just cause by the mayor, if he
determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions hereof. Any
person making application under this article shall be deemed to recognize and
acknowledge that said license may be revoked pursuant to the terms of this
article, including the violation of any of the terms of this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Fine: In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, the mayor
may, instead, levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall not exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day on which a
violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Agreement Or Hearing Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee
shall be fined except by a written agreement entered into with the licensee, or
after a hearing by the mayor with a written notice of not less than seven (7)
days to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend
against the charges contained in such notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The mayor shall, within a reasonable time after such hearing, if
he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or
suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such
determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period
of the suspension or that the license has been revoked, and serve a copy of
such order upon the licensee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Payment Of Fines: Fines shall be paid to the city within the time
designated by the mayor, but not later than thirty (30) days of said decision.
Failure to pay said fine in a timely manner is a violation of this article and
shall be cause for license suspension or revocation or the levy of a fine.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Hearing Costs: Any licensee determined by the mayor to have violated
any of the provisions of this article shall pay to the city the costs of the
hearing before the mayor on such violation. The mayor shall determine the costs
incurred by the city for said hearing, including, but not limited to, court
reporter fees, the costs of all transcripts or records, attorney fees, the
costs of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous
expenses incurred by the city, or such lesser sum as the mayor may allow. The
licensee shall pay said costs to the city within the time designated by the
mayor, but not later than thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the
mayor. Failure to pay said costs in a timely manner is a violation of this
article and shall be cause for license suspension or revocation or the levy of
a fine.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Time Period Of Revocation: When any license shall have been revoked
for any cause, no license shall be granted to said licensee for the period of
six (6) months thereafter for selling "tobacco products", as defined in section
6-5G-1 of this article, in the premises described in such revoked license.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Responsibility For Violations: Every act or omission of whatsoever
nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this article by any
officer, director, a manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall
be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee, and such licensee shall be
punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or
omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-2002)
6-5G-8: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, or corporation, or employee of same,
violating any provision of this article shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity
or corporation for violation of the provisions of this article shall not
release such person from paying any fee due and unpaid at the time of such
conviction, nor shall payment of any fee prevent prosecution for violation of
any of the provisions of this article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The amount of any fee due hereunder shall be deemed a debt to the city.
An action may be commenced in the name of the city in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent fee. All unpaid fees shall be
deemed delinquent after they are due and payable.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 2002-O-20, 3-19-
2002)
CHAPTER 6
SOCIAL HOSTING RESPONSIBILITIES AND REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
6-6-1: Definitions
6-6-2: Prohibited Gatherings
6-6-3: Exceptions
6-6-4: Penalties
6-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the
purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in
this section, except when the context otherwise requires and except where
another definition set forth in another section of this chapter and applicable
to that section or a designated part thereof is applicable:
ALCOHOL: Ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, whiskey,
rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits including dilutions and
mixtures thereof from whatever source or by whatever process produced.
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: Alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and every liquid or
solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine, beer, and which contains one-half of
one percent or more of alcohol by volume and which is fit for beverage purposes
either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined with other substances.
CONVEYANCE: Any vehicle, trailer, or watercraft or container operated for the
transportation of persons or property.
GATHERING: Any group of three (3) or more persons who have assembled or
gathered together for a social occasion or other activity.
HOST: To aid, conduct, allow, entertain, organize, supervise, control, or
permit a gathering.
ILLICIT DRUGS: Any drug, substance, or compound prohibited by law, including
drugs prescribed by a physician that are in the possession of or used by
someone other than the person to whom the drug was prescribed.
PARENT: Any person having legal custody of a juvenile as natural, adoptive, or
stepparent, as a legal guardian, as a person to whom legal custody has been
given by order of the court, or any other person over twenty one (21) years of
age who is in loco parentis of a minor.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or
any other legal entity.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any "public place" including, without limitation, streets,
highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office
buildings, transport facilities, parks, businesses, or parking lots.
REASONABLE STEPS: Controlling access to alcoholic beverages at a gathering,
controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages present at the gathering,
verifying the age of persons attending the gathering by inspecting drivers'
licenses or other government issued identification cards to ensure that minors
do not consume alcoholic beverages while at the gathering, supervising the
activities of minors at the gathering, and calling for police assistance in the
event underage persons are in possession of alcohol at the gathering or
advising law enforcement in advance of departing one's residence that such
person will be away and no underage person is authorized to be present and
consume alcohol at such person's residence.
RELIGIOUS CEREMONY: The possession, consumption, and dispensation of alcohol or
an alcoholic beverage for the purpose of conducting any bona fide rites or
religious ceremony.
RESIDENCE OR PREMISES: Any home, yard, field, land, apartment, condominium,
hotel or motel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall or meeting room, park,
or any other place of assembly, public or private, whether occupied on a
temporary or permanent basis, whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically
for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or
used with or without permission or compensation.
RESPONSE COSTS: The costs associated with responses by law enforcement, fire,
and other emergency response providers to a gathering including, but not
limited to: a) salaries and benefits of law enforcement, code enforcement,
fire, or other emergency response personnel for the amount of time spent
responding to, remaining at, or otherwise dealing with a gathering, and the
administrative costs attributable to such response(s); b) the cost of any
medical treatment for any law enforcement, code enforcement, fire, or other
emergency response personnel injured while responding to, remaining at, or
leaving the scene of a gathering; c) the cost of repairing any city equipment
or property damaged, and the cost of the use of any such equipment, in
responding to, remaining at, or leaving the scene of a gathering.
RESPONSIBLE PERSON: Any person which hosts a gathering or having custody or
control of private property where a gathering occurs.
UNDERAGE PERSON: Any individual less than twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord.
2009-O-45, 12-15-2009)
6-6-2: PROHIBITED GATHERINGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â 1Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person to host, permit, allow, or fail to
take reasonable steps to prevent a gathering at any residence or premises, or
on any other property whether private or public, or in any conveyance, over
which that person has control or a reasonable opportunity for control where:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Illicit drugs are present, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Alcoholic beverages are present,
when that person knows or reasonably should know that an underage person will
or does consume or possess any illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A person is responsible for violating this chapter if that person
intentionally aids, advises, hires, counsels, conspires with, or solicits
another person to commit a violation of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A person is responsible for violating this chapter if that person
knows or should have known about the committing of a prohibited act and failed
to take reasonable steps to prevent the prohibited act.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any responsible person to fail to take reasonable
steps to prevent possession or consumption of illicit drugs by any person, or
alcoholic beverages by an underage person at any such gathering. A responsible
person does not have to be present to be in violation of this chapter. (Ord.
2009-O-45, 12-15-2009)
6-6-3: EXCEPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A responsible person shall not be in violation of this chapter if such
responsible person seeks assistance from the police department or other law
enforcement agency to remove any individual who refuses to abide by the
responsible person's performance of the duties imposed by this chapter or
terminates the gathering because illicit drugs are present or the responsible
person has been unable to prevent underage persons from consuming illicit
drugs, alcohol, or alcoholic beverages despite having taken all reasonable
steps to do so.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â This chapter does not apply to conduct involving the use of alcoholic
beverages that occurs at a religious ceremony or that is exclusively between an
underage person and his or her parent, as permitted by Illinois state law.
(Ord. 2009-O-45, 12-15-2009)
6-6-4: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2009-O-45, 12-15-2009)

Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any shotgun with a revolving cylinder.

MUZZLE COMPENSATOR: A device attached to the muzzle of a weapon that utilizes
escaping gas to control muzzle movement. (Ord. 13-O-42, 6-18-2013)
6-7-2: ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY MAGAZINES; POSSESSION AND SALE
PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall manufacture, sell, offer or display for sale, give,
lend, transfer ownership of, acquire or possess any assault weapon or large
capacity magazine. This subsection shall not apply to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The sale or transfer to, or possession by any officer, agent, or
employee of the city of Highwood or any other municipality or state or of the
United States, members of the armed forces of the United States; or the
organized militia of this or any other state; or peace officers to the extent
that any such person named in this subsection is otherwise authorized to
acquire or possess an assault weapon and/or large capacity magazine and does so
while acting within the scope of his or her duties;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Transportation of assault weapons or large capacity magazine if such
weapons are broken down and in a nonfunctioning state and are not immediately
accessible to any person.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any assault weapon or large capacity magazine possessed, sold or
transferred in violation of subsection A of this section is hereby declared to
be contraband and shall be seized and disposed of in accordance with the
provisions of section
6-7-3 of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person found in violation of this section shall be sentenced to not
more than six (6) months' imprisonment or fined not less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any person who, prior to the effective date hereof, was legally in
possession of an assault weapon or large capacity magazine prohibited by this
section shall have ninety (90) days from the effective date hereof to do any of
the following without being subject to prosecution hereunder:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To remove the assault weapon or large capacity magazine from within
the limits of the city of Highwood; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â To modify the assault weapon or large capacity magazine either to
render it permanently inoperable or to permanently make it a device no longer
defined as an assault weapon or large capacity magazine; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â To surrender the assault weapon or large capacity magazine to the
chief of police or his designee for disposal as provided below. (Ord. 13-O-42,
6-18-2013)
6-7-3: DESTRUCTION OF WEAPONS CONFISCATED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whenever any firearm or large capacity magazine is surrendered or
confiscated pursuant to the terms of this chapter, the chief of police shall
ascertain whether such firearm is needed as evidence in any matter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If such firearm or large capacity magazine is not required for evidence
it shall be destroyed at the direction of the chief of police. A record of the
date and method of destruction and inventory of the firearm or large capacity
magazine so destroyed shall be maintained. (Ord. 13-O-42, 6-18-2013)
CHAPTER 8
ASSISTED LIVING FACILITIES
SECTION:
6-8-1: Definitions
6-8-2: License Required
6-8-3: License Eligibility
6-8-4: Renewals
6-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "Assisted Living Facility" as used in this chapter, shall mean a
"facility", as that term is defined in section 1-113 of the Illinois Nursing
Home Care Act, 210 Illinois Compiled Statutes 45/1-113, as may be amended.
(Ord. 20-O-02, 1-7-2020)
6-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person or entity may operate an Assisted Living Facility within the City,
except upon receipt of an assisted living facility license issued by the City
Manager pursuant to this chapter. All assisted living facility licenses will be
for a term of one year. (Ord. 20-O-02, 1-7-2020)
6-8-3: LICENSE ELIGIBILITY:
An applicant for an assisted living facility license must submit a properly
completed application to the City Clerk, on a form to be provided by the City,
which application must include the payment of a non-refundable assisted living
facility license registration fee, in the amount set forth in the Annual Fee
Resolution. (Ord. 20-O-02, 1-7-2020)
6-8-4: RENEWALS:
For all applications for the renewal of an assisted living facility license,
for an Assisted Living Facility to which the City received a quantity of
requests for the provision of emergency medical services greater than the
number of beds in such Assisted Living Facility, the applicant must also pay an
Assisted Living Facility Impact Fee of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to
offset the costs incurred by the City's emergency services infrastructure
caused by the high frequency of calls for service and cause at least one
employee of the Assisted Living Facility charged with the responsibility of
managing and overseeing the facility's personnel, to attend an emergency
medical services training class, completed within three (3) months of license
renewal, to be conducted by representatives of the Fire Department providing
service to the community. (Ord. 20-O-02, 1-7-2020)

7-1-2: STATE VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and
sections of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100
et seq., as amended, are hereby adopted by the city. Any and all violations
thereof shall be considered violations of this title, and each such violation
shall subject the violator thereof to penalty provisions under this title if
proceeded hereunder. (2009 Code)

Provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101 et seq., shall apply.
(2009 Code)
7-1-4: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Application Of Provisions: The provisions of this title applicable to
the drivers of vehicles upon the highways shall apply to the drivers of all
vehicles owned or operated by the United States, the state of Illinois or any
county, city, town, district or any other political subdivision of the state,
except as provided in this section and subject to such specific exceptions as
set forth in this title with references to authorized emergency vehicles.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Authorized Emergency Vehicles:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an
emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the
law, or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may
exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the
conditions of this subsection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this title.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after
slowing down as may be required and necessary for safe operations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger
life or property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning
in specified directions.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The exceptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle,
other than a police vehicle, shall apply only when the vehicle is making use of
either an audible signal when in motion or visual signals meeting the
requirements of this title.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â This subsection does not relieve the driver of an authorized
emergency vehicle from the duty of driving with due regard for the safety of
all persons, nor does this subsection protect the driver from the consequences
of his reckless disregard for the safety of others.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Public Works Vehicles: The provisions of this title do not apply to
persons, teams, motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in
work upon the surface of the highway, but apply to such persons and vehicles
when traveling to or from such work. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-1975)

7-1-8: TRANSPORTING ALCOHOL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Restrictions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no driver may
transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor within the passenger
area of any motor vehicle upon a highway in the state except in the original
container and with the seal unbroken.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no passenger may
carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any
motor vehicle upon a highway in the state except in the original container and
with the seal unbroken.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exemptions: This section shall not apply to the passengers in a
limousine when it is being used for purposes for which a limousine is
ordinarily used, the passengers on a chartered bus when it is being used for
purposes for which chartered buses are ordinarily used, or on a "motor home or
minimotor home", as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-145.01.
However, the driver of any such vehicle is prohibited from consuming or having
any alcoholic liquor in or about the driver's area. Any evidence of alcoholic
consumption by the driver shall be prima facie evidence of such driver's
failure to obey this section. For the purposes of this section, a "limousine"
is a motor vehicle of the first division with the passenger compartment
enclosed by a partition or dividing window used in the for hire transportation
of passengers and operated by an individual in possession of a valid Illinois
driver's license of the appropriate classification pursuant to 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-104. The exemption applicable to chartered buses under
this subsection does not apply to any chartered bus being used for school
purposes.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Penalties:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any driver who is convicted of violating subsection A1 of this
section for a second or subsequent time within one year of a similar conviction
shall be subject to suspension of driving privileges as provided in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-206, subsection (a), paragraph 23.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any driver who is less than twenty one (21) years of age at the date
of the offense and who is convicted of violating subsection A1 of this section
shall be subject to the loss of driving privileges as provided in 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-205, subsection (a), paragraph 13, and 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-206, subsection (a), paragraph 33. (Ord. 2001-O-20, 3-20-
2001)
7-1-9: DEPOSITING SNOW AND ICE ON PUBLIC WAYS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibitions: No person, firm or corporation removing snow or ice from

the same upon any street or public parking area, or upon any sidewalk or right
of way used or intended to be used for vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or upon
any adjoining property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Responsibility For Deposits: The owner and/or occupant of any private

receives the benefit of the removal of said snow and ice from the owner's or
occupant's private property shall also be deemed responsible for any violation
of subsection A of this section by any person, firm or corporation performing
snow and ice removal upon the property of said owner or occupant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Exemptions: The officers, agents, contractors and employees of the city
are hereby exempted from the provisions of this section when performed in
furtherance of municipal purposes.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of
this section may avail themselves of the out of court settlement procedures
pursuant to section
7-5-19-2 of this title, notwithstanding any other provision of this section.
The provisions of section
7-5-19-2 of this title shall be applicable to persons, firms or corporations
violating this section. (Ord. 97-O-41, 12-2-1997)
