7-2-2: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC LAWS AND POLICE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Obedience To Traffic Laws: It is unlawful and, unless otherwise
declared in this title with respect to particular offenses, it is an ordinance
violation for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act
required in this title.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Obedience To Police: No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply
with any lawful order or direction of any police officer invested by law with
authority to direct, control, or regulate traffic. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-1975)
7-2-3: FLEEING AND ELUDING POLICE:
Any driver or operator of a motor vehicle who, having been given a visual or
audible signal by a peace officer directing such driver or operator to bring
his vehicle to a stop, wilfully fails or refuses to obey such direction,
increases his speed, extinguishes his lights, or otherwise flees or attempts to
elude the officer, is guilty of fleeing and eluding a police officer. The
signal given by the peace officer may be by hand, voice, siren, or red light.
Provided, the officer giving such signal shall be in police uniform, and if
driving a vehicle, such vehicle shall be marked showing it to be an official
police vehicle. (Ord. 2001-O-20, 3-20-2001)
7-2-4: VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT 1 :
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
Â Â Â BUSINESS DAY: Any day in which the office of the city clerk of the city of
Highwood is open to the public for a minimum of seven (7) hours.
Â Â Â MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled including, but not
limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters.
Â Â Â OWNER OF RECORD: The record title holder(s) of the vehicle.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Conduct Prohibited: A motor vehicle that is used in connection with any
of the following violations may be subject to seizure and impoundment by the
city, and the owner of record of said vehicle shall be liable to the city for
an administrative penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus any
applicable towing fees:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A motor vehicle that is knowingly used in the commission of any
felony criminal offense as described in Illinois criminal code of 1961, chapter
720 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A motor vehicle that is used in the commission of the offense of
driving under the influence of alcohol, drugs, and/or intoxicating compounds as
defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A motor vehicle that is used in the commission of the offense of
driving on a suspended or revoked license, as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-303, as a result of a conviction pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-501(a).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A motor vehicle that is used in the commission of the offense of
driving without a valid license or permit as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-101; except, that the vehicle of a driver whose license has been
expired for less than six (6) months, shall not be subject to seizure under
this subsection B2.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Seizure And Impoundment:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Whenever a police officer has reason to believe that a vehicle is
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this section, the police officer
shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility approved by the chief
of police, if the towing of the vehicle is supported by probable cause or if it
is in the furtherance of public safety or community caretaking functions.
Provided, in the event the vehicle is not otherwise needed for law enforcement
purposes, and a person authorized by the owner, licensed and insured, is
available to immediately remove the vehicle, the officer shall permit such
removal by such authorized person. This subsection C1 shall not apply if the
vehicle used in the violation was stolen at that time, and the theft was
reported to the appropriate police authorities within twenty four (24) hours
after the theft was discovered, or reasonably should have been discovered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The police officer shall notify any person identifying himself as
the owner of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the
vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the
fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's right to request an
administrative hearing to be conducted under this section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Administrative Hearing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Within five (5) business days after a vehicle is seized and
impounded pursuant to this section, the city shall notify, by certified mail,
the owner of record of the owner's right to request a hearing to challenge
whether a violation of this section has occurred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The owner of record seeking a hearing must file a written request
for a hearing with the chief of police or his designee no later than ten (10)
business days after notice was mailed. The hearing date must be no more than
fifteen (15) business days after a request for a hearing has been filed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing, and
hearsay evidence shall be admissible. If, after the hearing, the hearing
officer determines by a preponderance of evidence that the vehicle was used in
violation of this section, then the hearing officer shall enter an order
finding the owner of record of the vehicle civilly liable to the city for the
administrative penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If, after a hearing, the hearing officer does not determine by a
preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used in such a violation,
the hearing officer shall enter an order finding for the owner and for the
return of the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â If the owner of record requests a hearing but fails to appear at the
hearing or fails to request a hearing in a timely manner, the owner of record
shall be deemed to have waived his or her right to a hearing, and the hearing
officer shall enter a default order in favor of the city in the amount of the
administrative penalty. However, if the owner of record pays such penalty and
the vehicle is returned to the owner, no default order need be entered if the
owner is informed of his or her right to a hearing and signs a written waiver,
in which case, an order of liability shall be deemed to have been made when the
city receives the written waiver.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Retention Of Impounded Vehicle: A penalty imposed pursuant to this
section shall constitute a debt due and owing the city. A vehicle impounded
pursuant to this section shall remain impounded until:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is paid to the city
and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing agent, in which case, the
owner of record shall be given possession of the vehicle;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is posted
with the police department and all applicable towing fees are paid to the
towing agent, at which time, the vehicle will be released to the owner of
record; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case, the vehicle shall be
disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned
vehicles.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Bond For Release: If a bond in the amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00) is posted with the police department, the impounded vehicle shall be
released to the owner of record. The owner of the vehicle shall still be liable
to the towing agent for any applicable towing fees. If a five hundred dollar
($500.00) penalty is imposed for violation of this section, the five hundred
dollar ($500.00) bond will be forfeited to the city; however, if a violation of
this section is not proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the five hundred
dollar ($500.00) bond will be returned to the person posting the bond. All bond
money posted pursuant to this section shall be held by the city until the
hearing officer issues a decision or, if there is a judicial review, until the
court issues its decision.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Unclaimed Vehicles: Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed within
thirty (30) days after the expiration of the time during which the owner of
record may seek judicial review of the city's action under this section, or the
time at which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the city, or the time a
final administrative decision is rendered against an owner of record who is in
default may be disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle as provided by law;
provided, however, that where proceedings have been instituted under state or
federal drug asset forfeiture laws, the subject vehicle may not be disposed of
by the city except as consistent with those proceedings. (Ord. 2008-O-29, 9-16-
2008)

7-2-5: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Penalty Amounts:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Unless otherwise provided in this title, any person, partnership,
firm, entity or corporation in violation of this title shall be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for each and every offense. Each day that such offense continues shall be
considered a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 2000-O-40, 7-18-2000)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The penalty for any person, partnership or corporation who violates
any provision of section
7-2-3 of this chapter or section
7-1-8 or
7-4-16 of this title shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
nor more than the maximum amount permitted by Illinois statute for each
offense. (Ord. 2000-O-40, 7-18-2000; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Attorney Fees: In addition to any penalty or fine levied under this
title, any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation found to be in
violation of this title shall pay any and all reasonable attorney fees incurred
by the city in the enforcement of this title.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Court Costs: Further, in the event the city deems it necessary to bring
any court action to enforce this title, there shall be assessed against any
person, partnership, firm or corporation found to be in violation of this
title, all reasonable costs, expenses and attorney fees incurred by the city in
bringing said action, in addition to the fines provided herein.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Other Sanctions: In addition to any penalty or fine levied under any
court disposition or adjudication for a violation of this title, the court
shall be authorized to consider any disposition authorized or permitted
pursuant to the applicable statutes of the state, including, but not limited
to, imposition of community service, court supervision, and/or restitution. The
imposition of a sentence of imprisonment shall not be authorized pursuant to
this section. A sentence of imprisonment shall be authorized only if
specifically referenced in the penalty section of the applicable ordinance, or
otherwise authorized pursuant to state statute due to the enactment of said
ordinance.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Towing Charges:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In the event of the towing, seizure or storage of any vehicle by the
city, whether incident to an arrest or in furtherance of the duties of the
city, unless alternate arrangements have been made with a tow provider or
storage facility, the owner of the vehicle shall pay to the city the greater of
the following amounts: (Ord. 2000-O-40, 7-18-2000)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Any costs charged to the city by said tow provider or storage
facility, plus an administrative fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code in order to obtain the release of said vehicle; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â If towed and/or stored by the city, the amounts provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The provisions of this subsection shall constitute a lien upon the
vehicle. (Ord. 2000-O-40, 7-18-2000; amd. 2009 Code)

7-4-13: TRUCK TRAFFIC:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibited On Designated Streets; Exceptions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Vehicles exceeding eight thousand (8,000) pounds' registered gross

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The prohibitions established in this subsection shall not apply to

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Vehicles making deliveries to or pick ups from property

subsection, unless said vehicle bears a state of Illinois vehicle license,
class S or over, or any comparable class license issued by any other state; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Vehicles operated on behalf of public utility companies for the

via streets designated as "no truck" streets pursuant to this subsection,
within the city; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â School buses; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Emergency vehicles when operating in the line of duty. (Ord.

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Trucks In Alleys: It shall be unlawful for any vehicle with a gross
weight in excess of six (6) tons to operate or park in any alley within the
city. (Ord. 77-O-9, 9-16-1977)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Tractors And Trailers: All road tractors operated in combination with a
trailer or semitrailer shall be prohibited from movement upon the streets of
the city unless the operator displays in the windshield of the road tractor a
temporary use permit as defined in subsection D of this section. This
prohibition shall not apply to emergency vehicles when operating in the line of
duty. (Ord. 90-O-9, 5-15-1990; amd. Ord. 2006-O-8, 3-7-2006)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Permit Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Temporary street use permits may be granted by the mayor, chief of
police or any member of the police department authorizing the movement on city
streets by any vehicle otherwise prohibited by this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Application for a temporary street use permit shall be made by the
owner or operator of the vehicle or vehicles which will be the subject of the
permit, or by the owner of any property within the city to or from which such
vehicles will be traveling, and shall include all information which the mayor
or chief of police shall, from time to time, deem appropriate but shall, in any
event, include at least the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Name and address of applicant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Name and address of the owner of the vehicle or vehicles which
will be the subject of the permit;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The state of Illinois or other state vehicle license number of
the subject vehicle or vehicles;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A specific description of the vehicle or vehicles and load to be
operated or moved and whether such permit is requested for a single trip or for
limited continuous operation and date or dates of such trip or limited
continuous operation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â The points of origin and destination of the subject vehicle or
vehicles;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Whether the vehicle or vehicles are being operated for hire; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â The route or routes over which the applicant desires to operate
the subject vehicle or vehicles.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The mayor, chief of police or any member of the police department
may issue such temporary street use permits upon determining that the proposed
street use is not inconsistent with traffic safety and maintenance of the
structural integrity of the city streets. Where a permit is issued, the issuing
officer may impose on such grant any conditions deemed appropriate to the
protection of the public safety and the structural integrity of all city
streets including, but not limited to, the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Description of the route or routes to be traveled.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Establishment of season, weather condition or time limitations on
such operation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Restriction on the size and type of loads which may be moved by
virtue of such permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Description of appropriate safety measures and methods of
securing loads.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â In no event shall the mayor, chief of police, or any member of the
police department issue a temporary street use permit for a period exceeding
fourteen (14) days.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â During the term of such permit, the person to whom such permit is
issued and the owner and operator of the vehicle covered by the permit shall be
responsible for keeping all city streets used by such vehicle free and clear of
all dirt, mud, obstructions and hazards resulting from such use and shall
repair such damage thereby caused as may be necessary to keep routes for which
a permit has been issued in a reasonable state of repair for normal and safe
use. At the termination of the period for which such permit was issued, such
persons shall be responsible for causing all streets over which the subject
vehicles traveled to be restored to their condition prior to such use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The issuing officer may, as a condition to the issuance of a
temporary street use permit, require any applicant to post a bond, in an amount
to be established by the mayor or chief of police and in a form satisfactory to
the city attorney, to guarantee the adequate repair and restoration of all
streets over which travel is authorized by such permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Any temporary street use permit granted pursuant to this subsection
may be revoked by the mayor or chief of police or any member of the police
department if the person to whom the permit has been issued, or any person
acting on his behalf, violates any of the terms of the permit, any terms of
this section, or the terms of any other applicable ordinance, or where the
safety of pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the structural integrity of city
streets so require. Any such revocation may be appealed to the mayor and city
council for final determination.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The granting of a temporary use permit shall be in the sole
discretion of the mayor or chief of police. Nothing in this subsection shall be
construed as granting to any person, firm, corporation or entity any right to
the issuance of such a temporary permit. (Ord. 90-O-9, 5-15-1990)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Fees for temporary street use permits issued pursuant to this
subsection shall be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 90-O-9, 5-15-1990; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Signs Posted: The department of streets shall cause signs to be posted
at all appropriate locations within the city bearing the universal "no truck"
legend and a legend similar to the following: "No Semitrailer Trucks - Special
Permit Required". (Ord. 90-O-9, 5-15-1990)

7-4-15: SKATEBOARDING IN BUSINESS DISTRICT PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a skateboard or ride upon a

other municipally owned or leased property within said zoning districts. (Ord.
98-O-46, 5-19-1998; amd. 2009 Code)
7-4-16: IMPROPER, DANGEROUS DRIVING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Reckless Driving: Any person who drives any vehicle with a wilful or
wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless
driving.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Negligent Driving: Any person who drives any vehicle in a careless or
negligent manner so as to unnecessarily endanger persons or property is guilty
of negligent driving.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Drag Racing: No person shall drag race within the city. "Drag racing"
means the act of two (2) or more individuals competing or racing on any street
or highway in the city in a situation in which one of the motor vehicles is
beside or to the rear of a motor vehicle operated by a competing driver, and
the one driver attempts to prevent the competing driver from passing or
overtaking him, either by acceleration or maneuver, or one or more individuals
competing in a race against time on any street or highway in the city. (Ord.
2001-O-20, 3-20-2001)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Driving Under The Influence Of Alcohol And/Or Drugs: Provisions of 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-500, 5/11-501 and all subparts thereof, as
amended from time to time, through and including 5/11-501.1 through 5/11-501.5
shall apply. (Ord. 2001-O-20, 3-20-2001; amd. 2009 Code)
7-4-17: SAFE CARRYING OF PASSENGERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definition: The term "vehicle", as used in this section, shall have the
meaning defined in the Illinois vehicle code, as amended, or as may be defined
in any successor statute.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Scope: The provisions of this section shall apply to all areas and
parts of vehicles, whether interior or exterior.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Prohibitions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No person or persons shall occupy a house trailer while it is being
moved upon a public street or highway.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No person or persons shall occupy any area or part of a vehicle
designed or intended for pulling or carrying of property, freight or cargo
while such vehicle is being moved upon a public street or highway.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No person or persons shall occupy any area or part of a vehicle not
designed or intended for the carrying of passengers while such vehicle is being
moved upon a public street or highway.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Approved Seating Areas: An area of a motor vehicle which is equipped
with a seat designed or intended for carrying of passengers and where required
by the Illinois vehicle code, as amended, seat safety belts shall be proper for
carrying of passengers under this section.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Violation Prohibited; Responsibility For Violation: No person shall
drive or move any vehicle upon a public street or highway while passengers
occupy any area in violation of this section. The driver of each vehicle shall
be responsible to assure compliance with all the provisions of this section
prior to commencing movement upon a public street or highway.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Prima Facie Proof: The fact that the number of passengers occupying a
vehicle exceeds the maximum number of passengers stated in the manufacturer's
specifications shall be prima facie evidence that one or more violations of
this section have occurred. (Ord. 92-O-24, 5-5-1992)
7-4-18: USE OF WIRELESS TELEPHONES AND ELECTRONIC DEVICES WHILE OPERATING A
MOTOR VEHICLE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following terms shall be
applicable:
Â Â Â  ELECTRONIC DEVICE: Any electronic device, including, but not limited to, a
wireless telephone, personal digital assistant, or a portable or mobile
computer while being used for the purpose of composing, reading, or sending an
electronic message, but does not include a global positioning system or
navigation system or a device that is physically electronically integrated into
the motor vehicle.
Â Â Â HANDS FREE DEVICE: An external device that connects to a mobile telephone
that allows the user to engage in a telephone call without touching the user's
mobile telephone.
Â Â Â USE OR USING: Talking or listening to another person, text messaging,
sending, reading or listening to an electronic message, or browsing the
internet.
Â Â Â WIRELESS TELEPHONE: A cellular, analog, wireless or digital telephone
capable of sending or receiving telephone messages without an access line for
service.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Use Of Wireless Telephones And Electronic Devices While Driving
Prohibited: Except as otherwise provided in subsection C of this section, no
person shall operate a motor vehicle while using any wireless telephone or
electronic device.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Exceptions: The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any person using a hands free device for voice communication,
provided that person does not touch the wireless telephone or electronic device
connected to such hands free device while operating or using the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any person using a wireless telephone or electronic device for
purposes of contacting or communicating with public safety or other emergency
service providers while driving a motor vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Any person using a wireless telephone or electronic device while
maintaining a motor vehicle in a parked position.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Any law enforcement officers and operators of emergency vehicles
when on duty and acting in their official capacities. (Ord. 13-O-28, 5-7-2013)

7-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
stated in this section. Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning
ascribed to it in other sections of this chapter or other ordinances of the
city, and if not defined in any other section or ordinance, shall have the
meaning ascribed in the Illinois vehicle code, as amended, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, unless used herein in a context that clearly requires
another definition.
ABANDONED: Factors which may be considered in ascertaining if a vehicle has
been abandoned include, but are not limited to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It does not have current valid state license plates (or a license
applied for sticker or temporary permit, in accordance with statute or the
rules and regulations of the Illinois secretary of state) displayed thereon; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Its condition; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The period during which it has not been moved; or
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Other circumstances indicating abandonment.
HAZARDOUS: Includes, but is not limited to, a vehicle:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In such a condition and such a position or location that it presents an
immediate danger to the health or welfare of members of the public; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â That presents a potential danger to pedestrians or operators of other
vehicles; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â That is parked in such a way as to block access to or use of a fire
hydrant or movement of any authorized emergency vehicle.
HIGHWAY: Shall include, but is not limited to, any publicly maintained off
street parking area.
INOPERABLE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any motor vehicle in view of the general public, whether on public or
private property, and from which, for a period of at least seven (7) days:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The engine, wheels, or other parts have been removed; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â On which the engine, wheels, or other parts have been altered,
damaged, or otherwise treated so that the vehicle is incapable of being driven
under its own motor power.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â "Inoperable" shall not include a motor vehicle:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â That has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under
its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations;
or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Kept within a building when not in use; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â That is an operable historic vehicle over twenty five (25) years of
age; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â On the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or
junking of motor vehicles; provided, that such place of business shall be
otherwise properly licensed and authorized by or pursuant to the ordinances of
the city of Highwood.
OWNER: In subsections 7-5-19-1C2, E, F and G of this chapter, the term "owner"
of a vehicle may also include, in addition thereto, another person legally
entitled to possession of the vehicle, upon satisfactory proof thereof.
THIS CHAPTER: Shall mean or refer to all the provisions of this title relating
to towing or removal of vehicles hereunder, including sections
7-5-1 through
7-5-19-6 of this chapter, inclusive.
UNLAWFUL: Includes, but is not limited to, a vehicle parked in violation of any
statute or ordinance that authorizes the vehicle to be towed, especially when
signs posted at the location in question indicate that vehicles may be subject
to towing. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
7-5-2: MANNER OF PARKING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Outside Business Or Residence District: Upon any highway outside a
business or residence district, no person shall stop, park or leave standing
any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the roadway when it is
practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of the
roadway, but in every event, an unobstructed width of the roadway opposite a
standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a
clear view of such stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of two
hundred feet (200') in each direction upon such highway. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-
1993)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Parallel Parking: Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a highway or
street where there is an adjacent curb shall be so stopped or parked with the
right hand wheels of such vehicle parallel with and within twelve inches (12")
of the right hand curb. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â One-Way Streets: Except when otherwise provided by ordinance, every
vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way street shall be so stopped or parked
parallel to the curb or edge of the street, in the direction of authorized
traffic movement, with its right hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the
right hand curb or edge of the street, or its left hand wheels within twelve
inches (12") of the left hand curb or edge of the roadway. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-
1993)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Stop Engine; Remove Key; Parking On Grade: No person driving or in
charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first
stopping the engine and removing the ignition key and, when standing upon any
perceptible grade, without effectively setting the brake and turning the front
wheels to the curb or side of the street.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Starting Parked Vehicle: No person shall start a vehicle which is
stopped, standing, or parked unless and until such movement can be made with
reasonable safety. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-1975)
7-5-3: OPENING VEHICLE DOORS:
No person shall open the door of a vehicle on the side available to moving
traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without
interfering with the movement of other traffic, nor shall any person leave a
door open on the side of a vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of
time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. (Ord. 75-O-15, 11-21-
1975)
7-5-4: NO PARKING PLACES; MOVING IMPROPERLY PARKED VEHICLES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except when, and only so long as temporarily necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a
police officer or official traffic control device, no person shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked adjacent to
the edge or curb of a street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â On a sidewalk.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Within an intersection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â On a crosswalk.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â On any railroad tracks.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â i.Â Â Â Upon residential property in locations other than driveway areas
and parking areas established in accordance with the applicable city
ordinances.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â j.Â Â Â Within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway
entrance to any abutting property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily
to pick up or discharge passengers:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â In front of a public or private driveway.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any stop sign,
yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â On any private property without the consent of the owner of the
property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â Within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to
leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the roadway for the
free movement of vehicular traffic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily, for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or
passengers:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â On any shoulder within the city, except that portion of a
shoulder cut back and improved for parking in accordance with a written permit
for the same pursuant to the ordinances of the city. Such permit may be issued
by the mayor of the city; provided, that the portion of the shoulder to be used
for parking shall be cut back and improved at the expense of the applicant, in
accordance with the standards and regulations approved by the city council.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful, or start
or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change, or
move the levers, brake, starting device, gears, or other mechanism of a parked
motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner
or driver of such vehicle, or attempt to do so. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-1993)

7-5-6: OVERNIGHT PARKING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibited Generally: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any
street in the city or any parking lot owned or operated by the city between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., local time. This
prohibition shall not apply to vehicles parked pursuant to section
7-5-14 of this chapter or vehicles parked pursuant to subsection C of this
section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Tow Away Zones: City parking lots are all hereby declared tow away
zones between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00)
A.M., local time. Any vehicle parked or left unattended in any such lot during
such hours in violation of this section shall be subject to immediate towing
and removal. In addition to any other costs and penalties applicable to such
violation pursuant to this title, no person (other than officers and agents of
the city) may gain access to or recover such vehicle until they shall have
first paid in full the towing fee, storage fee, and all other applicable fees
arising out of such towing charged by the entity making such tow, as authorized
by the city. This subsection shall only be effective where signs are
prominently posted at such location giving notice of the tow away zone.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Permit Parking On Lakeview Avenue: Parking between the hours of two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., local time shall be allowed
for passenger cars only, as defined by the Illinois vehicle code, on the west
side of Lakeview Avenue from Webster Avenue to Clay Avenue, provided that the
vehicle displays a valid parking sticker, decal, tab or permit which has been
purchased from the city of Highwood specifically allowing overnight parking for
the vehicle and is properly and plainly displayed upon the vehicle. Display of
such a valid overnight parking sticker, decal, tab or permit shall permit
parking on the above designated street area between the hours of two o'clock
(2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., local time. A total of twenty four
(24) permits shall be available per quarter solely for residents with a maximum
of one permit available per residential unit. The cost of such a permit shall
be as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code and shall be applied for as follows: (Ord. 15-O-25, 5-19-
2015)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The application for overnight parking shall be in such a form as
prescribed by the city manager, and shall contain the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The applicant's name;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The applicant's address, home telephone number and work telephone
number;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The description of the vehicle and the license number and
Highwood city sticker number of the vehicle to which the permit is issued (a
valid Highwood city vehicle sticker must have been purchased for the vehicle
seeking an overnight parking permit);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Such other information as is reasonably required by the city
council and/or city manager in order to process such application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â In the event the application is granted, the city manager, or other
officer or employee designated by the city council, shall issue to the
successful applicant, an overnight parking sticker, decal, tag or permit, or
such other identification as is reasonably required to identify the granting of
the application for overnight parking on the designated street. However, the
permit shall not be granted until the applicant has paid in full the required
quarterly annual fee for such permit. (Ord. 14-O-28, 9-2-2014)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The permit and parking privileges may be rescinded by the city
council, or any municipal officer or employee designated by the city council,
with forty eight (48) hours' notice delivered to the applicant. However, in the
event the permit is rescinded, there shall be refunded to the applicant, a pro
rata share of the funds paid by the applicant. (Ord. 14-O-28, 9-2-2014; amd.
Ord. 15-O-24, 5-19-2015)
7-5-7: PARKING ON PARKWAYS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definition: For purposes of this section, the "parkway" is that portion
of real property lying between property owned by any entity other than the city
and the nearest curb line or lateral line of any improved road, street, or
alley within the city which is designed or intended for vehicular traffic.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Residential Districts: Except when, and only so long as temporarily
necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or
the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no
person shall stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except
momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers, upon any portion of a parkway
(whether or not said parkway is paved or improved with a driveway or approach)
within any residential district within the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All Other Districts: In all other districts, other than the residential
districts, parking on parkways within the city is prohibited except where the
owner of the abutting property has secured a permit and built a parking space
thereon of concrete not less than five inches (5") in thickness, or an asphalt
surface upon a base not less than six inches (6") in thickness, and dimensions
of not less than nine feet (9') wide and twenty feet (20') long for each car.
No permits to construct a parkway parking space shall be granted in a zoned
residential district. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-1993)
7-5-8: PARKING ON UNPAVED SURFACES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any privately owned
property or premises within any zoning district within the city, whether
occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers, if the
portion of the privately owned property or premises where the vehicle is parked
has not been paved with a previously permitted gravel lot/driveway, bituminous
or concrete pavement, cement paver bricks, or a similar hard, all weather,
durable and dustless surface, approved for the parking of vehicles and meeting
applicable ordinance requirements for the construction and maintenance of
parking areas.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Neither any person in possession or control of any property or premises
nor any owner or operator of any property or premises shall permit, suffer or
allow any person to stand or park a vehicle upon any privately owned property
or premises within any zoning district within the city, whether occupied or
not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers, if the portion of
the privately owned property where the vehicle is parked has not been paved
with a previously permitted gravel lot/driveway, bituminous or concrete
pavement, cement paver bricks, or a similar hard, all weather, durable and
dustless surface, approved for the parking of vehicles and meeting applicable
ordinance requirements for the construction and maintenance of parking areas.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In no event shall any person stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied
or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers, upon any
privately owned property consisting of grass, dirt, earth or mud. (Ord. 2003-O-
66, 11-18-2003)
7-5-9: PARKING IN FIRE LANES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person shall park or allow any vehicle to stand or be left stopped
in any place which is designated as a fire lane, whether on public or private
property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â This section shall be effective at all locations within the city where
signs giving notice of the same are posted and are visible.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In addition to any other penalties and/or fines levied under this
section, any vehicle found in a marked fire lane in violation of this section
shall be subject to immediate towing as a hazardous vehicle in accordance with
other sections of this chapter. (Ord. 95-O-33, 12-5-1995)
7-5-10: PARKING VEHICLES CONTAINING ORGANIC WASTE:
No vehicle shall be parked within any area within the city limits when the
vehicle contains any organic waste material, unless the organic waste material
is fully enclosed so than no odor emanates therefrom, or unless the area of
such vehicle which contains the organic material is fully enclosed so than no
odor may escape therefrom. "Organic waste material", as used in this section,
shall include, but be not limited to, landscape waste, garbage, trash, building
material waste, etc. This section shall not apply to garbage, refuse or
sanitary trucks while actually engaged in the performance of their duties.
(Ord. 98-O-70, 8-4-1998)
7-5-11: PARKING FOR SALE, WASHING OR REPAIRS:
No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway, public parking lot or
off street parking facility for the principal purpose of:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Displaying it for sale; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Washing, greasing, changing oil, or repairing such vehicle, except
repairs necessitated by an emergency. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-1993)

7-5-14: LEASED PARKING AREAS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The city council, or designee, is hereby authorized to designate up to
twenty five (25) parking spaces in the city owned lot adjacent to the Union
Pacific Railroad tracks as "leased spaces" to be leased by the city for parking
of vehicles on a quarter-annual basis.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any city council designee is hereby authorized to grant to selected
applicants a permit to park a single vehicle in any such space as is designated
for the applicant's use. No space shall be leased to an applicant unless such
applicant is a resident of the city or the applicant's business is located in
the city. Any vehicle to be parked in the leased space shall display a current
city vehicle sticker and shall be registered to applicant. Any city council
designee is hereby authorized to promulgate such reasonable rules and
regulations as may be necessary to regulate the leased spaces.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The applicant shall remove all snow and ice or any other foreign matter
from the space in leased area.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The applicant shall promptly notify the city if any signs or
designations indicating the leased space are removed or damaged so as to allow
the city to replace said signage.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Only one vehicle may be parked in each leased space at any given time.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The applicant shall cause a valid parking sticker, decal or tag, as
issued by the city, to be properly and plainly displayed upon the vehicle at
all times when the vehicle is within the leased space, along with a current
city vehicle sticker. Such vehicle shall be registered to the applicant.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Any applicant leasing a space pursuant to this subsection agrees and
acknowledges that the city shall not be held accountable in any manner for any
damage to the vehicle, any person or property or in any other manner whatsoever
due to the leasing of said space. By application for and/or acceptance of a
vehicle parking sticker, decal or tag, the applicant indemnifies and holds
harmless the city for any and all claims, causes of action or otherwise from
the applicant or any other person, including, but not limited to, reasonable
attorney fees arising out of the leasing, use and occupancy of said leased
space.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The application for a permit shall be in such a form as prescribed by
the mayor and the city clerk, but shall contain, at a minimum, the following
information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The applicant's name.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The applicant's address, home telephone number and work telephone
number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The description of the vehicle or vehicles and the license number
and city sticker number of the vehicles which are to occupy the designated
parking space.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Such other information as is reasonably required by the city council
and/or city clerk in order to process such application.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â In the event the application is granted, the city clerk or city council
designee shall issue to the applicant a parking sticker, decal or tag or such
other identification as is reasonably required to identify the granting of the
application for the use of the designated leased space. However, the permit
shall not be granted until the applicant has paid in full the required
quarterly-annual fee for such permit. (Ord. 98-O-83, 10-20-1998)
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â The applicant shall pay in advance the sum as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code as a condition precedent to the issuance of the permit.
Said fee will allow parking of one vehicle at a time in a single designated
space. The permit and parking privileges may be rescinded by the city council
or designee, with forty eight (48) hours' notice delivered to the applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â However, in the event the permit is rescinded, there shall be
refunded to the applicant a pro rata share of the funds paid by the applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Once the parking permit is rescinded, the applicant shall cause any
vehicles to be promptly removed from such leased parking area. In the event the
applicant fails to remove said vehicles, in addition to any other fine or
penalty provision of this chapter, the applicant shall pay any and all towing
charges and any and all reasonable attorney fees incurred by the city in
bringing any action to enforce the provisions of this subsection.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â The department of streets shall cause signs to be posted at the parking
area designating the area as "permit parking area" and further indicating such
area as a "tow away zone", as provided by Illinois statute.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Any vehicle parked or left standing in such leased spaces for any
period of time shall be deemed abandoned and subject to towing and removal as
provided by law and in accordance with section

located in areas owned or controlled by the city, including, but not limited

parking" by appropriate signage and/or pavement markings.

following provisions shall apply:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Before any person shall be permitted to remove such a vehicle,
the owner of such vehicle shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Furnish evidence of his or her identity, and ownership or
right to possession of the vehicle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Sign a receipt for the vehicle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Pay the standard towing and storage fees established by the
towing service operator and approved by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The chief of police is authorized to promulgate regulations as to
the documents or other proof necessary to establish these facts.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The owner must take possession of the vehicle and remove it
within twenty four (24) hours of the payment required in subsection E2a(3) of
this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Payment as required in subsection E2a(3) of this section does not
prevent a person from subsequently requesting a hearing pursuant to subsection
F of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any provision of this subsection to the contrary,
the owner may remove a vehicle without paying towing or storage fees upon
presentation of an order for release issued pursuant to subsection G3b(2)(B) of
this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Fees for towing and storage shall be posted in the city hall and
the Highwood police department at least fourteen (14) days before taking
effect, and said published fees shall remain available for inspection as long
as said fees are in effect.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Post-Tow Hearing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â When the city has authorized a vehicle to be removed, towed or
impounded, the owner of such vehicle may request a post-tow hearing to
determine the validity of such tow, removal or impoundment, and any towing or
storage charges.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Such request must be made within fifteen (15) days after the date of
mailing of notice or release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The request must be made in writing, and may, but need not be, on
forms furnished by the police department for such purpose.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â If such written request is not delivered to and actually received by
the Highwood police department within said fifteen (15) day period, the right
to a post-tow hearing under the provisions of this section shall be deemed
waived.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Hearing Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Scheduling Hearing: Upon proper request, the city shall schedule a
date, time and place for a hearing as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Within fifteen (15) days after the receipt of such request for a
hearing, except as provided in subsection G1b of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Where the vehicle has already been removed, towed, or impounded,
and has not been released, the owner may request an expedited hearing, which
shall be scheduled:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Within twenty four (24) hours after such request for such
hearing, excluding weekends and holidays.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Except, that if such request is made after three o'clock (3:
00) P.M., then a hearing shall be held on the second working day following the
request.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Procedures:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Upon receipt of a proper request for a hearing, but not less than
forty eight (48) hours before such hearing, the city shall notify the owner of
the date, time and place for such hearing by telephone, by mail, or in person
as the circumstances require. Upon receipt of a request for hearing pursuant to
subsections G1b of this section, the city shall, at the earliest possible time,
notify the owner of the date, time and place of such hearing, by telephone or
in person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Whenever a hearing is requested pursuant to subsection C2 or F of
this section, the chief of police or his designee shall serve as hearing
officer; provided, that no person shall serve as hearing officer who was
directly involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in an informal
manner and shall not be bound by the technical rules of evidence.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The issue to be determined at the hearing is whether lawful
authority exists for the towing and any storage of the vehicle. The person
demanding the hearing shall have the burden of establishing that he has a right
to possession of the vehicle. The city shall have the burden of establishing
that there was lawful authority for the towing and any storage of the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â After reviewing all relevant evidence presented at the hearing,
the hearing officer shall make his determinations based upon a preponderance of
the evidence. The hearing officer shall record this determination and the basis
for such determination in writing and provide the owner with a copy of such
written determination.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â The hearing officer shall not determine or adjudicate, and the
hearing will not be determinative of or adjudicate, any citation issued
relative to any vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â The city or the owner may contest the decision of the hearing
officer in any manner provided by law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â Whenever the hearing officer determines that the owner is
entitled to reimbursement by the city, the hearing officer shall transmit a
copy of his written determination to the city treasurer, who shall remit
payment of the money due to the owner within twenty eight (28) days after the
decision of the hearing officer, unless the city files a lawsuit to contest the
decision of the hearing officer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Determination:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Towing Justified: If the hearing officer determines that lawful
authority exists for removal, towing or impounding the vehicle, as the case may
be, or that the owner of the vehicle failed to request a hearing pursuant to
subsection C2 or F of this section, the written determination of the hearing
officer shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â For pre-tow hearings, direct that the vehicle be towed, with
any towing and storage costs to be imposed upon the owner thereof, in
accordance with subsection E2a(3) of this section. The owner of the vehicle
having had such a hearing may avoid the towing, removal or impoundment by
immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a proper, lawful
location and correcting any unlawful condition of the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â For post-tow hearings, indicate the amount due for towing and
storage of the vehicle. The hearing officer may determine that the owner
incurred additional storage charges for reasons not the fault of the owner and,
therefore, excuse some or all of said storage charges. The specific amount owed
by the owner and the specific amount of any charges excused shall be stated in
the written determination of the hearing officer. If a specific amount of any
charges is excused, then:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â The owner of a vehicle that has been released shall be
reimbursed by the city for the amount of any charges excused.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â The owner of a vehicle that is still impounded may obtain
the release of the vehicle upon payment of the amount owed; provided, that the
owner presents the written determination of the hearing officer to the towing
service operator at the time of such payment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Towing Not Justified: If the hearing officer determines that
lawful authority does not exist for towing, removing or impounding the vehicle,
or that the requirements for towing a vehicle had not been satisfied, the
written determination of the hearing officer shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â For pre-tow hearings, direct that the vehicle shall not be
towed. The owner the vehicle may display his copy of the written determination
inside the vehicle. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered
shall be towed by the city unless:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â The circumstances under which the decision was rendered
have changed; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â The procedures for towing similarly situated vehicles
pursuant to law or under this chapter are followed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â For post-tow hearings:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â If the vehicle has been released to the owner, note the
amount of towing and storage fees prepaid and advise the owner that such towing
and storage fees shall be reimbursed by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â If the vehicle is still impounded at the time of the
hearing, direct that the vehicle shall be released. This written determination
of the hearing officer shall be an order for release which, upon presentation
by the owner to the towing service operator, shall entitle said person to
release of the vehicle without payment of any towing or storage charges
theretofore incurred.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Disposition Of Towed Vehicle:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Compliance With Law: Any vehicle removed, towed or impounded
pursuant to the authority of the Highwood police department shall be disposed
of as provided by law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Sale Of Towed Vehicle:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â In the event that such disposition is not provided for by law,
the vehicle may be sold by the Highwood police department to the highest bidder
at either a private or public sale.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â No vehicle shall be sold under this subsection H2 until at least
thirty (30) days after the latter of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If a hearing is requested, the date of a hearing officer's
written determination; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If no hearing is requested, the expiration of the period for
requesting a vehicle tow hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Notice of any sale pursuant to this subsection H2 shall be
mailed:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â By certified or registered mail, return receipt requested.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â To the owner of the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â At his address as indicated in the most current registration
list of the secretary of state of the state in which the vehicle is registered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â At least thirty (30) days in advance of a sale.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Such notice shall also be published:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â At least twenty (20) days in advance. (Ord. 93-O-22, 8-3-
1993)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In a newspaper of general circulation in the city. (Ord. 93-
O-22, 8-3-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Vehicle Immobilization And Towing:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Authorization: The police department of the city is hereby
authorized to direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization for the
purpose of enforcing the parking regulations of the city. Any police officer of
the city is hereby authorized to cause the immobilization, by placement of a
restraint in such a manner as to prevent its operation, of any vehicle parked
upon any public street or way, or upon any other city owned property, that is
eligible for immobilization and that has been included on the vehicle
immobilization list pursuant to this subsection. The chief of police may
establish such rules and procedures not inconsistent with the terms of this
subsection to administer the city's immobilization program.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Eligibility For Immobilization: A vehicle shall be considered
eligible for immobilization when the registered owner of the vehicle has
accumulated five (5) or more citations, all of which are more than thirty (30)
days old, and for which the fines and penalties have not been paid in full,
issued against any vehicle registered to such owner charging that such vehicle
was in violation of the city's standing, parking, or compliance regulations.
Every such vehicle shall hereafter be referred to as an eligible vehicle. Any
eligible vehicle found upon any street or public place within the city may be
immobilized in place by use of a mechanical device for such purpose. Such
device may be called a "boot", and the use of the same may be called "booting".
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Notice Of Pending Immobilization: The police department shall cause
a notice of pending immobilization to be sent to the registered owner of any
eligible vehicle. The notice shall be sent by certified mail or registered
mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the registered owner of the
eligible vehicle recorded with the Illinois secretary of state, or if the
eligible vehicle bears a registration number of a state other than Illinois,
then at the address of the registered owner recorded in that state's registry
of motor vehicles. The notice of pending immobilization shall provide the
following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A description of the vehicle, including the make, model, year,
and color of the eligible vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The eligible vehicle's vehicle identification number, and the
number and state of the license plate displayed on the eligible vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The name and address of the registered owner of the eligible
vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The number and issue dates of the outstanding parking citations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â A statement that the registered owner's vehicle is subject to
immobilization pursuant to this subsection, unless the registered owner, within
ten (10) days of receipt of the pending immobilization notice:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Submits to the city payment for the full fine or penalty
amount due for each outstanding parking citation; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Requests a pre-immobilization hearing to contest the notice
of pending immobilization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Pre-Immobilization Hearing Procedures:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Request For Hearing: The registered owner of an eligible vehicle
may contest the validity of a notice of pending immobilization by delivering to
the chief of police, within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice of
pending immobilization, a written request for a pre-immobilization hearing. If
the registered owner of an eligible vehicle does not request a pre-
immobilization hearing pursuant to this subsection I4a within said ten (10) day
period, then the right to a pre-immobilization hearing shall be deemed waived.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Scheduling Of Hearing: The chief of police or his or her designee
shall schedule a pre-immobilization hearing within ten (10) days after receipt
of the written request and shall promptly notify the registered owner of the
eligible vehicle of the scheduled hearing date and time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Conduct Of Hearing: The pre-immobilization hearing may be
conducted either by the chief of police or by his or her designee. The
registered owner of the eligible vehicle must appear in person at the hearing
and, to invalidate the notice of pending immobilization, submit evidence that
conclusively demonstrates that the registered owner's vehicle is not an
eligible vehicle. Such evidence may include demonstration of any of the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The registered owner is not the owner or lessee of the
subject vehicle on the date or dates that the parking citations were issued; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The fines or penalties for the parking citations identified
in the notice of pending immobilization have been paid in full; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The registered owner has not accumulated five (5) or more
outstanding parking citations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Decision:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Based on the evidence presented by the registered owner, the
chief of police or his or her designee shall issue a written decision either:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â Affirming the validity of the notice of pending
immobilization and confirming that the subject vehicle is an eligible vehicle
subject to immobilization pursuant to this subsection; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â Revoking the notice of pending immobilization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A copy of the written decision shall be delivered to the
registered owner within forty eight (48) hours after the conclusion of the pre-
immobilization hearing. The decision of the chief of police or his or her
designee to affirm or revoke the notice of pending immobilization shall be
final.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Action If Affirmed: If the decision affirms the validity of the
pending immobilization notice, the decision shall be accompanied by a notice
that the registered owner has three (3) days to pay, or cause to be paid, all
outstanding parking citation fines and penalties, and that failure to do so
will subject the registered owner's vehicle to immediate immobilization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â No Determination Of Violations: A pre-immobilization hearing
shall not be determinative of, and shall not be used or construed to
adjudicate, any of the individual parking violation citations on which the
notice of pending immobilization was based, or any other violation of any city
ordinance relating to the eligible vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Vehicle Immobilization List: The chief of police or his or her
designee shall create, keep, and maintain a vehicle immobilization list. The
chief of police or his or her designee shall place on the vehicle
immobilization list the vehicle registration number of all eligible vehicles
for which the registered owner has: a) failed to respond to a notice of pending
immobilization within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice; or b) failed
to pay all outstanding parking citation fines and penalties within three (3)
days after receipt of the decision following a pre-immobilization hearing to
affirm the validity of a notice of pending immobilization. Any police officer
may, in a manner consistent with this subsection, immediately immobilize any
vehicle included on the vehicle immobilization list without further notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Immobilizing Restraint: When immobilizing an eligible vehicle
pursuant to the provisions of this subsection, the police department shall use
the "Denver boot" or other similar wheel locking restraint in such a manner as
to prevent operation of the vehicle. Every such vehicle so restrained shall
hereafter be referred to as an "immobilized vehicle".
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Unauthorized Activities: It shall be unlawful for any person to
relocate or to tow any immobilized vehicle except in accordance with the
provisions of this subsection. It shall also be unlawful for any person to
damage an immobilizing restraint or to remove or attempt to remove an
immobilizing restraint without authorization. Any person who violates any
provision of this subsection I7 shall be: (Ord. 2006-O-15, 4-18-2006)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Subject to a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation;
and (Ord. 2006-O-15, 4-18-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Pay all costs to repair or replace the immobilization restraint
damaged or destroyed by such person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Notice Of Immobilization: Upon immobilization of a vehicle, the
police officer present shall immediately cause to be placed upon such vehicle,
in a conspicuous manner, notice sufficient to warn any individual that such
vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move such vehicle might
result in damage to such vehicle and/or the boot device. A notice of
immobilization shall be immediately affixed to any eligible vehicle immobilized
pursuant to this subsection. The notice of immobilization shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â State that the eligible vehicle is immobilized, and that any
attempt to move the immobilized vehicle may result in damage to the vehicle.
(Ord. 2006-O-15, 4-18-2006)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â State that the unauthorized removal of or damage to the
immobilizing restraint is prohibited and punishable by a fine of not less than
seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each such violation. (Ord. 2006-O-15, 4-18-2006; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Provide information on how the registered owner may secure
release of the immobilizing restraint.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Provide information on how the registered owner may obtain a
post-immobilization hearing pursuant to this subsection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â State that if the registered owner fails to secure release of the
immobilizing restraint or to request a post-immobilization hearing within
twenty four (24) hours, the immobilizing restraint may be released by the city,
and the eligible vehicle may be towed and impounded.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Release Of Immobilizing Restraint: The registered owner of an
immobilized vehicle, or other person entitled to possession of such vehicle,
may secure the release of an immobilizing restraint by paying or causing to be
paid to the city the following fees and penalties:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â An immobilization fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â All parking citation fines and penalties issued against the
immobilized vehicle that remain outstanding, including specifically, but
without limitation, the parking citations identified in the notice of pending
immobilization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Towing And Impoundment Of Immobilized Vehicle: If the registered
owner of the immobilized vehicle or other authorized person does not secure the
release of the immobilizing restraint or request a post-immobilization hearing
within twenty four (24) hours of the immobilization, the police department
shall be authorized to cause such vehicle to be towed and impounded. If a
request for a post-immobilization hearing is received within this time, the
towing and impounding of the immobilized vehicle shall be deferred pending the
outcome of the post-immobilization hearing. The provisions set forth in
subsection E of this section regarding impounded vehicles parked illegally
shall apply fully to all immobilized vehicles impounded pursuant to this
subsection; provided, however, that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â In addition to the towing and storage charges imposed pursuant to
subsection E of this section, the fees and penalties specified in subsection I8
of this section shall be paid before the owner or person entitled to possession
of the impounded vehicle shall be permitted to repossess or secure the release
of such vehicle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Notification to be provided to the owner of the impounded vehicle
under subsection D of this section shall include a statement that the vehicle
was impounded pursuant to the provisions of this subsection, and that the
registered owner has a right to appeal the immobilization, towing, and
impoundment of such vehicle by requesting a post-immobilization hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Post-Immobilization Hearing Procedures:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Request For Hearing: The registered owner of an immobilized or
impounded vehicle shall have the right to contest the validity of the
immobilization and any subsequent immobilization, towing, or storage fees by
delivering a written request for a post- immobilization hearing to the chief of
police within five (5) days after the immobilization of the vehicle. If the
registered owner of an immobilized or impounded vehicle does not request a
post-immobilization hearing pursuant to this subsection I11a within said five
(5) day period, then the right to a post- immobilization hearing shall be
deemed waived.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Scheduling Of Hearing: The chief of police or his or her designee
shall schedule a post-immobilization hearing within three (3) days after
receipt of the written request, and shall promptly notify the registered owner
of the eligible vehicle of the scheduled hearing date and time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Conduct Of Hearing: The hearing may be conducted either by the
chief of police or by his or her designee. At the hearing, the registered owner
must appear in person and present evidence conclusively establishing that the
immobilization, towing, or impoundment of the registered owner's vehicle was
not authorized.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Decision: Based on the hearing record, the chief of police or his
or her designee shall issue a written decision: 1) affirming, in whole or in
part, the validity of the immobilization, towing, or impoundment of the
registered owner's vehicle; or 2) invalidating, in whole or in part, the
immobilization, towing, or impoundment of the registered owner's vehicle. A
copy of the decision shall be delivered to the registered owner of the subject
vehicle within forty eight (48) hours after the close of the postimmobilization
hearing. The decision of the chief of police or his or her designee shall be
final.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Action:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Invalidation: If the decision is to invalidate the
immobilization, towing, or impoundment, the chief of police or his or her
designee shall immediately release the immobilizing restraint if the vehicle
has not yet been towed, or release the vehicle if impounded, and remove its
state registration number from the vehicle immobilization list.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Affirmation: If the decision is to affirm the immobilization,
towing, or impoundment, the registered owner shall be so informed. If the
immobilized vehicle has not yet been towed, the registered owner shall also be
informed that the immobilization fee and all outstanding parking citation fines
and penalties must be paid in full within twenty four (24) hours after receipt
of the decision, and that failure to make such payment may result in the
immediate towing and impoundment of the registered owner's vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â No Determination Of Violations: A postimmobilization hearing
shall not be determinative of, and shall not be used or construed to
adjudicate, any of the individual parking citations on which the
immobilization, towing, or impoundment was based, or any other violation of any
city ordinance relating to the eligible vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â Removal From Vehicle Immobilization List: After payment in full of
all applicable fees, fines, and penalties specified in this subsection, the
state registration number of the eligible vehicle shall be removed immediately
from the vehicle immobilization list. (Ord. 2006-O-15, 4-18-2006)
