8-8-1: DEFINITION:
The term "special event", as used in this chapter, shall include the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any organized formation, procession, parade, or assembly of persons,
animals, vehicles, or any combination of one or more of the same, which will
travel together or with a common purpose upon any public street, road, highway,
alley, sidewalk, parking lot or other public way, and which will likely:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Present an unusual obstruction to the normal and ordinary use of or
passage of pedestrians and/or vehicles upon any part of such a public way; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Would require the reservation or substantial use of any city parks
or public ways; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Would conflict with other events for which permits have been issued;
or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any organized assemblage of more than fifty (50) persons which will
gather in any park or other public place for a common purpose or under the
direction or control of one or more responsible persons, agencies or other
entities; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any other organized activity or set of activities conducted by one or
more individuals, groups or other entities, for a common or collective use or
benefit, and which:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Will involve the use of any public building, park, way, or other
public facility or any part thereof; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â May reasonably be expected to involve the provision of city services
ancillary thereto; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â May reasonably be expected to have a direct effect upon public
property, use of or traffic flow upon any public sidewalk, street or other
public way or any part thereof, or public health or safety within any part of
the city; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â May reasonably be expected to have a direct effect upon or cause a
substantial use of any public property including parks or public ways. (Ord.
95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-2: INTERPRETATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A "special event", as defined in section
8-8-1 of this chapter, shall include, but shall not be limited to, parades,
processions, circuses, fairs, mass participation sports such as marathons and
running events, bicycle races or tours, and spectator sports such as football,
basketball and baseball games and golf tournaments.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A "special event", as defined in section
8-8-1 of this chapter, shall not include any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Funeral processions; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Sales held at residences that are subject to the Highwood house/
garage sale ordinance 1 , such as home, rummage or garage sales; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Use of the Highwood recreation center pursuant to a written lease
approved by the Highwood recreation board; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Any event sponsored and controlled by the city or any of its
departments; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Any procession or parade by the armed forces of the United States of
America, the military forces of the state of Illinois, or the police or fire
departments of the city of Highwood; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Use of the Highwood public library when approved by the library
board or a library director. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See title 4, chapter 12 of this code.
8-8-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person may conduct, organize, plan, promote, or otherwise hold or facilitate
any "special event", as defined in section
8-8-1 of this chapter, within any part of the city unless and until approval
for the same has been granted by the issuance of a permit for the holding of
such special event by the city hereunder. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995; amd. 2009
Code)
8-8-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Forms: The city clerk shall provide application forms to request
permits hereunder. Such application forms shall include all reasonable
information needed by each and every city department to evaluate all matters
within its area of responsibility.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Time Of Filing: The application form shall be submitted to the city
clerk at the city hall no later than sixty (60) days prior to the commencement
of the special event; except, that large scale events that require extensive
planning shall be submitted no less than six (6) months prior to the
commencement of the special event. Applications for small scale special events
which are not filed within the sixty (60) day deadline may be provisionally
accepted, subject to refusal if any city department does not have sufficient
time to process the application. Any application for a special event which,
because of its size or scope, requires more extensive planning than normal, may
be rejected if an insufficient time for advance planning is available for any
city department. No application shall be submitted more than thirteen (13)
months in advance. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Fees: Each application for a permit for a special event shall include
full payment of a filing fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code for each day on which the special event will take place or
continue. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Return Of Application: An application shall be considered incomplete
and may be returned without any action by the city if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The application is not fully completed or any requested information
is missing or incomplete; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Full payment of the required fee is not tendered with the
application; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The insurance documents required under this chapter are not complete
and attached. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-5: REVIEW OF APPLICATION; MODIFICATIONS; APPROVAL OR DENIAL OF PERMIT;
APPEALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Review Of Application: Once a fully complete application has been
filed, a copy thereof will be submitted to each city department which may be
affected for review and analysis. The applicant will then be contacted by the
city clerk or the appropriate city department, which will coordinate the city's
response to the proposed special event with the results of such review and
analysis. This shall include, but not be limited to, an estimate of all costs
that will be incurred by the city in any way connected or related to the
proposed special event, such as (but not limited to) for manpower, services,
equipment, and the like.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Modifications: The applicant may modify, add to, or delete from its
application as he may wish following such response from the city. The applicant
shall promptly notify the city clerk in writing when he has completed any
changes in his application and the application is in the final form that
applicant desires.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Review Of Application; Recommendations To Mayor: The application in
such final form shall then be reviewed by the appropriate city departments.
Such departments shall then make their final recommendations to the mayor with
respect to the application in its final form.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Approval Or Denial: The mayor shall then either approve or deny the
application for the special event. The city clerk shall promptly thereafter
notify the applicant, either by issuance of a permit pursuant to this chapter
or by notice of denial.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Contents And Conditions Of Permit:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any permit issued hereunder shall have all of the pertinent
information from the application made a part of the conditions and requirements
of the permit. The permit may be issued with any other or additional conditions
as the city may deem reasonable or necessary.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The permit shall be issued subject to the duty and obligation of the
applicant to maintain all information therein current with the city clerk,
including, but not limited to, address, telephone number, name of responsible
individual, etc.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Appeals: Any person aggrieved by a denial hereunder may appeal the same
to the city council. Such appeal shall be made in writing and shall be promptly
filed with the city clerk.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Posting Permit: A clearly legible copy of the city permit shall be
immediately available for display by all responsible persons during the special
event. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-6: INDEMNITY AND INSURANCE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nonliability Of City; Indemnification: No application hereunder shall
be complete unless the applicant has executed therein the prescribed portion
pursuant to which the applicant agrees to release, indemnify, defend, and hold
the city and all its officers, employees and agents harmless against any and
all claims, liabilities, suits, judgments, costs and expenses, including
attorney fees, arising out of or in consequence of any acts or omissions of the
applicant and, as may be the case, each of its directors, officers, employees
and agents in connection with the special event. Any application that is filed
with the city for a special event shall constitute such a release, hold
harmless and indemnification by the applicant. Any and all permits issued
hereunder shall likewise be subject to all such conditions.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Insurance Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The application shall not be complete, nor shall any permit be
issued hereunder unless and until the insurance requirements of this subsection
are satisfied.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The minimum amount of general public liability insurance required
for a special event shall be one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
occurrence.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The applicant shall provide the city with one or more certificates
evidencing the existence of insurance policies providing the applicant, and all
of its directors, officers, employees and agents, as the case may be, with
coverage equal to or exceeding that required in this subsection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All insurance certificates required hereunder shall provide that the
insurance will not be canceled or amended without thirty (30) days' prior
written notice to the city. The applicant shall name the city as additional
insured on each such general liability policy.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The applicant shall further maintain, at all times during the
special event or otherwise, all such insurance and other coverage as may be
required by law, such as, but not limited to, workers' compensation and
unemployment coverage. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-7: COSTS OF EVENT:
The city shall be promptly reimbursed for all costs arising as a result of, or
in any way relating to, any special event. Such costs shall include, but are
not limited to, payment to city employees for all time spent on the special
event, replacement of any supplies or materials used, all cleanup, repair or
replacement of any damage, etc. The applicant shall be fully responsible for
and shall promptly pay to the city all such amounts upon billing for the same.
The city may require an advance deposit of any reasonable sum or a bond prior
to the special event in order to guarantee such payment. Any such advance
deposit shall be refundable after deduction of any amounts due the city
pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-8: UTILITY SERVICE:
The applicant shall be responsible for and shall make all necessary
arrangements for any utility service that may be necessary or desirable, such
as, but not limited to, electricity, lighting, sound, telephone, water, sewer,
portable toilets, etc. The city shall not be made liable for any charges, costs
or expenses in connection therewith. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-9: PUBLIC SAFETY:
The applicant shall be responsible for and shall make all necessary
arrangements for public safety in connection with the special event, such as,
but not necessarily limited to, police protection, security, crowd control,
medical services (first aid, ambulance), fire protection, etc. The city shall
not be made liable for any charges, costs or expenses in connection therewith.
(Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-10: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS:
The acceptance of any application or issuance of any permit hereunder shall not
relieve the applicant or any other person from full compliance with all other
applicable federal, state and local laws, rules, regulations and ordinances,
including any permits which may be required by other ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-11: WAIVERS:
Any requirement of this chapter may be waived by the mayor or the city council
upon a satisfactory showing that the same would be in the public interest, that
such requirement is impossible or infeasible to obey, that such requirement is
unreasonable under the circumstances, that a waiver would not be contrary to
the spirit and intent of this chapter, and that such a waiver would not
unreasonably impact the public safety, health or welfare. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-
1995)
8-8-12: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The mayor and each city department head shall have the right, at any time, to
revoke the permit upon substantial violation of any of its terms. This
condition shall be clearly indicated on the face of the permit. Unless
circumstances require otherwise, the applicant shall be given an opportunity to
abate or correct the violation before revocation during the event itself. (Ord.
95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-13: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation in violation of
any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every
offense, and each day that such offense continues shall be considered a
separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995; amd. Ord. 99-O-09, 2-
16-1999)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In addition to any penalty or fine levied under this chapter, any
person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation in violation of any provision
of this chapter shall pay any and all reasonable attorney fees incurred by the
city in enforcing this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the event the city deems it necessary to bring any court action to
enforce this chapter, there shall be assessed against any person, partnership,
firm, entity, association or corporation violating this chapter all reasonable
costs, expenses and attorney fees incurred by the city in bringing said action,
in addition to the fines provided herein.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity
or corporation for violation of the provisions of this chapter shall not
release such person from paying any permit fee due and unpaid at the time of
such conviction, nor shall payment of any permit fee prevent criminal
prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The amount of any permit fee shall be deemed a debt to the city. An
action may be commenced in the name of the city in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent permit fee. All unpaid permit
fees shall be deemed delinquent thirty (30) days after they are due and
payable.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The city clerk may immediately revoke the permit of any person who
violates any of the terms of this chapter. Any person aggrieved by such
revocation may appeal the same to the city council.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 95-O-11, 5-2-1995)
8-8-14: SALE OF CONCESSIONS AT SPECIAL EVENTS HELD AT THE HIGHWOOD RECREATION
CENTER:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any vendor desiring to operate a concession stand for the sale of food
and/or beverage items in conjunction with a permitted special event held at the
Highwood Recreation Center shall require a permit to do so from the city of
Highwood. Applications for a concession permit shall be made on a form approved
by the city manager no less than fourteen (14) days in advance and shall
include full payment of the concession fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this code for each day on which the sale of concessions will take
place. Payment of this concession fee shall be in addition to any other fees
charged in conjunction with the special event or under other provisions of this
code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any permit issued hereunder where the applicant has indicated a desire
to operate a concession stand and has paid the concession fee shall include
language allowing for such sale of conditions and any conditions related to
said sale of concessions deemed reasonable by the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Permits shall be issued or denied in the sole discretion of the city
manager or mayor. (Ord. 14-O-08, 5-6-2014)

CHAPTER 1

9-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
CLARIFICATION OF WORD USAGE:
Â Â Â Shall; May: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissible.
CONSTRUCTION/IMPROVEMENT TERMS:
Â Â Â Curb Cock: A shutoff valve attached to a water service pipe from a water
main to a building installed near the curb, which may be operated by a valve
key to start or stop flow in the water supply lines of a building; also called
"curb stop".
Â Â Â Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by
others.
Â Â Â Service Box: A valve box used with corporation or curb cock.
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT:
Â Â Â Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection
agency.
Â Â Â Federal Act: The federal 1996 safe drinking water acts amendments.
IDENTIFICATION:
Â Â Â Consumer Or Customer: The owner, official custodian or person in control of
any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to the waterworks system.
Â Â Â Person: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any
individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association,
society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT:
Â Â Â City: The city of Highwood, Lake County, Illinois.
STATE GOVERNMENT:
Â Â Â Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
Â Â Â State Act: The Illinois anti-pollution bond act of 1970 1 .
Â Â Â State Loan: The state of Illinois participation in the financing of the
construction of waterworks system as provided for by the Illinois anti-
pollution bond act and for making such loans as filed with the secretary of
state of the state of Illinois.
TYPES OF CHARGES:
Â Â Â Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the
waterworks system.
Â Â Â Capital Improvement Charge: A charge levied on users to improve, extend or
reconstruct the waterworks system.
Â Â Â Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment
of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding.
Â Â Â Local Capital Cost Charge: Charges for costs other than the operation,
maintenance and replacement costs, i.e., debt service and capital improvement
costs.
Â Â Â Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the
works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were
designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
"replacement".
Â Â Â Useful Life: The estimated period during which the waterworks system will be
operated.
Â Â Â User Charge: A charge levied on users of the waterworks system for the cost
of operation, maintenance and replacement.
Â Â Â Water Fund: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received
in the operation of the waterworks system.
Â Â Â Water Service Charge: The charge per period of time established by the city
levied on users of the water facilities. The service charge shall be computed
as outlined in article A of this chapter.
WATER AND ITS CHARACTERISTICS:
Â Â Â Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of the concentration of water constituent. It
is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters (1,000 ml) of
water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to
which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water
analysis.
Â Â Â ppm: Parts per million by weight.
Â Â Â pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion
concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA "Division
Of Laboratories Manual Of Laboratory Methods". (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)

Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq.
9-1-2: CONNECTION TO SYSTEM; USE OF WELLS; TAP FEES AND COSTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Permit And Connection Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No connections with the waterworks system shall be made without a
permit issued by the city. All such connections shall be made by city employees
under the supervision of the superintendent of water, superintendent of public
works, their designee, or a licensed plumbing company under the supervision of
the city, and no connections shall be covered until the work has been inspected
to the satisfaction of city. Whenever any premises shall hereafter be connected
with the waterworks system, a charge shall be made pursuant to the terms of
this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The owner, occupant or party or parties in possession of any house,
structure, factory, industrial or commercial establishment or any other
building or structure of any other character which uses water and is located on
property within the corporate limits shall cause such house, structure,
factory, industrial or commercial establishment or any other building or
structure of any other character to be connected with the waterworks system
within ninety (90) days from the date that water facilities become available to
such property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Every building with an installed plumbing system intended for human
habitation or occupancy on the premises which falls within any residentially
zoned district of the City (pursuant to the City zoning regulation) shall be
provided by the owner of said property with a connection to the public water
system and public sanitary system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Use Of Wells:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No new wells for the provision of water shall be constructed within
the corporate limits of the City. Existing nonresidential premises which are
supplied by existing wells shall be permitted to continue said use, provided it
is not expanded, altered or intensified. Such determination shall be made in
the sole discretion of the Superintendent of Water or his designees. (Ord.
2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Within fourteen (14) days of the effective date hereof, any person,
firm, corporation or entity operating an existing well shall register same with
the City. Such registration shall include identification of the well location,
when such well was put into service, the depth of the well, type of equipment,
maximum capacity, well water used on a monthly basis, and such further
information as may be reasonably required by the City. Such information shall
be updated by the operator on an annual basis on July 1 of each year. Each
registration shall be accompanied by a registration fee as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Any well so permitted shall comply with the Illinois Plumbing Code,
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and all other applicable State and
Federal Statutes and regulations and local regulations, and shall have
inspections and tests made of such permitted wells as required by the Illinois
Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and all other
applicable State and Federal Statutes and regulations and local regulations. A
copy of such compliance records shall accompany the registration required
herein. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Tap Fees And Costs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Fees Established; Tap Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Water taps are by permission of the Superintendent of Water or
his designee only. The property owner/applicant shall install the required
water meter and pay the water tap fees as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Any tap into the waterworks system shall be by full circle
stainless steel repair clamp with a welded tap of a type and kind approved by
the City, unless another tapping alternate is otherwise approved in the sole
discretion of the Superintendent of Water or his designee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Notwithstanding the above, any consumer that demonstrates to the
satisfaction of the Superintendent of Water that such consumer has a need for
an oversized meter to alleviate flow restriction may install such oversized
meter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Scope Of Fees: The water tap fees shall be due and payable for any
building or structure which is directly or indirectly connected to a City water
main. Evidence of connection to a City water main shall include, but not be
limited to, installation of a water meter for the provision of water to said
building or structure.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Additional Costs: The water tap fees do not include tapping,
corporation stop, curb stop, stop/buffalo box, meter pit (if permitted), meter,
materials, labor, or miscellaneous costs which shall be paid by the owner/
applicant. As set forth herein, water service lines to the main shall be
maintained by the property owner. If the property owner shall fail to maintain
said line pursuant to the direction of the City, the City may pursue any or all
of the following remedies:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Terminate the water service to the premises until repairs deemed
necessary by the City are made. The cost of said termination shall be paid by
the owner, and if not paid, said charges shall be deemed to be unpaid water
charges and shall, at the City's sole option, constitute a lien upon the
serviced property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Charge the property owner for the estimated cost of all water
that is determined by the City to have not been metered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Perform the repairs or maintenance to the service lines. The cost
of said repairs shall be paid by the owner upon presentation, or said charges
shall be deemed to be unpaid water charges and shall, at the City's sole
option, constitute a lien upon the serviced property which may be foreclosed as
set forth herein, and if unpaid, the City may terminate service to the
property. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1-3: AUTHORITY TO TURN ON WATER; APPLICATION FOR SERVICE:
No water from the waterworks system shall be turned on for service into any
premises by any person other than the superintendent of the water department or
his designee. Applications to have water turned on shall be made in writing to
the city and shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept
all of the provisions of this chapter as conditions governing the use and
service of the waterworks system by the applicant. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1-4: INSTALLATION AND CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Service Pipes: The state plumbing code shall control the design and
installation of new plumbing systems and the alteration of existing plumbing
systems. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Compliance With Plumbing Regulations: No water shall be turned on for
service in any premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the
ordinances of the city; provided, that water may be turned on for construction
work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Excavations: Excavations for installing service pipes and laterals or
repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the ordinance provisions
relating to making excavations in streets; provided, that it shall be unlawful
to place any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any
drainpipe or sewer lateral, unless approved by the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Shutoff Boxes: Shutoff boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every
service pipe, and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line
where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily
accessible and shall be protected from frost. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Costs: All service pipes and laterals required or permitted by the
city, from the waterworks system (water mains/corporation) to the stop box,
shall be installed at the sole expense of the owner of the property to be
served or the applicant for the service. If such water service must cross a
city or state road or alley that requires boring and casing, the cost of such
boring and/or casing shall be borne by the applicant for the service or the
owner of the property being served. All such water services shall have a curb
cock with a stop box flush with the ground and placed as directed and approved
by the superintendent of water or his designee. Repairs to existing water pits
for service connections may be permitted in the sole discretion of the
superintendent of water or his designee, at the sole cost of the owner of the
property to be served or the applicant for the service. (Ord. 14-O-11, 6-3-
2014)
9-1-5: SERVICE TO MORE THAN ONE PREMISES:
No owner or plumber shall be permitted to connect water pipes into any two (2)
distinct premises or tenements. Multiple units on single lots, consolidated
lots, single zoning lots, duplex flats, double houses, multi-family
construction, condominium structures and apartment houses shall be considered
as one "premises". (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1-6: METERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Metered Water Required: Any person who receives water from the city
public water supply shall install and maintain a water meter, approved and
supplied by the city in its sole discretion. All meters placed in service on
any premises using the city water supply will be provided by the city at the
cost of the property owner; however, such meters shall be owned by the city,
which retains the right to inspect, repair and replace them upon reasonable
notice to the owner of the premises. The property owner shall be responsible
for the cost of repair or replacement of the water meter if damaged by any
negligence or intentional act of the owner or occupant of the property being
serviced.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Location: All water meters required by ordinance and hereinafter
installed, replaced or serviced within the city shall be installed in a
location that will provide easy access thereto and shall be located in the
basement or crawl space of the structure being constructed or remodeled. In the
event the structure does not have a basement or crawl space, the location of
the water meter shall be designated by the code official or superintendent of
water or their designee. Further, the water meter, when installed, replaced or
serviced, shall provide for and include an exterior remote receptacle for
reading the installed water meter. Said receptacle shall be of a type approved
by the city and installed and maintained in a location which is easily
accessible to personnel of the water department. The location of said
receptacle shall be approved by the code official or superintendent of water or
their designee. In the event that there is any suspected malfunction of the
metering system, then, upon notice, access to the property shall be made
available to the superintendent of water or his designee for inspection and
repair. Upon failure to make the premises immediately available, water service
to the premises may be terminated. Once so terminated, all of the charges,
fines and fees specified in article A of this chapter for disconnection of
delinquent consumers shall be applicable for such disconnection and
reconnection. All owners and occupants shall, at their own expense, keep all
water meters, including those previously located in outside meter pits, in good
repair and properly protected from frost and other dangers, and shall be
responsible for the cost of replacing or repairing water meters that are
damaged due to the failure of the owner or occupant to keep said meter in good
repair or to protect said meter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Reading Meters: The superintendent of water shall read or cause to be
read every water meter used in the city at such times as are necessary so that
the bills may be sent out at the proper times.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Testing Meters: Upon request or complaint of the consumer, any water
meter shall be tested for accuracy. If, upon testing, the meter is found to be
over three percent (3%) off in accuracy, the meter shall be replaced at no cost
to the consumer. If the meter is found to be three percent (3%) or less in
accuracy, then the consumer shall pay a testing fee equal to the cost charged
by the contractor or facility performing the test, which contractor or facility
shall be selected by the city. The city may also impose an administrative fee
not to exceed twenty percent (20%) of the testing fee. (Ord. 14-O-11, 6-3-2014)
9-1-7: REPAIRS TO SYSTEM:
All repairs for service pipes and laterals from the waterworks system (water
mains/corporation) to the stop box shall be made at the sole expense of the
owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. All
repairs and excavations from the stop box to the property being served shall be
made at the sole expense of the owner of the property to be served or the
applicant for the service. The proposed repairs shall be approved by the
superintendent of water or his designee who may require the replacement of all
or a portion of such service. All owners and/or occupants shall, at their own
expense, keep their water service pipe from the point of connection with the
stop box to their premises, and all other apparatus, such as meters, including
any meters located in outside meter pits, in good repair and properly protected
from frost and other dangers. (Ord. 14-O-11, 6-3-2014)
9-1-8: EMERGENCIES; CONSERVATION MEASURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
Â Â Â  A PERIOD OF EMERGENCY WATER CONDITIONS: Any of the conditions listed in
subsection B1 of this section.
Â Â Â SPRINKLING: The transfer of water by means of hoses, tubing, pipes or
otherwise from any water source under the control of or supplied by the city
waterworks system to any lawn or any outdoor plants or vegetation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Emergencies:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Declaration Of Emergency: The mayor or the superintendent of water
or their designee is empowered to declare that a state of emergency water
condition exists, in his sole discretion, including, but not limited to,
whenever any one or more of the following conditions exist:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Pump breakdown in wells.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Failure in distribution systems of water.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Pump breakdown in the water plant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A contamination of the city water supply.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â A regional water shortage is determined by the state.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â A local water shortage is determined to exist.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Procedures: During the time when the emergency water condition
exists, the mayor or superintendent of water or their designee shall take the
following steps as deemed necessary:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Order closed all commercial car wash facilities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Order closed all commercial laundries.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Require the cessation of all water main flushing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Require the cessation of all sewer flushing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Limit the exterior water use by commercial and residential
consumers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Limit or cut off the industrial use of water.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â Lower the distribution system pressure so long as there is enough
pressure for adequate fire protection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Notice Of Emergency: Notice of the declared state of emergency water
condition must be served either by mail, in person or by posting in city hall
of any steps taken in subsection B2 of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Shut Off Of Water: The mayor or superintendent of water or their
designee may limit or cut off the water supply to any structure which fails to
comply with the terms and conditions of this section, with or without notice,
until said structure and all facilities thereunder meet with the standards of
this section.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Outside Water Use: Outside water use is hereby regulated in the
following manner:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The users of the city waterworks system shall be encouraged to
voluntarily regulate their sprinkling to every other day, with the consumers
with odd numbered addresses watering on odd numbered days (i.e., 17 Highwood
Avenue watering on the first, third, etc.) and even numbered addresses watering
on even numbered days (i.e., 300 Green Bay Road on the second, fourth, etc.).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All outdoor sprinkling during May, June, July, August and September
between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
(or such other times as prohibited by regulation of the state) is hereby
banned. Sprinkling shall be permitted only between the hours of one minute past
five o'clock (5:01) P.M. and eleven fifty nine o'clock (11:59) A.M. of the next
day, or such other times as may be permitted by regulation through the state.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â During the period of emergency water conditions, as proclaimed by
the mayor of the city pursuant to this section, users of the waterworks system
may be required to restrict sprinkling to every other day, with the users with
odd numbered addresses watering on odd numbered days (i.e., 17 Highwood Avenue
watering on the first and third, etc.) and even numbered addresses watering on
even numbered days (i.e., 300 Green Bay Road on the second and fourth, etc.).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â During a period of extended emergency water conditions as proclaimed
by the mayor or superintendent of water or their designee, sprinkling or all or
some outside use of water for the duration of the period of extended emergency
water conditions may be banned.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â When such proclamation is made pursuant hereto, the city shall take
reasonable steps to communicate same to the public.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Violations: For failure to obey an order to limit or cease use of water
when the emergency condition or an extended emergency condition exists and any
sprinkling which is in violation of this chapter, each hour shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1-9: RESALE OF WATER, UNAUTHORIZED USE PROHIBITED:
No water supplied by the waterworks system of the city shall be resold by any
consumer. No water consumer may supply water to other families or allow them to
take water, except for use on the premises and for the purpose specified in
such consumer's approved application. After water is introduced into any
building or upon any premises, no person shall make or employ any other person
to make any tap or connection with or work upon the premises for alterations,
repairs, extensions or attachments without a written permit therefor. Resale or
unauthorized use of water shall be grounds for discontinuance of water service
to the consumer or the premises, or both. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1-10: TAMPERING WITH, DAMAGE TO SYSTEM:
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the city council to
connect to, tamper with, alter or injure any part of the city waterworks or
supply system, or any meter. If any person allows damage to occur, either
intentionally, through negligence, or in any other fashion to any water meter,
including meters located in outside meter pits, or any portion of the city's
water supply system, it shall be said person's and the property owner's
responsibility to contact the city for an inspection. Pursuant to said
inspection, the city may recommend that the respective water meters, remote
reader or any other portion of the municipal waterworks or system be replaced
or repaired and such repair or replacement shall be at the sole expense of the
property owner or person causing the damage. For purposes of this section, a
meter with a broken seal or a frozen meter shall be deemed to be a damaged
meter. (Ord. 14-O-11, 6-3-2014)
9-1-11: LIABILITY AND EXEMPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Service Failures: All waterworks service supplied by the waterworks
system shall be upon the express condition that the city shall not be liable
nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by reason
of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or
appurtenances connected with said system or any part or portion thereof, or for
any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery, or by
reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Interruption Of Service: The city reserves the right to shut off water
at any time in the mains for the purpose of repairing, cleaning, making
connections with or extensions to same, or for the concentrating of water in
any part of the city, and for restricting the use of water in case of
deficiency in supply, including the suspension of the use of water for
sprinkling lawns or gardens. No claim shall be made against the city by reason
of the breaking of any service pipe or service cock, or damage arising from
shutting off of water for repairing, laying or relaying mains, hydrants or
other connections, or repairing any part of the waterworks system, or from
failure of the water supply, or by increasing or decreasing the water pressure
at any time, or from concentrated or restricted use of water as above.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Indemnification Of City: The city does not waive the immunities
provided by law to itself, its officers, officials, employees, or agents,
including, but not limited to, those under the Illinois tort immunity act 1 .
However, to the extent any liability may exist for which said immunity does not
apply, by accepting service, each consumer does hereby release, indemnify and
hold harmless the city, and each of its corporate authorities, elected and
appointed officials, officers, boards, commissions, legal counsel, agents, and
employees from and against the following: Any and all liability, claims,
damages, losses and expenses, including, without limitation, attorney fees and
costs, from any claim whatsoever related to the provision of water services,
the waterworks system, or service pipes and laterals required or permitted by
the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â City Exempt: The city and its agents, employees and contractors shall
be exempt from the provisions of this chapter where determined to be in the
best interests of the city, in the opinion of the superintendent of water.
(Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)

9-1A-1: BASIS FOR WATER SERVICE CHARGES:
Where an amount or rate has not been specifically determined in this chapter,
the water service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the water
facilities of the city shall consist of a basic user charge, a debt service
charge, and a capital improvement charge. The city may establish differential
rates based upon categories of consumers.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Basic User Charge: The basic user charge is levied on all consumers to
recover the operation, maintenance and replacement (hereinafter "OM&R") costs
and shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters. The basic user
charge shall be computed as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Estimate the annual water volume.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and
maintain the water facilities, including a replacement fund for the year, for
all works categories.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Compute costs per one hundred (100) cubic feet.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Debt Service Charge: The debt service charge is computed by
apportioning the annual debt service at the city's option either as:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A fixed charge per billing period; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A fixed charge, plus a charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Capital Improvement Charge: The capital improvement charge is levied on
consumers to provide for capital improvements, extensions or reconstruction of
the waterworks system. The capital improvement charge is computed by
apportioning the annual amount to be accrued at the city's option either as:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A fixed charge per billing period; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A fixed charge, plus a charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Consumer Category Differential: The consumer category differential is
an additional amount levied upon different categories of consumers to
compensate for the disproportionate cost of providing service, increasing
capacity, or increased maintenance. Such amount may be applied to billings for
the water supply or wastewater facilities. Such amount may be expressed at the
city's option either as:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A fixed charge per billing period; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A fixed charge, plus a charge per one hundred (100) cubic feet; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â An additional fixed surcharge, surcharge per business or residential
unit receiving service, increase in rate, or combination thereof per billing
period or per one hundred (100) cubic feet. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-2: MEASUREMENT OF FLOW:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges shall be the
metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of one hundred
(100) cubic feet.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Where a person is permitted by the City to procure any part of his
water from sources other than the public waterworks system, the person shall
install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by the
City for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these
other sources.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Devices for measuring the volume of water may be required by the City
if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water
consumption records. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Metering devices for determining the volume shall be installed and
maintained by the person. Following approval and installation, such meters may
not be removed, unless service is canceled, without the consent of the City.
(Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004; amd. 2009 Code)
9-1A-3: RATE CATEGORIES; CHARGES ESTABLISHED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Consumers: Based upon the components in this article, the following
charges and rate categories are hereby determined for water consumers:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Within City Limits:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â There is hereby established a charge to each user of the
waterworks system of the City, based upon the amount of water consumed, as
registered by the water meters installed in each domicile, as provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this Code. (Ord. 18-O-17, 8-21-2018)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The minimum charge in any one (1) 2-month period shall be the
equivalent of ten (10) units of one hundred (100) cubic feet. (Ord. 12-O-39, 9-
4-2012)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Outside City Limits:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â There is hereby established a charge, in addition to the charge
described in subsection A1 of this section, to each user of the waterworks
system of the City who is not located within the corporate limits of the City,
based on the amount of water consumed, as registered by water meters installed
in each domicile service as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code. (Ord. 18-O-17, 8-21-2018)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The minimum charge in any one (1) 2-month period shall be the
equivalent of ten (10) units of one hundred (100) cubic feet. (Ord. 12-O-39, 9-
4-2012)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Environmental Remediation Fee: Certain costs have been, and will be,
incurred by the City which were necessitated by environmental considerations.
Specifically, costs for remediation of underground storage tanks at the water
plant facility; mandated shoreline cleanup; remediation due to disposal of
debris at the water plant facility; removal of sediment and chemicals in the
filtration process; and issues regarding remediation of areas where water and
sewer mains are constructed. Compliance by the City with environmental
considerations is mandated by law and by the desire of the City to provide the
best quality water to the consumers of its waterworks system. Therefore, in
addition to the rates imposed above, all property, whether within the City or
outside the City limits of the City and having a connection with any mains or
pipes constructed or hereafter constructed and used in connection with the City
waterworks system, where water meters are used, shall be charged at the rate as
provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code. (Ord. 18-O-17, 8-21-2018)
Said environmental remediation fee shall be separately designated on each
statement, if practicable.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Adjustment Of Rates To Comply With Bond Requirements: The City shall
from time to time adjust the above rates by further ordinance as may be
required to ensure that the City is at all times in compliance with the revenue
requirements of "an ordinance authorizing and providing for the issuance of
waterworks and sewerage bonds, series 1994, of the City of Highwood", ordinance
94-O-24, any refinancing of said bond, or as may be required to ensure that the
City is at all times in compliance with the revenue requirements of "an
ordinance authorizing the City of Highwood, Lake County, Illinois to borrow
funds from the public water supply loan program", ordinance 99-O-55. (Ord. 10-
O-22, 6-15-2010; amd. Ord. 12-O-39, 9-4-2012)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Water Meter Surcharge Fee: Certain costs have been, and will be,
incurred by the City with regard to the purchase and installation of new water
meters for water consumers. Therefore, in addition to the rates imposed above,
all property, whether within the City or outside the City limits of the City
and having a connection with any mains or pipes constructed or hereafter
constructed and used in connection with the City waterworks system, where water
meters are used, shall be charged a surcharge in an amount as provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this Code per billing cycle. This surcharge shall terminate upon
final payment by the City of all costs related to purchase and installation of
the new water meters, including all debt service payments. (Ord. 18-O-17, 8-21-
2018)
9-1A-4: COMPUTATION OF CHARGE:
Where an amount or rate has not been specifically determined above, the water
service charge shall be computed by the following formula:
CW = CC + CD + CM + (Vu-X)CU
(as adjusted by CCD for any category established above)
Where:   Â 
CW     = Amount of water service charge ($) per billing period
CC     = Capital improvement charge (subsection 9-1A-1C of this article)
CD     = Debt service charge (subsection 9-1A-1B of this article)
CM     = Minimum charge for operation, maintenance and replacement (section
         9-1A-3 et seq., of this article, as applicable)
Vu     = Water volume for the billing period
X      = Allowable consumption in cubic feet for the minimum charge (subsection
         9-1A-3A1 or A2 of this article, as applicable)
CU     = Basic user charge for operation, maintenance and replacement
         (subsection 9-1A-1A of this article)
CCD    = Consumer category differential (subsection 9-1A-1D of this article)
Â 
(Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-5: APPEALS:
The method for computation of rates and service charges established for
consumer charges in this article shall be made available to a consumer within
thirty (30) days of receipt of a written request for same. Any disagreement
over the charges or in the computations thereof shall be remedied by the City
within ninety (90) days after receipt of a formal written appeal outlining the
alleged discrepancy. Any such appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of
the mailing of the bill by the City. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-6: AUDIT REQUIRED:
The adequacy of the water service charge shall be reviewed, not less often than
annually, by certified public accountants or financial consultants for the City
in their annual audit report. The water service charge shall be revised
periodically to reflect a change in local capital costs or OM&R costs. (Ord.
2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-7: BILLS RENDERED; LIABILITY; LATE PAYMENT PENALTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All water charges and rents shall be due and payable on January 1,
March 1, May 1, July 1, September 1, and November 1 of each and every year for
the period last preceding. However, high volume commercial consumer water
charges and rents shall be due and payable monthly, if so billed by the City at
its sole option.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All water charges and rents shall be fixed upon the reading of the
meters for the preceding period, and the Clerk of the Water Department or the
City Collector shall, at the expiration of each period aforesaid, mail to all
water consumers statements or bills with the amounts due from them
respectively. However, at its option, the City may fix water charges and rents
upon an estimate of water usage for any given billing period. If the water
rents and charges are fixed upon said estimate, the water charges and rents for
the following billing period shall be fixed upon the reading of the meter, and
the charges adjusted according to actual usage revealed by said reading.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the consumer of the
service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for all fees, fines,
penalties and charges levied under this article, including the water service to
any premises furnished to the premises by the City.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In the event any consumer fails to pay such bill within twenty (20)
days from the date of mailing, such consumer shall pay an additional charge as
follows: an initial late charge of ten percent (10%) of the bill amount as a
late payment penalty. An additional late charge of ten percent (10%) per month
of the outstanding bill shall accrue thereafter as a penalty for failure to
make prompt payments. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-8: DELINQUENT PAYMENTS; DISCONTINUANCE AND RESTORATION OF SERVICE:
If the charges for such services are not paid within sixty (60) days after the
rendition of the bill for such services, such services shall be discontinued
without further notice and shall not be reinstated until all claims are
settled. In the event that water service is cutoff or terminated to any
consumer for failure to make payment for service, or under any other ordinance
requiring disconnection, as required herein, water service shall be restored to
the consumer only upon payment of the consumer's bill, all accrued late
charges, and a turn on fee as follows: (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An amount as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code for any residential use.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An amount as provided in section
3-2A-1 of this Code for any business or commercial use. (Ord. 18-O-17, 8-21-
2018)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Further, the consumer shall pay any and all fees incurred by the City
in effectuating said water service cutoff including, but not limited to,
manpower charges for effectuating said turnoff and any repairs, modifications
or construction of the water service in effectuating the water service turnoff
or turn on. This shall include repair to any water mains or pipes; excavation
to effectuate the turnoff or turn on; cost of installation of necessary valves
or piping and repair and restoration of the street, sidewalk, curbing or
landscaping attendant to said turnoff or turn on. (Ord. 2004-O-8, 1-20-2004)
9-1A-9: LIEN PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Statement Of Lien Claim:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid for sixty (60) days
after it has been rendered, the City Treasurer may file with the County
Recorder of Deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the
legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a
notice that the City claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges
subsequent to the period covered by the bill.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the consumer whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the
premises and the City Treasurer has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to
the owner of the premises if his address be known to the Treasurer. The failure
of the City Treasurer to record such lien or to mail such notice or the failure
of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the
lien for unpaid bills as set forth herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges
shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be
applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be pursuant to a
complaint filed in the name of the City. The City Attorney is hereby authorized
to institute such proceedings in the name of the City in any court having
jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has
remained unpaid for sixty (60) days after it has been rendered. (Ord. 2004-O-8,
1-20-2004)

ARTICLE B. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
9-1B-1: Purpose
9-1B-2: Scope
9-1B-3: Policy
9-1B-4: Definitions
9-1B-5: Water System
9-1B-6: Cross Connections Restricted
9-1B-7: Surveys And Investigations
9-1B-8: Where Protection Required
9-1B-9: Type Of Protection Required
