Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Whenever the words "dwelling unit", "dwelling", "premises", "building",
"rooming house", "rooming unit", "story", and "structure" are used in this
article, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or
any part thereof". (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-3: DEFINITIONS OF SPECIFIC TERMS:
Unless otherwise specifically indicated, the following definitions shall apply
in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
BASEMENT: The lowest level story of any structure, which is more than fifty
percent (50%) below grade.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Highwood, Illinois.
DRIVEWAY: A private road that connects a house, garage, or other residential
building with a street or alley.
DWELLING: Any building which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used
for living or sleeping by human occupants.
DWELLING UNIT: A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities
for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping,
eating, cooking and sanitation.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: Any of the following: code official, health inspector,
police chief or fire chief of the city of Highwood, Illinois, or their
authorized representatives.
EXTERIOR PROPERTY: The open space on the premises and on adjoining property
under the control of owners or operators of such premises.
EXTERMINATION: The control and elimination of insects, rats or other pests by
eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible
materials that serve as their food; by poison spraying, fumigating, trapping or
by any other approved pest elimination methods.
FAMILY: An individual, or two (2) or more persons related by blood or marriage
or adoption, living together in a dwelling unit, or a group of not more than
four (4) persons who need not be related by blood or marriage or adoption,
living as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit, and sharing common
facilities as considered reasonably appropriate for a family related by blood,
marriage or adoption.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
HABITABLE SPACE OR HABITABLE ROOM: Space in a structure for living, sleeping,
eating, or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet compartments, closets, halls, storage or
utility spaces, and similar areas are not considered "habitable spaces".
INFESTATION: The presence, within or contiguous to a structure or premises, of
insects, rats, vermin or other pests.
LET FOR OCCUPANCY OR LET: To permit possession or occupancy of a dwelling,
dwelling unit, rooming unit, building or structure by a person who shall be the
legal owner or not be the legal owner of record thereof, pursuant to a written
or unwritten lease, agreement or license, or pursuant to a recorded or
unrecorded agreement or contract for the sale of land.
MULTIPLE-FAMILY DWELLING: A building containing more than two (2) dwelling
units and not classified as a one- or two-family dwelling.
OCCUPANT: Any person living or sleeping in a building or having possession of a
space within a building.
ONE-FAMILY DWELLING: A building containing one dwelling unit with not more than
one "family", as defined in this section.
OPENABLE AREA: That part of a window or door which is available for
unobstructed ventilation and which opens directly to the outdoors.
OPERATOR: Any person who has charge, care or control of a structure or premises
which is let or offered for occupancy.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or
equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
state, county or city as holding title to the property; or otherwise having
control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such
person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of any such person if
ordered to possession of real property by a court.
PARKING AREA: The area adjacent to or on the same zoning lot as a residential
building or structure utilized for the parking of vehicles for that residential
building or structure.
PERSON: An individual, corporation, partnership or any other group acting as a
unit.
PLUMBING: The practice, materials, and fixtures used in the installation,
maintenance, extension and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances, and
appurtenances within the scope of the plumbing code of the state of Illinois
and/or the 2012 international fuel gas and mechanical codes.
PLUMBING FIXTURE: A receptacle or device which is either permanently or
temporarily connected to the water distribution system of the premises, and
demands a supply of water therefrom; or discharges used water, liquid borne
waste materials, or sewage, either directly or indirectly, of the drainage
system of the premises; or which requires both a water supply connection and a
discharge to the drainage system of the premises.
ROOMING HOUSE: A building or portion of a building, other than a hotel or
motel, in which sleeping accommodations not constituting an apartment are
furnished at a fee for four (4) or more persons ordinarily renting such
accommodations at a specified rate for a specified time, and occupying the
premises as a permanent place of abode rather than on a transient basis for a
short term period of occupancy. An "apartment" is a self-contained unit with
private bath and cooking facilities.
ROOMING UNIT: Any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit used
or intended to be used for sleeping and/or living, but not for cooking
purposes.
RUBBISH: Combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage; and
the term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and
other combustible material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood excelsior,
rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral
matters, glass, crockery and dust.
STRUCTURE: That which is built or constructed, including, without limitation
because of enumeration, buildings for any occupancy or use whatsoever, fire
escapes, chute escapes, railings, open grade steps, sidewalks, stairways, or
anything erected and framed of component parts which is fastened, anchored or
rests on a permanent foundation or on the ground.
SUPPLIED: Paid for, furnished or provided by or under the control of the owner
or operator.
TWO-FAMILY DWELLING: A building containing two (2) dwelling units with not more
than one "family", as defined in this section, per dwelling unit.
VENTILATION: The natural or mechanical process of supplying conditioned or
unconditioned air to or removing such air from any space.
YARD: An open space on the same lot with the building. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994;
amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 16-O-34, 7-19-2016; Ord. 16-O-55, 12-6-2016)
10-2A-4: MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR BASIC EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES:
The owner or operator of any structure shall provide and maintain said
structure with facilities and equipment in compliance with the requirements of
this article. A person shall not occupy, as owner-occupant, or permit another
person to occupy or use any structure, dwelling, dwelling unit or premises
which does not comply with the requirements of this article. Further, no person
shall let to another for occupancy any structure, dwelling, dwelling unit, or
premises, which does not comply with the following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink in a safe, sanitary
and good working condition and properly connected to a water and sewer system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit (except as otherwise permitted under subsection D
of this section) shall contain a room which affords privacy to a person within
said room and which is equipped with a flush water closet and a lavatory basin
in a safe, sanitary and good working condition and properly connected to a
water and sewer system.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit (except as otherwise permitted under subsection D
of this section) shall contain, within a room which affords privacy to a person
within said room, a bathtub or shower in a safe, sanitary and good working
condition and properly connected to a water and sewer system.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The occupants of not more than two (2) dwelling units may share a
single flush water closet, a single lavatory basin and a single bathtub or
shower, if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Said dwelling units were both constructed pursuant to permits issued
by the city and existed prior to the effective date hereof; and that
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Neither of the two (2) dwelling units contains more than two (2)
rooms; provided, that for the purpose of this subsection, a kitchenette or an
efficiency kitchen with not more than sixty (60) square feet of floor area
shall not be counted as a room; and that
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The habitable area of each of such dwelling units shall equal not
more than three hundred (300) square feet of floor area; and that
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Such water closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be in
a safe, sanitary and good working condition and properly connected to a water
and sewer system approved by the enforcement officer.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All plumbing fixtures shall be properly installed and maintained in
working order and shall be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects and
capable of performing the functions for which such plumbing fixtures are
designed. All plumbing fixtures shall be maintained in a safe, sanitary and
good working condition.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Plumbing fixtures shall have adequate clearances for use and cleaning.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Every sink, lavatory, bathtub or shower, drinking fountain, water
closet or other plumbing fixture shall be properly connected to a public water
system. All kitchen sinks, lavatories, laundry facilities, bathtubs and showers
shall be equipped with hot or tempered and cold running water.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The water supply shall be maintained free from contamination, and all
water inlets for plumbing fixtures shall be located above the flood level rim
of the fixture. Shampoo basin faucets, janitor sink faucets, and other hose
bibs or faucets to which hoses are attached and left in place shall be
protected by an approved atmospheric type vacuum breaker or an approved
permanently attached hose connection vacuum breaker.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â The water supply system shall be installed and maintained to provide a
supply of water to plumbing fixtures, devices, and appurtenances in sufficient
volume and at pressures adequate to enable the fixtures to function properly,
safely, and free of defects and leaks.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Water heating facilities shall be properly installed, maintained, and
capable of providing an adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required
sink, lavatory, bathtub, shower and laundry facility at a temperature of not
less than one hundred ten degrees Fahrenheit (110Â°F) (43Â°C). A gas burning
water heater shall not be located in any bathroom, bedroom or other occupied
room normally kept closed, unless adequate combustion air is provided. An
approved combination temperature and pressure relief valve and relief valve
discharge pipe shall be properly installed and maintained on water heaters.
Such supplied water heating facilities shall be capable of meeting the
requirements of this subsection when the dwelling or dwelling unit heating
facilities required under the provisions of this article are not in operation.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â All plumbing fixtures shall be properly connected to a public sewer
system.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Every plumbing stack, vent, waste and sewer line shall function
properly and be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit shall have safe, unobstructed and continuous means
of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â No rooming unit shall contain facilities such as stoves, hot plates,
other appliances for cooking or heating foods or beverages, one refrigerator
larger than 5.2 cubic feet, or kitchen sinks, whether or not such appliances
are currently connected to power sources or water and drainage facilities.
Where a rooming unit is located within a dwelling unit, no occupant of said
rooming unit shall use any area for cooking or food preparation except for the
principal kitchen of the dwelling unit within which said lodging room is
located. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â Every dwelling shall be provided with heating facilities capable of
maintaining a room temperature of sixty five degrees Fahrenheit (65Â°F) (18Â°C)
at a level of three feet (3') (914 mm) above the floor and a distance of three
feet (3') (914 mm) from the exterior walls in all habitable rooms, bathrooms
and toilet rooms based on the outside design temperature required for the city
by the 2012 international fuel gas and mechanical codes.
Â Â Â P.Â Â Â Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one
or more dwelling units, rooming units, dormitory rooms or guestrooms on terms,
either express or implied, shall supply sufficient heat during the period from
October 1 to May 1 to maintain a room temperature of not less than sixty eight
degrees Fahrenheit (68Â°F) (18Â°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet
rooms during the hours between six thirty o'clock (6:30) A.M. and ten thirty
o'clock (10:30) P.M. of each day and not less than sixty five degrees
Fahrenheit (65Â°F) (16Â°C) during other hours. The temperature shall be measured
at a point three feet (3') (914 mm) above the floor and three feet (3') (914
mm) from the exterior walls. When the outdoor temperature is below the outdoor
design temperature required for the city by the 2012 international fuel gas and
mechanical codes, the owner or operator shall not be required to maintain the
minimum room temperatures, provided the heating system is operating at full
capacity, with supply valves and dampers in a full open position. (Ord. 94-O-
31, 7-5-1994; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 16-O-55, 12-6-2016)
Â Â Â Q.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with adequate rubbish storage
facilities.
Â Â Â R.Â Â Â Every dwelling unit shall have adequate garbage disposal facilities or
garbage storage containers.
Â Â Â S.Â Â Â After October 15, 1994, all rooms which are let for occupancy, and
further, which can or may be occupied for sleeping purposes, shall have a safe,
unobstructed and continuous means of egress to a safe and open space at ground
level to the exterior of the premises. Said egress shall be provided to the
immediate exterior of the premises and may be satisfied by means of an exterior
stairway, fire escape, or approved temporary chain or rope escape ladder or
escape device. This subsection shall not apply if the building in which the
rooms which are let for occupancy has two (2) separate approved exits from each
floor containing rooms for sleeping purposes. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
Â Â Â T.Â Â Â Driveways and parking areas for residential uses shall be constructed
of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Minimum six inch (6") concrete with a minimum four inch (4")
compacted aggregate base course, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Minimum two inches (2") asphalt surface course with a minimum six
inch (6") compacted aggregate base course, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Concrete pavers, as determined by the building official, with a
minimum six inches (6") compacted aggregate base course.
Any driveway or parking area lawfully existing or under construction on the
effective date hereof which does not meet the requirements of this subsection
shall be made to conform by September 1, 2017. (Ord. 16-O-34, 7-19-2016)
10-2A-5: MINIMUM SPACE, USE AND LOCATION REQUIREMENTS:
The owner or operator of any structure shall provide and maintain said
structure with facilities and equipment in compliance with the requirements of
this article. A person shall not occupy, as owner-occupant, or permit another
person to occupy or use any structure, dwelling, dwelling unit or premises
which does not comply with the requirements of this article. Further, no person
shall let to another for occupancy any structure, dwelling, dwelling unit, or
premises which does not comply with the following requirements:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The total of all habitable rooms in a dwelling unit shall be such as to
provide at least two hundred (200) square feet of floor area per occupant.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain
at least seventy (70) square feet (6.51 square meters) of floor area, and every
room occupied for sleeping by more than one person shall contain at least fifty
(50) square feet (4.65 square meters) of floor area for each occupant thereof.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sleeping rooms shall not be used as the only means of access to other
sleeping rooms or habitable spaces, except for dwelling units that contain
fewer than two (2) sleeping rooms.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Every sleeping room shall have access to at least one water closet and
one lavatory without passing through another sleeping room.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Dwelling units and rooming units shall be arranged to provide privacy
and be separate from other adjoining spaces.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Notwithstanding the minimum footage requirements herein, no dwelling
unit shall be occupied by more than one "family", as defined in section
10-2A-3 of this article.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Kitchens, bathrooms, nonhabitable spaces, interior public areas (which
include, but are not limited to, hallways, entryways, living rooms and dining
rooms) shall not be used for sleeping purposes. However, said interior public
areas may be used for sleeping purposes in efficiency type dwelling units
having no separate sleeping room whatsoever, and further provided, that said
efficiency type unit is occupied by no more than two (2) persons, and all other
minimum space requirements established hereunder are satisfied.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Habitable spaces, other than kitchens, shall have a clear ceiling
height of not less than seven feet four inches (7'4") (2235 mm). Hallways,
corridors, laundry areas, bathrooms, toilet rooms, and kitchens shall have a
clear ceiling height of not less than seven feet (7') (2134 mm). Exceptions are
as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Beams or girders spaced not less than four feet (4') (1219 mm) on
center and projecting not more than six inches (6") (152 mm) below the required
ceiling height, provided the minimum clear height is not less than six feet
eight inches (6'8") (2033 mm).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Dropped or furred ceilings over no more than one-half (1/2) of the
minimum floor area required by this article, provided no part of such dropped
or furred ceiling is less than seven feet (7') (2134 mm) in height.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Rooms used exclusively for sleeping, study, or similar uses and
having a sloped ceiling over all or part of the room, with a clear ceiling
height of at least seven feet (7') (2134 mm) over not less than one-third (1/3)
of the required minimum floor area. In calculating the floor area of such
rooms, only those portions of the floor area with a clear ceiling height of
five feet (5') (1524 mm) or more shall be included.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Basement rooms in one- and two-family dwellings used exclusively for
laundry, study, or recreation purposes having a ceiling height of not less than
six feet eight inches (6'8") (2033 mm) with not less than six feet four inches
(6'4") (1932 mm) of clear height under beams, girders, ducts, and similar
obstructions.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â A habitable room, other than a kitchen, shall not be less than seven
feet (7') (2,133 mm) in any plan dimension. Kitchens shall have a clear
passageway of not less than three feet (3') (914 mm) between counterfronts and
appliances or counterfronts and walls.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â All spaces to be used for food preparation shall contain suitable space
and equipment to store, prepare and serve foods in a sanitary manner. There
shall be adequate facilities and services for the sanitary disposal of food
wastes and refuse, including facilities for temporary storage.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â No basement shall be used in a dwelling unit, rooming unit, rooming
house or otherwise as a place for sleeping, kitchen or cooking purposes. (Ord.
94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-6: RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Every owner of a dwelling containing one or more dwelling units shall
be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or
public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof and the exterior property and
yard.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall keep in a clean and
sanitary condition that part of the dwelling, dwelling unit and premises
thereof which he occupies and controls.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his
rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the rubbish containers
required by subsections 10-2A-4Q and R of this article.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his
garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents in a
clean and sanitary manner, by placing it in the garbage disposal facilities or
garbage storage containers required by subsections 10-2A-4Q and R of this
article. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to supply such facilities
or containers for all dwelling units in a dwelling containing more than four
(4) dwelling units and for all dwelling units located on premises where more
than four (4) dwelling units share the same premises. In all other cases, it
shall be the responsibility of the occupant to furnish such facilities or
containers.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall be responsible for
hanging all screens and double or storm doors and windows whenever the same are
required under the provisions of this article or of any rule or regulation
adopted pursuant hereto, except where the owner has agreed to supply such
service.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â 1. The owner of the premises shall maintain the structures, yard and
exterior property in compliance with the requirements of this subsection. A
person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or permit another person to occupy or
use premises which do not comply with the requirements of this subsection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All structures shall be kept free from insect and rat infestation.
All structures in which insects or rats are found shall be promptly
exterminated by approved processes that will not be injurious to human health.
After extermination, proper precautions shall be taken to prevent
reinfestation.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures
therein in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be responsible for the
exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The owner of the premises shall maintain all interior stairs and
railings in sound condition and good repair.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Every flight of stairs which is more than four (4) risers high shall
have a handrail on at least one side of the stair, and every open portion of a
stair, landing or balcony which is more than thirty inches (30") (762 mm) above
the floor or grade below shall have guardrails. Handrails shall not be less
than thirty inches (30") (762 mm) nor more than forty two inches (42") (1,067
mm) high, measured vertically above the nosing of the tread or above the floor
of the landing or balcony. Guardrails shall be not less than thirty inches
(30") (762 mm) high above the floor of the landing or balcony. Every handrail
and guardrail shall be firmly fastened and capable of bearing normally imposed
loads and shall be maintained in good condition. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-7: ROOMING HOUSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance Required: No person shall operate a rooming house or shall
occupy or let to another for occupancy any rooming unit in any rooming house,
except in compliance with the provisions of this article, except the provisions
of subsection 10-2A-4A.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Prohibited In Residential Districts: It shall be unlawful for any
person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation to operate, maintain, control
or permit any structure within a residential district to be used as a rooming
house.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â License Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â License Required: No person shall operate a rooming house unless he
holds a valid rooming house license issued by the city in the name of the
operator and for the specific dwelling or dwelling unit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Application For License: In order to obtain a rooming house license,
the applicant shall file with the city clerk a written statement setting forth
the full name and address, date and place of birth of the applicant; or the
names and addresses, dates and places of birth of the partners, if the
applicant is a partnership; or the names and addresses of each of the
directors, officers and shareholders of the corporation, if the applicant is a
corporation; and the present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of
filing of the application. In the case of a corporation, the application shall
disclose the number and class of shares owned by each shareholder. The
application shall be in substantially the same form as is attached to the
ordinance codified herein. The application shall be signed and notarized under
oath by the applicant. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Investigation Of Applicant; Ineligibility For License: The
application shall be referred by the clerk to the license committee of the
council, who shall investigate the applicant. Further, the application shall be
referred to the code official or health inspector, who shall, within a
reasonable time, inspect the premises and report to the license committee and/
or the city council to ascertain compliance by the operator with the applicable
provisions of this article. The application shall be presented to the city
council within a reasonable time for approval by the council; provided,
however, that no operator's license shall be issued by the city to any of the
following: (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state or of the United States within the immediately preceding five (5) years
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted, within the immediately preceding
five (5) years, of being the keeper or who is keeping a house of ill fame
(unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor or ordinance violation opposed to decency and morality within the
immediately preceding five (5) years (unless pardoned).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â A person who, at the time of application for renewal of an
operator's license hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a
first application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â A partnership, unless all of the partners of said partnership
shall be individually qualified to obtain a license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â A corporation, unless all officers, managers, directors thereof,
or any shareholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the
shares of the corporation shall each be individually qualified to obtain a
license hereunder.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â A person who is an officer of the city or a member of the city
council. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â License Fee: Each application for each rooming house license or
renewal thereof shall be accompanied by an annual license fee as provided in
section
3-2A-1 of this code. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Expiration Of License: Every rooming house license shall expire at
the end of one year following its date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or
revoked as hereinafter provided.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Display Of License: The license shall be displayed in a conspicuous
place within the rooming house at all times.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Transfer Of License: No such license shall be transferable or
assignable. Every person holding such a license shall give notice in writing to
the city clerk within twenty four (24) hours after having sold, transferred,
given away or otherwise disposed of ownership of, interest in, or control of
any rooming house, or any partnership or corporation controlling a rooming
house in which said person has an interest. Such notice shall include the name
and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such
rooming house, or the partnership interest or corporate interest. Upon transfer
of the ownership interest in or control of the rooming house, or said
individual's partnership or corporate interest, the license shall terminate,
and the subsequent owner shall apply for a new license and pay the required
fee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Appeals: Any person whose application for a license to operate a
rooming house has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the
matter before the city council, under the procedure provided in subsection G of
this section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Premises Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one person shall
contain at least seventy (70) square feet of floor space, and every room
occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one person shall contain at least
fifty (50) square feet of floor space for each occupant thereof.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Every rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed and contiguous
means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Sanitary Conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The operator of every rooming house shall change supplied bed linen
and towels therein at least once each week and prior to letting of any room to
any occupant. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all
supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The operator of every rooming house shall be responsible for the
sanitary maintenance of all walls, floors, and ceilings, and for maintenance of
a sanitary condition in every other part of the rooming house; and he shall be
further responsible for the sanitary maintenance of the entire premises where
the entire structure or building is leased or occupied by the operator.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Every operator of a rooming house shall report, within twenty four
(24) hours, to an enforcement officer any person suffering from any
communicable disease, and such report shall be made whenever there is reason to
believe or suspect that any person in such rooming house may be afflicted with
any communicable disease, and especially with smallpox, scarlet fever,
diphtheria, measles, chickenpox, typhoid fever or tuberculosis.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Monthly Inspections; Violations; Suspension Of License:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The city shall conduct a monthly inspection of any rooming house
through one of the designated enforcement officers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whenever, upon inspection of any rooming house, any enforcement
officer finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any
provision of this article, or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant
hereto, the enforcement officer shall give notice in writing to the operator of
such rooming house that unless such conditions or practices are corrected
within a reasonable period, however, not to exceed thirty (30) days, to be
determined by the enforcement officer, the operator's rooming house license
will be suspended. At the end of such period, the enforcement officer shall
inspect such rooming house, and if he finds that such conditions or practices
have not been corrected, he shall give notice in writing to the operator that
the latter's license has been suspended. Upon receipt of notice of suspension,
such operator shall immediately cease operation of such rooming house, and no
person shall occupy for sleeping or living purposes any rooming unit therein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Any person whose license to operate a rooming house has been
suspended, or who has received notice from an enforcement officer that his
license is to be suspended, unless existing conditions or practices at his
rooming house are corrected, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the
matter before the city council, under the procedure provided in subsection G of
this section; provided, that if no petition for such hearing is filed within
ten (10) days following the day on which such license was suspended, such
license shall be deemed to have been automatically revoked.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Hearings: Upon request of any license holder, the city council shall in
every case hold a hearing and reach a decision without unreasonable or
unnecessary delay. Every decision of the city council shall be in writing and
be promptly filed in the office of the city clerk. A copy of the decision shall
be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant. All decisions shall require an
affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the city council present at
such hearing. If a decision of the city council reverses an order of the
enforcement officer, he shall take action immediately in accordance with such
decision.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Variances:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Upon request of any license holder, the city council may vary the
application of any provision of this article to any particular case when, in
its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be
contrary to the spirit and purpose of this article or public interest, or when,
in its opinion, the interpretation of the enforcement officer should be
modified or reversed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A decision of the city council to vary the application of any
provision of this article, or to modify an order of the enforcement officer,
shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is made, the
conditions upon which it is made, and the reasons therefor. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-
1994)
10-2A-8: UNFIT STRUCTURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
Â Â Â UNLAWFUL STRUCTURE: One found in whole or in part to be occupied by more
persons than permitted under this article, or was erected, altered or occupied
contrary to law.
Â Â Â UNSAFE EQUIPMENT: Includes any boiler, heating equipment, elevator, moving
stairway, electrical wiring or device, flammable liquid containers or other
equipment on the premises or within the structure which is in such disrepair or
condition that such equipment is a hazard to life, health, property or safety
of the public or occupants of the premises or structure.
Â Â Â UNSAFE STRUCTURE: One in which all or part thereof is found to be dangerous
to life, health, property, or the safety of the public or the occupants of the
structure by not providing minimum safeguards for protection from fire or
because such structure contains unsafe equipment or is so damaged, decayed,
dilapidated, structurally unsafe, or of such faulty construction or unstable
foundation that partial or complete collapse is likely.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Determination Of Unfit Structure: A structure is unfit for human
occupancy or use whenever any enforcement officer finds that such structure is
unsafe, unlawful, or because of the degree to which the structure is in
disrepair or lacks maintenance, is unsanitary, vermin or rat infested, contains
filth or contamination, or lacks ventilation, illumination, sanitary or heating
facilities or other essential equipment required by this article, or because
the location of the structure constitutes a hazard to the occupants of the
structure or to the public.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Condemnation Of Structure: When a structure or part thereof is found by
the enforcement officer to be unsafe, or when a structure or part thereof is
found unfit for human occupancy or use, or is found unlawful, such structure
shall be condemned pursuant to the provisions of this article and shall be
placarded, vacated and shall not be reoccupied without approval of the
enforcement officer. Unsafe equipment shall be placarded and placed out of
service.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Vacant Structures: If the structure or part thereof is vacant and unfit
for human habitation, occupancy or use and is not in danger of structural
collapse, the enforcement officer shall be permitted to post a placard of
condemnation on the premises and order the structure closed up so as not to be
an attractive nuisance. Upon failure of the owner to close up the premises
within the time specified in the order, any enforcement officer shall cause the
premises to be closed through any available public agency or by contract or
arrangement with private persons, and the cost thereof shall be charged against
the real estate upon which the structure is located, and shall be a lien upon
such real estate, and shall be included as part of any fine assessed pursuant
to section
10-2A-11 of this article. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-9: INSPECTIONS:
Any enforcement officer is hereby authorized and directed to make inspections
to determine the condition of dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and
premises in the city in order that he may perform his duty of safeguarding the
health and safety of the occupants of dwellings and of the general public as
follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Inspection Of Dwellings:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â One-Family, Two-Family And Multiple-Family Dwellings: Any
enforcement officer is hereby authorized, with the consent of the owner or
occupant, to enter, examine and survey at all reasonable times all one-family
dwellings, two-family dwellings and multiple-family dwellings and dwelling
units therein, including the surrounding premises and exterior property. The
owner or occupant of the above or the person in charge thereof may consent to
give any enforcement officer free access to such premises at all reasonable
times for the purpose of inspection, examination and survey.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Other Dwellings: Any enforcement officer shall have the right to
inspect all other dwellings including those requiring a license to operate and
all dwellings open to the public for the purpose of examination and survey at
all reasonable times. The owner or occupant of every dwelling, dwelling unit
and rooming unit, or the persons in charge thereof, shall give the enforcement
officer free access to such dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit and its
premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspection, examination and
survey.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Right Of Access:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall give the owner
thereof, or his agent or employee, access to any part of such dwelling or
dwelling unit, or its premises, at all reasonable times for the purpose of
making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with
the provisions of this article or with any lawful rule or regulation adopted or
any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Where consent to inspection is not given to the enforcement officer,
he shall be authorized to seek a warrant requiring said owner or occupant to
permit the inspection. The enforcement officer shall be authorized to seek such
warrant in any court of competent jurisdiction and shall be required to
establish probable cause for inspection. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-10: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in
conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety or health
ordinance or code of the city existing on the effective date hereof, the
provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and
protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in
conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the city existing
on the effective date hereof which establishes a lower standard for the
promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provisions
of this article shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes
are hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in
conflict with this article. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)
10-2A-11: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation violating any
provision of this article shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In the case of any violation of this article, any enforcement officer
may institute an appropriate action or proceeding at law to exact the penalty
provided above. Also, such enforcement officer shall refer such matter to the
city council. The city council may direct the city attorney to proceed at law
or in equity against any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation
determined to be in violation of this article for the purpose of ordering said
person, firm, entity or corporation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To restrain, correct or remove the violation or refrain from any
further execution of work;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â To restrain or correct the erection, installation, maintenance,
repair or alteration of any structure, dwelling or dwelling unit;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â To require the removal of any items found to be in violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â To prevent the occupation or use of any structure, dwelling or
dwelling unit which is not in compliance with the provisions of this article;
or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Such other actions as may be necessary and proper for full
enforcement of this article. (Ord. 94-O-31, 7-5-1994)

twenty four (24) hour per day basis and capable of reasonably and effectively
responding to tenant needs in such situations.

required pursuant to the terms of this section. Further, no lessee shall
execute a lease without first determining that such required information is

10-2C-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the CITY OF
HIGHWOOD RENTAL PROPERTY SAFETY ORDINANCE OF 2003. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003;
amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this article:
BUILDING OFFICIAL: The building official for the city of Highwood or his
designee; also the code official.
CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE: A certificate issued by the code official certifying
that the applicant for such certificate and/or owner of a residential rental
premises or dwelling unit, subject to inspection, is currently in compliance
with city ordinances. Such certificate may be temporary or conditional.
CITY: The city of Highwood, Illinois.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Highwood, Illinois.
CODE OFFICIAL: The code official for the city of Highwood or his designee; also
the building official.
DWELLING: Any structure which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used
for living or sleeping by human occupants.
DWELLING UNIT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The permanent or temporary abode of a family, an individual, or group
of individuals.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A single unit providing complete independent facilities for the
exclusive use of the family, individual, or group of individuals, including,
but limited to, permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and
sanitation.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: Any of the following: building official, code official,
health inspector, police chief, or fire chief of the city of Highwood,
Illinois, or their designees. Any "enforcement officer" may discharge the
duties of the code official.
FAMILY: An individual, or two (2) or more persons related by blood or marriage
or adoption, living together in a dwelling unit, or a group of not more than
four (4) persons who need not be related by blood or marriage or adoption,
living as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit, and sharing common
facilities as considered reasonably appropriate for a family related by blood,
marriage or adoption.
GUEST: A person who is a temporary resident (less than 10 percent of the time)
of a dwelling unit and who does not utilize the unit as a legal address for any
purpose. "Guest" shall also mean a person who occupies a rental unit without
providing compensation for the privilege of occupying such rental unit.
HOTEL: A building which is arranged and designed for rooms or suites reserved
with bathroom and closet space, located on a single zoning lot to provide
living and sleeping accommodations for transient or temporary guests, making
use of the facilities for a period of less than thirty (30) days and with no
provisions in the said rooms or suites for cooking facilities.
INITIAL INSPECTION: The first inspection of a dwelling unit for the purpose of
determining compliance with the city ordinances and codes including, but not
limited to, the city building, zoning, property maintenance, fire and life
safety codes.
LET FOR OCCUPANCY OR LET: To permit, provide or offer possession of occupancy
of a dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, building, premises or structure to
a person who is or who is not the legal owner of record thereof, pursuant to a
written or unwritten lease, agreement or license, or pursuant to a recorded or
unrecorded agreement of contract for the sale of the premises. The term "of the
letting" shall be the period which has been agreed upon during which the rent
or other compensation is fixed and/or no further agreement or permission is
needed to remain in occupancy.
MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE OCCUPANCY: The maximum number of persons permitted to occupy
a dwelling unit as determined under the zoning regulations and/or property
maintenance code.
MOTEL: An establishment consisting of a group of attached or detached living or
sleeping accommodations with bathroom and closet space, located on a single
zoning lot and designed for use temporarily by transient automobile tourists,
making use of the facilities for a period of less than thirty (30) days, with
garage attached or parking space conveniently located to each unit, including
auto courts, motels, motor lodges or other similar type uses, and which
furnishes customary hotel services.
OCCUPANT: A person occupying a dwelling unit or using the property as a legal
address for any purpose.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, association, organization, firm, entity,
limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership or corporation
having a legal or equitable ownership interest in the fee title to the
property.
PERSON: Any firm, entity, limited liability company, partnership, limited
partnership, corporation, association, organization or any group acting as a
unit, as well as a natural person.
PROPERTY AGENT: A person, operator, firm, partnership, corporation, or other
legal entity designated by the property owner to the code official to manage
any residential rental property including the authority to receive notices or
citations.
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE: That code adopted in section
10-1-1 of this title, with those amendments provided in section
10-1-4-5 of this title.
REINSPECTION: An inspection of a dwelling unit to determine the landlord's or
owner's correction of ordinance and code deficiencies cited during a prior
inspection.
RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY: Any dwelling unit or rooming unit let or intended
to be let to a family, person or persons for any amount of rent or other
compensation for the use of the rental property as a dwelling.
ROOMING UNIT: A room or a suite of rooms forming a single, separate, habitable
unit to be used for living, or for living and sleeping, or for sleeping, but
not for cooking and eating purposes.
STATUS REINSPECTION: Any additional reinspection of a rental dwelling unit that
occurs after the initial inspection and reinspection. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007; 2009 Code)
10-2C-3: SCOPE; CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; INSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â This article applies to all residential rental properties and all
dwelling units therein that are leased in whole or in part as a rental dwelling
unit, except those properties specifically excluded. All owners of residential
rental housing properties in the city, not specifically excluded, shall be
required to obtain an inspection in order to obtain a certificate of compliance
evidencing that the premises is in compliance with the building, zoning,
property maintenance, fire, and life safety codes and other applicable
ordinances and codes of the city which are referenced codes. The code official
shall perform a physical inspection of the residential rental property
including the building exterior, common areas, basement, and the interior of
each residential unit. Accessory structures including, but not limited to,
garages and storage buildings and appurtenances such as sidewalks, driveways,
parking facilities and retaining walls, which are on the property, are
included. However, this article does not apply to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Nursing homes, rest homes, and convalescent care facilities licensed
by the state of Illinois; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Hotel or motel rooms exclusively let for short term occupancy (for a
period of less than 30 days) and otherwise regulated by the city. (Ord. 13-O-
16, 3-7-2013)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â At the time of the receipt of a duly completed initial application or
renewal application and the required verification, and the application fee
having been paid, the code official and the applicant shall schedule an
inspection of the subject premises. Provided, however, nothing in this article
shall be construed to prevent the code official from scheduling and/or lawfully
seeking an inspection of any dwelling unit where a certificate of compliance
has expired and a renewal certificate of compliance has not been issued, or
when the code official has reasonable belief that a violation of the property
maintenance code or other applicable ordinances and codes, including the
building code or zoning regulations, have been violated.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Annually, the code official shall inspect all dwelling units occupied
or held or offered for letting or occupancy within the city according to the
schedule of inspections established by the code official, unless a violation is
reasonably suspected, in which case, the code official may make other and more
frequent inspections to seek compliance with the property maintenance code or
other applicable city ordinances and codes.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The code official shall develop and maintain a citywide inventory of
all dwelling units occupied or held or offered for occupancy which, to the code
official's best knowledge and belief, is based on the applications for
certificates of compliance, their renewal, or any other reasonable information
available, and establishing a schedule of inspections that will ensure that all
such dwelling units and associated premises shall be inspected at least once
each year. Provided, however, upon probable cause that a violation exists,
where required, additional inspections may be made to take steps needed to
bring the subject building, dwelling unit and/or associated premises into
compliance with the property maintenance code and other applicable ordinances
and codes.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Where an inspection is made pursuant to an initial application or a
renewal application, the code official shall endeavor to schedule the
inspection with the applicant or the applicant's agent at a time and on a date
during normal city business hours which is convenient to the code official and
the applicant or agent. In all other cases, the inspection shall be made at
such other time which the code official establishes.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In the event the applicant, owner or tenant of the premises to be
inspected refuses entry to the premises to the code official, or in the event
the owner or his agent is uncooperative in scheduling the inspection, the code
official may seek the appropriate warrant from the circuit court of the
nineteenth judicial circuit in Lake County for an administrative warrant.
Refusal or failure of the owner or owner's agent to permit the code official to
make the scheduled inspection shall be grounds for refusal to issue a
certificate of compliance, renewal certificate of compliance or temporary
certificate of compliance.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Inspection of the premises, to the extent reasonable and possible,
shall be conducted with the consent and cooperation of the applicant or the
designated agent.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Each inspection shall be made by the code official and shall be for the
purpose for determining compliance with the provisions of this article. The
inspections provided for in this article shall be of the mechanical, sanitary,
safety and structural components and interior and exterior, walls, walks and
driveways, parking facilities, rooms, roof and other areas open to plain view
from the ground or from the air, and all internal common areas, such as
vestibules, halls, stairways and components, and all other areas within the
structure which pertain to each of the construction elements and room
configurations of the structure being inspected, or in which the owner has an
equal right to authorize entry.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Any violations found as a result of the inspection shall be set forth
in a written notice to the owner(s) or owner's agent as designated on the
application form. A copy of such notice of violation may, but need not be, left
with the occupier or occupiers of the rental property.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â All notices under this article, including notices of violations, shall
be sent to the owner at the address stated on the application or to the person
designated on the application form as the owner's agent. In the absence of a
person designated to receive notice, the notice shall be sent by U.S. mail,
postage prepaid, to the last taxpayer of record shown on the records of the
county treasurer as responsible for the real estate taxes for the property in
violation. Such mailing shall be deemed to be service of such notice. (Ord.
2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-4: APPLICATION FOR AND CONTENTS OF CERTIFICATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No certificate of compliance shall be issued except upon written

Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A survey of the property and floor plan of the basement and each

square footage of the floor area of each room, closet and basement, if any.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A parking site plan showing the layout of any parking spaces for the
premises, spaces devoted to tenant use, and if sufficient parking (computed per
the city zoning regulations) is not provided on site for the dwelling unit and/

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A copy of the most current report of compliance with the zoning
regulations for each premises, or evidence that the individual has owned the
premises continuously since prior to the enactment of the 1996 zoning
regulations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A copy of any document of title, such as a deed or title policy.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A certified copy of any land trust, if title is held in trust.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A certified copy of any limited partnership agreement or investment
or other trust agreement, if title is held in a land trust.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A copy of the operating agreement, if title is held by a limited
liability company.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A copy of any lease requested by the code official for any unit or
units on the premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â A copy of the most recent alarm certification (for premises in which
an alarm is required).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â A copy of the most recent sprinkler certification (for premises in
which a sprinkler is installed).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â A copy of the most recent elevator inspection (for premises in
which an elevator is installed).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Further, such application shall contain such further information
required by the code official, including:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The full legal name; business and home address; home and daytime
telephone numbers; home and daytime fax numbers; e-mail address and federal
employer identification number of each and every owner, and/or persons holding
an interest (legal or equitable) in the property. This shall include
beneficiaries of any land trust holding title; limited partners; shareholders,
officers and directors of corporations; and members and managers of limited
liability companies. Further, the application shall include the same
information for any property manager and/or person designated as the agent of
the owner for purposes of scheduling inspectors and/or receiving notices; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The name and phone number of an owner, property manager, agent of
the owner, or management company who, in an emergency situation, will be
accessible to tenants on a twenty four (24) hour per day basis and capable of
reasonably and effectively responding to tenant needs in such situations; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The address of the property to be occupied; the total number of
properties subject to the terms of this article which are owned by the
applicant within the city (or in which the applicant has any interest), the
number of units at each premises, and whether the units are occupied or vacant
at the time of application; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The date the property was acquired; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A list of the rental dwelling units at the property, the number of
occupants of each unit and the rental per month for each unit; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The full name and mailing address of the person to whom any notices
are to be sent under the provisions of this article ("the notice address").
Until written notification of a change of the notice address is received by the
city, any notice to be provided under the provisions of this article, the
property maintenance code or other applicable ordinances and codes shall be
deemed sufficiently given if deposited in the United States mail, postage
prepaid, and addressed to the person at the address listed in that portion of
the application.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Each application for a certificate of compliance or a renewal
certificate of compliance shall be accompanied by the application fee and/or
late fee due.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The first application for a certificate of compliance, accompanying
attachments and fee shall be due within sixty (60) days of the effective date
hereof for all residential rental property presently occupied and for all
residential rental property presently held out for occupancy, or at least
thirty (30) days prior to the holding out of any rental property for occupancy
at any time after the effective date hereof.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Each application shall be signed by the owner and shall be subject to
penalty of perjury.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Each application form and certificate of compliance issued thereon
shall apply to one single tract or parcel of real estate with the improvements
thereon, and operated as one proprietary unit.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Each certificate of compliance shall contain the date of issuance of
the certificate of compliance, the name or names of the owner or owners of
record to whom the certificate of compliance is issued, the address of the
dwelling unit for which the certificate of compliance applies, the maximum
occupancy for the dwelling unit at the address on the certificate of compliance
and any and all such other information as the code official may determine. Such
certificate of compliance shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place
in each residential rental unit at all times. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd.
Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-5: FEES:
