10-2C-6: REINSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â When an inspection of a residential rental property reveals any
violations of applicable codes, a compliance period shall be set by the code
official, based on the minimum reasonable amount of time necessary to correct
all violations given their number and severity. This compliance period shall in
no event exceed thirty (30) days, unless extended by written order of the code
official, in his sole discretion.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A status reinspection will be conducted at the end of the compliance
period, or sooner at the request of the owner. If the reinspection reveals that
outstanding code violations remain, the applicant shall be charged a
reinspection fee. The code official shall set another compliance date for
remediation of all remaining code violations. If previously issued, the
certificate of compliance shall remain in effect during this reinspection time
period. If, at the time of the reinspection, the code official finds that the
requirements of this article or any applicable city codes have not been met, or
that any information provided in the application is false, the certificate of
compliance shall be suspended, and revocation proceedings shall commence in
accordance with this article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Reinspections shall be made as often as reasonably necessary to ensure
corrective action to cure any violations of the relevant ordinances or
regulations, and to bring the building, dwelling unit and premises into
compliance, and if necessary, the appropriate warrant may be sought for these
purposes based upon the probable cause or causes supplied by the noted
violations.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Individual units subject to the provisions of this article that become
vacant during the course of the year may not be reoccupied until they are
reinspected and approved for occupancy. Such reinspection shall be conducted by
the city at no charge. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-7: RENEWALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any existing certificate of compliance in good standing is eligible to
be renewed annually. Prior to the annual expiration date of each certificate of
compliance, the applicant shall submit an application for certificate of
compliance renewal, which shall include all the information required in section
10-2C-4 of this article, or a statement indicating that such information is
still current. Following submittal of the renewal application and fee, the
property shall be scheduled for inspection by the code official.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Renewal fees shall be paid at the time of the renewal application.
Renewal fees paid after the renewal date shall be considered delinquent, and
the existing certificate of compliance shall be suspended until such time as a
renewal application is made and the fee and late fee are paid. Any such
suspension shall only remain in effect for a period of sixty (60) days, at
which time, if the renewal application, renewal fee and late fee are not
received by the office of the city, the certificate of compliance shall be
revoked. Such revocation shall be automatic and shall not be subject to any
hearing process set forth herein. A holder of a certificate of compliance
revoked for nonpayment of fees and penalties shall be so notified by the city
and shall immediately cease occupancy of the dwelling unit/premises under the
revoked certificate of compliance. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-
4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-8: EFFECT OF CERTIFICATE; NONTRANSFERABILITY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Once a certificate of compliance is issued, it shall be valid and
continued until the sooner of the any of the following occurs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â There is a change of occupancy of the residential dwelling unit
covered by the certificate of compliance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The residential improvements to the property covered by the
certificate of compliance are damaged or destroyed to the extent that the
residential unit is uninhabitable as determined by the code official.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The certificate of compliance is lawfully revoked or suspended.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Expiration of one year from the issuance of said certificate of
compliance.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Provided however, nothing in this section shall prohibit or prevent the
city from requesting the owner or tenant in possession for a voluntary
inspection of the property covered by the certificate of compliance if the city
believes that a violation of the city's ordinance has taken place or is taking
place upon the property. Provided further, nothing in this section shall be
construed to prevent the city from seeking a lawful administrative search
warrant at any time circumstances exist which would support the issuance of
such a warrant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If a certificate of compliance is revoked or is no longer valid (as
provided herein), a renewal certificate of compliance shall be obtained using
the same procedure and application fee as are required for an original
certificate of compliance.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Once issued, a certificate of compliance or a temporary certificate of
compliance cannot be transferred or assigned to another residential dwelling
unit or to a successor owner acquiring the property. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-9: WAIVER OF INSPECTIONS:
If the owner of a residential rental property is issued a certificate of
compliance for a period of two (2) consecutive years by reason of successful
annual inspections and renewals, then renewal inspections shall be required
only every other year after the third year, and shall continue thereafter on a
biennial basis. If at any time the property fails its biennial inspection, the
property shall revert to an annual inspection schedule for another three (3)
year period. The term "fails" shall be determined by the code official, where
he finds less than ninety percent (90%) compliance with all applicable city
codes in any single unit. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-
2007)
10-2C-10: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Let to another for use or occupancy any residential rental property
without a current and valid city certificate of compliance for such residential
rental property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fail to file an application required hereunder or to fail to provide
required information.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â To erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, maintain, fail to
maintain, provide, fail to provide, occupy, let to another, or occupy or permit
another person to occupy any residential dwelling unit or residential premises,
property, building, dwelling unit, structure or equipment regulated by the
property maintenance code or any other applicable ordinances and codes, or
cause such things to be done contrary to, or in conflict with, or in violation
of this article or in violation of any of the provisions of the property
maintenance code or any other applicable ordinances and codes, or to fail to
obey a lawful order of the code official, or to remove or deface a placard or
notice posted under the provisions of this article, the property maintenance
code or any other applicable ordinances and codes.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â To operate, maintain, offer to let or rent within the city a
residential rental property subject to the provisions of this article, whether
vacant or not, without first obtaining a certificate of compliance or a
temporary certificate of compliance as provided in this article.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â To occupy a residential rental property or for any owner or property
agent to allow anyone to occupy a residential rental property for which a
current certificate of compliance or a temporary certificate of compliance has
not been issued, as provided in this article.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â To offer for rent or to occupy any vacant dwelling unit or any dwelling
unit that becomes vacant property for which a certificate of compliance or
temporary certificate of compliance is required and has not been obtained or is
under suspension or revocation. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4,
2-6-2007)
10-2C-11: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
A certificate of compliance which is in force may be suspended or revoked by
the code official upon finding conditions or practices pertaining to a property
or a dwelling unit in violation of the provisions of this article or other
applicable city ordinances and regulations. This may include any of the
following causes:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement contained in the
application for certificate of compliance.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Conducting activities on the premises in such manner as to constitute a
breach of the peace, or a menace to the health, safety, or welfare of the
public, or a disturbance of the peace and comfort of the residents of the city,
or upon recommendation of any official charged with approving health and/or
safety requirements on the premises.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Expiration or cancellation of any required bond or insurance, and/or
expiration or cancellation of the city occupancy permit.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Actions unauthorized or beyond the scope of the certificate of
compliance granted.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Violation of provisions of this article, city ordinances applicable to
the premises for which the certificate of compliance has been granted, or
regulations or laws of the state so applicable.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Failure to continuously comply with all conditions required as
precedent to the approval or renewal of the certificate of compliance,
including, but not limited to, failure to comply with all requirements of any
inspection or reinspection. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-
2007)
10-2C-12: APPEALS:
Any person notified of violations as provided in this article, or any person
denied a certificate of compliance, or any person whose certificate of
compliance has been suspended or revoked shall have the right of appeal as
provided in this section.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â When a certificate of compliance is suspended for any of the items set
forth herein, the city shall send notice to the certificate of compliance
holder. The notice shall include the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Description of the property sufficient for identification.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A statement of the reasons for the suspension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â An explanation of the certificate of compliance holder's right to
appeal the suspension.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the certificate of compliance was suspended based upon a
reinspection failure, the certificate of compliance holder may request another
reinspection prior to revocation. If, upon reinspection, the city finds that
the residential rental property in connection with which the notice was issued
is now in compliance with this article, the code official may reinstate the
certificate of compliance.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person whose certificate of compliance has been suspended or
revoked by the code official shall be entitled to appeal the suspension or
revocation by filing an appeal with the zoning board of appeals. A request in
written form, specifying in detail the reason for the appeal (and with all
documents relied upon), shall be filed with the city clerk. The city clerk
shall forthwith transmit to the zoning board of appeals all of the papers
constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken, which
shall be sufficient to cause the zoning board of appeals to set a reasonable
time and place for the hearing of the appeal and shall give notice thereof to
the persons appealing and to the code official from whom the appeal is taken.
The board shall hear and decide the appeal within a reasonable time. At the
hearing, parties of interest may appear in person or by agent or attorney.
Except as set forth below, such an appeal shall operate as a stay of the
revocation or suspension until such time as the board renders a decision on the
appeal. The hearing shall be according to the rules and regulations promulgated
by the board. A written or recorded transcript of the proceedings shall be
maintained for the purposes of appeal and consideration hereunder.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Following the hearing, the board may fashion an appropriate ruling,
revoking the certificate of compliance; continuing the suspension for a
definite compliance date (not to exceed 30 days) with revocation being the
penalty for noncompliance; or dismissing the charges and reinstating the
certificate of compliance. The concurring vote of four (4) members of the
zoning board shall be necessary to recommend reversal of any order, decision,
or determination of the code official or to decide in favor of the applicant,
of any matter upon which it is authorized by this article to render decisions.
The board's decision shall be in writing and shall be filed with the city clerk
and mailed to the person making the appeal after the conclusion of the hearing,
by certified mail, return receipt requested.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Decisions of the zoning board of appeals dismissing any charge and/or
reinstating the certificate of compliance shall be referred directly to the
mayor and city council for hearing as set forth below. Further, any person
having filed an appeal with the zoning board of appeals and having received
findings and recommendations which such person is aggrieved, may file an appeal
to the mayor and city council. Such appeal shall be in writing and may be in
the form of a letter (which shall contain a brief statement of the basis for
appeal), and shall be filed within fourteen (14) days of mailing of the board's
written decision.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â A hearing reviewing any appeal or any decision of the zoning board of
appeals dismissing any charge and/or reinstating the certificate of compliance
shall be conducted by the mayor and city council after receipt of the appeal or
decision of the zoning board of appeals. At the conclusion of the procedures
set forth in this section, the city council may make such findings and
determination as it determines appropriate. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd.
Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â A written or recorded transcript of the proceedings shall be maintained
for the purposes of appeal and consideration hereunder. All final
administrative decisions of the mayor and city council under this section shall
be subject to judicial review pursuant to the provisions of the state
administrative review law, and all amendments and modifications thereof, and
the rules adopted pursuant thereto 1 . The term "administrative decision" is
defined as in section 3-101 of the administrative review law 2 . (Ord. 2003-O-
75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007; 2009 Code)
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â A hearing officer may be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of
the city council, to conduct any hearing under subsection G of this section. In
any hearing conducted by a hearing officer pursuant to this subsection, the
officer shall, upon conclusion of the hearing, prepare a written recommended
decision that includes findings of fact and conclusions. The recommended
decision shall be filed with the city clerk and mailed to the parties not later
than thirty (30) calendar days after the conclusion of the hearing. Upon
receipt of such a recommended decision, the city may, without holding a further
hearing, either:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Adopt the recommended decision, including findings of fact and
conclusions submitted by the hearing officer; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Adopt the findings of fact and conclusions contained in the
recommended decision, modify the decision, and adopt the recommended decision
as so revised; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Based upon the record of the hearing, modify the findings of fact,
conclusions or decisions, and adopt the recommended decision as so revised.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â In all matters to be considered by the mayor and city council, there
shall be transmitted to the mayor and city council, in addition to the
materials in the subsection H of this section, the transcript or recording
required hereunder. Further, said materials may be reasonably supplemented by
such further written memorandum and written evidence as may be desired by the
person taking the appeal, the code official or the hearing officer. In their
sole discretion, the mayor and city council may require such additional
evidence or presentation before it by the person taking the appeal, the code
official or the hearing officer.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â The cost of any hearing (including the cost of the transcript or
recording of the proceedings) shall be borne by the ultimate nonprevailing
party. The hearing costs (attorney fees, expert witness fees and/or other
expenses) incurred by any person or property owner at either a hearing with the
zoning board of appeals or city council shall be borne solely by such person.
The hearing costs (attorney fees, expert witness fees and/or other expenses)
incurred by the city at any hearing before the zoning board of appeals or city
council shall be imposed upon any nonprevailing person or property owner.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â A certificate of compliance may be revoked when an appeal has not been
filed within twenty (20) days following the issuance of an order of suspension,
or if the suspension is sustained after an appeal.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â A certificate of compliance shall be revoked and the rental property
shall not be let or occupied if the decision being appealed is based upon one
or more of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Structural, mechanical, plumbing or electrical code violations,
which present a substantial risk of harm to the health or safety of the
occupants or the potential occupants of the subject premises, as determined by
the code official.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The failure of the owner or applicant to provide a completed
application for a certificate of compliance or a renewal certificate of
compliance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The occupancy of the dwelling unit exceeds the permitted maximum
occupancy under the property maintenance code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â In the opinion of the code official, emergency conditions exist that
require the immediate vacating of a structure as specified in the city property
maintenance and/or housing code.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â A certificate of compliance that has been properly revoked as herein
provided shall not be reinstated. The certificate of compliance holder may,
however, obtain a new certificate of compliance after all violations have been
corrected and following the procedures for obtaining a new certificate of
compliance as set forth in this article, including the payment of all
applicable fees.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Whenever a certificate of compliance is revoked, following a hearing or
twenty (20) days after suspension where no hearing was requested, the code
official shall send notice to the certificate of compliance holder at the
address provided on the most recent certificate of compliance application on
file with the city. Said notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt
requested. In the case of revocation of a certificate of compliance for
residential rental property, the code official shall also notify all tenants
and occupants of the property by posting a notice on all entrances of the
residential rental structure. The notice to be posted and shall contain the
following language:
Â Â Â Â Â Â You are hereby notified that the Certificate of Compliance for this
building has been revoked pursuant to the ordinances of the City. You must
vacate this building within 60 days of the date of this notice. If you fail to
vacate this building you will be in violation of the ordinances of the City,
and could also be subject to fines as set forth in the ordinances of the City,
including a fine of up to $750.00 per day of violation.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â Whenever an owner or property agent of a residential rental property
fails to obtain a certificate of compliance for said property with the city,
the code official shall notify all tenants or occupants of the residential
rental property by posting a notice on all entrances to the residential rental
property. The notice to be posted shall contain the following language:
Â Â Â Â Â Â You are hereby notified that the owner or agent for this building has
failed to obtain a Certificate of Compliance for this residential rental
property as required by the ordinances of the City. You must vacate this
building within 60 days of the date of this notice. If you fail to vacate this
building you will be in violation of the ordinances of the City, including a
fine of up to $750.00 per day of violation.
(Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)

10-2C-13: TERMINATION OF WATER SERVICE:
Termination of water service shall apply in those instances where a certificate
of compliance is revoked for nonpayment of fees and penalties. Property owners
who continue to operate in violation of the provisions of this article shall be
subject to water service termination, pursuant to procedures as set forth in
the ordinances of the city having to do with water service 1 , in addition to
any and all remedies available to the city under the provisions of the city
ordinances, state statutes or other applicable law and regulations, including,
but not limited to, the ability of the code official to cite any and all
individuals operating without a certificate of compliance as required
hereunder. Occupancy of such property shall be immediately prohibited and shall
not be reoccupied until such time as the owner is in full compliance with all
laws, regulations and the requirements of this article. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)

1 1. See title 9, chapter 1 of this code.
10-2C-14: OTHER INSPECTIONS NOT AFFECTED:
This article shall not be construed to repeal other inspections required under
the city ordinances, including those required for transfer of real property, or
to restrict the authority of the city to inspect any property or to seek
penalties for violations of other ordinances or regulations of the city. (Ord.
2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-15: OFFICIAL RECORDS:
An official record shall be kept of all business and activities specified in
the provisions of this article. All applications, final decisions, permits,
certificates of compliance and the like issued by the code official shall be in
writing and shall be maintained in the permanent records of the building
department. All such records shall be open to public inspection as are
consistent with the freedom of information act of the state at all appropriate
times and according to reasonable rules to maintain the integrity and security
of such records. However, the failure of the city to maintain or produce such
records shall not be a defense to any action hereunder. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-16: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The code official shall have the power as necessary, in the interest of public
health, safety and general welfare, to adopt and promulgate rules and
regulations interpreting and implementing the provisions of this article and to
achieve the intent hereof. Such rules shall be consistent with the standards,
procedures, and requirements established by this article and shall not have the
effect of waiving structural or fire performance requirements or violating
accepted engineering practices involving public safety. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-17: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The code official may appoint and be assigned any such number of
officers, technical assistants, inspectors and other consultants or employees
as shall be approved by the city council and as shall be necessary for the
administration of this article. The code official is authorized to designate
another employee of the city as his deputy who shall exercise the functions of
his office during any temporary absence or disability of the code official.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The code official, or his designee, shall be exclusively responsible
for scheduling of inspections and issuing of certificates of compliance.
However, any enforcement officer may enforce the other provisions of this
article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An official or employee connected with the enforcement of this article
shall not be engaged in or directly or indirectly connected with the furnishing
of labor, materials or appliances for the construction, alteration or
maintenance of the building or the preparation of construction documents
therefor, unless that person is the owner of the building; nor shall any
officer or employee connected with the enforcement, interpretation or
application of this article engage in any work that is considered a conflict of
interest with his or her official duties or with the interests of the building
department under the statutes and common law of the state. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-
16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-18: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
By enacting and undertaking to enforce this article, the mayor, city council,
city officials, the city and its agents, and employees do not warrant or
guaranty the safety, fitness or suitability of any dwelling in the city. Owners
and occupants should take whatever steps they deem appropriate to protect their
interests, health, safety and welfare. Further, any certificate of compliance
issued shall not be deemed a determination that a property or premises is in
compliance with any city ordinance in any action brought by the city, and shall
not be admitted into evidence (except if sought or stipulated by the city),
unless for the limited purpose of establishing that a certificate has been
issued. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)
10-2C-19: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation, or employee of
same, in violation of any provision of this article shall be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2009 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity
or corporation for violation of the provisions of this article shall not
release such person from paying any fee due and unpaid at the time of such
conviction, nor shall payment of any fee prevent prosecution for violation of
any of the provisions of this article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The amount of any fee due hereunder shall be deemed a debt to the city.
An action may be commenced in the name of the city in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent fee. All unpaid fees shall be
deemed delinquent after they are due and payable.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In the case of any violation of this article, the code official or any
other enforcement officer may request the city attorney to institute an
appropriate action or proceeding in equity or at law to exact the fines and
penalties provided above. Also, the code official or any such enforcement
officer may refer such matter to the mayor or city council. The mayor, city
council, code official or enforcement officer may request and/or direct the
city attorney to proceed at law or in equity against any person, partnership,
firm, entity or corporation determined to be in violation of this article for
the purpose of ordering said person, firm, entity or corporation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To restrain, correct or remove the violation or refrain from any
further violation of this article;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â To restrain or correct the erection, installation, maintenance,
repair or alteration or any structure, dwelling or dwelling unit;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â To require the removal of any items found to be in violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â To prevent the occupation or use of any structure, dwelling or
dwelling unit which is not in compliance with the provisions of this article;
or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For such other actions as may be necessary and proper for full
enforcement of this article.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies
by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. (Ord. 2003-O-75, 12-16-
2003; amd. Ord. 07-O-4, 2-6-2007)

10-3-1: FINDINGS:
The city finds that appearance and design have a direct relationship to the
economic value of property, stability, safety and quality of life. When the
appearance of public areas, business districts, and the residential districts
is good, shoppers, business owners and homeowners exhibit increased confidence
in the community. Conversely, poor appearance, congestion, and lack of proper
maintenance decrease the quality of life and property values and diminish
revenues and opportunities for the city and individuals. As the appearance of
the city is improved, the number and character of customers, investors and
visitors to the business districts will increase, and the residential districts
will benefit. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter and the appearance review committee is:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To promote those qualities in the environment that bring value to the
city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To foster the attractiveness and functional utility of the city as a
place to live and work.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â To preserve the character and quality of the city's heritage by
maintaining the integrity of areas that have maintained a discernible character
or are of special significance.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â To protect public and private investment in the city.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â To raise the level of community expectations for the quality of its
environment.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â To avoid and prevent deterioration of the character and appearance of
the city.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â To provide a favorable environment for residents and business
activities.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â To preserve and enhance the condition of the city and consequently
improve property values.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â To enhance the environment throughout the city.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â To develop and recommend standards for those seeking to develop
properties and/or businesses in the city and to the corporate authorities for
their consideration and implementation. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-3: INTENT AND INTERPRETATION:
The city recognizes that whenever any public authority legislates for the
public good, it affects private rights and interests. Therefore, the city
strives to make laws which strike a fair balance between the needs of the
community as a whole and the needs of the individual. The limitations and
requirements imposed by this chapter are enacted because the reasons for them
are compelling and essential to the future of the city. It is the intent of
this chapter to retain Highwood's cultural heritage and the traditional
excellence of its dining, entertainment and other business establishments,
while also attracting and integrating new business establishments, and to
promote the public safety, health and welfare. Accordingly, this chapter shall
be liberally construed to promote the interests expressed in sections
10-3-1 and
10-3-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-4: RULES AND DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this chapter, the rules and definitions contained in
this section shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly
indicates otherwise.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words
used in the singular number shall include plural number, and the plural the
singular.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The word "may" is permissive.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any words not defined as follows shall be construed in their general
accepted meaning as defined by Webster's Dictionary.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The section headings used in this chapter are included solely for
convenience and shall not affect nor be used in connection with the
interpretation of this chapter.
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
APPEARANCE REVIEW COMMITTEE, ARC OR COMMITTEE: The appearance review committee
of the city of Highwood, established by this chapter.
APPLICANT: A person, firm or legal entity seeking an approval or permit
required by this chapter.
ARCHITECTURAL CHARACTER: The composite or aggregate of the characteristics of
structure, form, materials, and function of a building, group of buildings, or
other architectural composition.
ARCHITECTURAL CONCEPT: The basic aesthetic idea of a building, or group of
buildings or structures, including the site and landscape development, which
produces the architectural character.
ARCHITECTURAL FEATURE: A prominent or significant part or element of a
building, structure, or site.
ARCHITECTURAL STYLE: The characteristic form and detail, as of buildings of a
particular historic period.
ATTRACTIVE: Having qualities that arouse interest and pleasure in the observer.
BERM: An earth embankment that is similar to a mound; except, that it is
extended to become a linear landform. A "berm" is often combined with fencing
or plantings to create a visual or sound barrier.
BUFFER STRIP: Using plant material to buffer surrounding unsightly views or
between unrelated land uses (i.e., parking lot and cars buffered from
neighborhood parks) and/or an area of plant material used to buffer surrounding
views.
BUILDING FACE: Any building surface or exterior wall or projection that is
adjacent to or open to public view from any street, place, alley, thoroughfare,
parking lot, or way. For purposes of this chapter, a building may have more
than one "building face".
BUILDING OFFICIAL/BUILDING DEPARTMENT: The building official or designee, or
building department of the city of Highwood.
BUSINESS DISTRICTS/BUSINESS ZONING: The zoning district(s) in the city of
Highwood in which business uses are permitted, consisting of B-1, B-2, and B-3.
CALIPER: The diameter of a tree's trunk, normally measured at a height of six
inches (6") above ground level.
CANOPY: Also an awning. See definition of Sign, Marquee.
CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL: A certificate issued by the ARC under the provisions
of this chapter that certifies the exterior design features of an applicant's
plans as suitable and as consistent with this chapter. The minutes of the ARC
may suffice.
CITY: The city of Highwood, Lake County, Illinois.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Highwood, Illinois.
COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: A material that will ignite when heated to a temperature
at or below one thousand two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (1,200Â°F) and continues
to burn or glow.
COMPATIBLE: Harmony in the appearance of two (2) or more buildings, structures,
and landscape developments in the same vicinity.
CONTINUITY: Unity of composition between design elements of a building, or a
group of buildings, and the landscape development.
DEAD LOAD: The weight of all permanent structural and nonstructural components
of a building such as walls, floors, roofs, and fixed service equipment.
DESIGN ELEMENTS: The details or components which collectively comprise the
facade, building, structure, sign or landscape plan, including the kind, color
and texture of the materials of such portion and the types of roof, windows,
doors, lights, lighting, attached or ground signs and/or other fixtures
appurtenant to same, as will be open to public view from any street, alley,
place, thoroughfare or way.
DWELLING: Any structure which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used
for living or sleeping by human occupants.
DWELLING UNIT: A. The permanent or temporary abode of a family, an individual,
or group of individuals.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A single unit providing complete independent facilities for the
exclusive use of the family, individual, or group of individuals, including,
but limited to, permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and
sanitation.
EXTERIOR DESIGN FEATURE: The general arrangement of any portion of a facade,
building, structure, sign, and/or landscaping, including the kind, color and
texture of the materials of such portion and the types of roof, windows, doors,
lights, lighting, attached or ground signs or other fixtures appurtenant to
such portions, as will be open to public view from any street, alley, place,
thoroughfare or way.
FACADE: An external face of a building which is open to public view or adjacent
to and mainly faces any street, place, alley, thoroughfare, parking lot, or
way. For purposes of this chapter, a building may have more than one "facade".
FAMILY: An individual, or two (2) or more persons related by blood or marriage
or adoption, living together in a dwelling unit; or a group of not more than
four (4) persons who need not be related by blood or marriage or adoption,
living as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit, and sharing common
facilities as considered reasonably appropriate for a family related by blood,
marriage or adoption.
IBC: The international building code (as adopted by the city of Highwood).
LANDSCAPE PLAN: A detailed, scaled (example, 1/8" = 1'0") drawing showing:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Existing vegetation noting species, size and drip lines of trees two
and one-half inch (21/2") caliper and larger, with a distinction shown between
vegetation to be retained or removed.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â New plant material (proposed trees, shrubs, evergreens, ground cover
and lawns), noting quantities, species (botanical and common names), and size
(in caliper or height at time of installation), and graphically distinguishing
between new and existing plant material and between species of new plant
material; all other existing features such as buildings, fences, walks, etc.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Site furnishings and specialties.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Existing site conditions.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Paving materials.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Height and location of flagpoles, signage, light standards and fences.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Screening, noting materials used as screen, height of screen material,
device or area which requires screening and height of device to be screened.
Please note that exterior areas which require screening include parking, refuse
storage and mechanical equipment.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Stormwater retention/detention areas.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â All other existing features such as buildings, fences, existing
vegetation, walks, etc.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Flow lines for drainage of surface water.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Proposed improvements such as fences, patios and walls.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â External design features, being the general arrangement of any portion
of a building, sign, landscaping or structure and including the kind, color and
texture of the materials of such portion and the types of roof, windows, doors,
lights, attached or ground signs or other fixtures appurtenant to such
portions, as will be open to public view from any street, place or way.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â Logic of design.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Proportions.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â Each landscape plan shall address the functional aspects of landscaping
such as drainage, erosion prevention, wind barriers, provisions for shade,
energy conservation, sound absorption, dust abatement, and reduction of glare.
LIAISON: An alderman appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the
city council, to attend ARC meetings and perform the duties designated to the
liaison by this chapter. "Liaison" shall also include any alternate appointed
to act as liaison to the ARC, or any temporary liaison designated by the mayor
or city council to attend any meeting of the ARC.
LOGIC OF DESIGN: Accepted principles and criteria of validity in the solution
of the problem of design.
LOGO: Any graphic symbol or type characters which are joined on one body as a
trademark or a company signature.
MAYOR: The mayor of the city of Highwood.
MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT: Equipment, devices, and accessories, the use of which
relates to water supply, drainage, heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and
similar purposes.
NEW CONSTRUCTION: Any building or structure which is to be newly constructed or
any addition to a building or structure, including the landscaping, parking and
loading areas and fencing and screening related thereto.
OWNER: All persons having a possessory interest in any property, premises or
sign, the business which any sign identifies, the property where said sign is
located including a leasehold interest (current or expired) or otherwise, and/
or the legal owner of the property.
PROFESSIONALLY DONE: Includes any sign, lettering, or graphic which is produced
by a sign company, design professional, or through electronic or mechanical
means. The term shall not include any sign or graphics that are lettered by
hand using pens, markers, etc.
PROPORTIONS: The balanced relationship of parts of a building, structure,
signs, landscape, or other components to each other and to the whole.
PROPOSED IMPROVEMENT: Any sign (wall, freestanding or temporary), canopy,
awning, building face, facade, landscaping or landscape plan, parking or
loading area, fencing or screening, or other item which requires consideration
and approval of the ARC.
PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY: That land area over which the city has rights, either
through ownership, dedication or easement, to use for public street and utility
purposes or other public use.
RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS/RESIDENTIAL ZONING: Those zoning districts in the city of
Highwood consisting of R-1, R-2, R-3, R-3A and R-4 districts.
SIGN: Any visible name, identification, description, announcement, declaration,
demonstration, display, flag, illustration, insignia, object or device
illuminated or nonilluminated and the structure displaying or supporting any of
the same, affixed directly or indirectly to or upon any building or structure,
or erected or maintained upon land or a premises, which directs attention to an
object, product, place, activity, person, institution, organization, service,
solicitation or business. Any such described items that are visible from the
exterior of the premises, including those items visible through any window or
door are deemed to be "visible" as set forth above and regulated hereunder. No
"sign" shall be removed from the scope of this chapter merely by painting over
or obscuring the sign.
SIGN, ADVERTISING: A sign which directs attention to a profession, business,
activity, commodity, service or entertainment other than one conducted, sold or
offered upon the premises where such sign is located, or within the building to
which such sign is affixed.
SIGN, CONFORMING: A sign which conforms to the provisions of this chapter and
with all applicable ordinances, rules and regulations in effect from time to
time, and shall include a sign for which a variation has been approved.
SIGN FACE: The surface of the sign upon, against or through which the message
of the sign is exhibited.
SIGN, ILLUMINATED: Any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or
outline illuminated by electric lights, luminous tubes or any other means of
artificial illumination.
SIGN, MARQUEE: A rooflike structure of a permanent nature which projects from
the wall of a building and overhangs the public way. A "marquee sign" shall
include canopies and awnings.
SIGN, MONUMENT: A freestanding sign erected at grade level set firmly, or below
the ground surface, on an approved foundation or utilizing a short wall, and
not attached to any building.
SIGN, NONCONFORMING: A sign which does not conform to the provisions of this
chapter, but which complied with this chapter, all applicable ordinances, rules
and regulations in effect at the time of its erection.
SIGN, OBSOLETE: A sign which has become no longer useful for any on site
purpose and/or a nonconforming sign which has been damaged, or fallen into
disrepair, and/or ceases to advertise or identify the business or use for which
a sign permit was issued.
SIGN, PERMANENT: Any sign or sign structure which is affixed or installed and
is intended for long term use.
SIGN, POLE: A freestanding sign erected at grade level supported by one or more
uprights (pole, pylon, standard or structure) and not attached to any building.
"Pole signs" specifically include, without limitation, pylon signs, pole signs,
blades and post signs.
SIGN, PORTABLE: A sign designed to be transported by means of wheels, a sign
converted to an A- or T-frame, a sign attached to a trailer, a menu or sandwich
board sign, or a sign attached to or painted on a vehicle parked and visible
from a street or public right of way.
SIGN, REAL ESTATE: Any sign having not more than two (2) sides which, in whole
or in part, announces the sale or lease of property, excluding subdivision
identification and tract identification signs.
SIGN, TEMPORARY ADVERTISING: A sign not requiring a permit to be issued under
this chapter and that is designed and intended to be displayed for a temporary
and short, and not permanent, period of time, and is for a special, unique,
limited activity such as the announcement of a grand opening, sale, limited
activity, special offering or event.
SIGN, WALL: A sign which is affixed directly to or painted on, or otherwise
inscribed on an exterior wall, including windows and doors, or any business,
retaining wall, or other structure.
SIGNAGE PLAN: A plan which addresses signage for the entire premises at which
signs are proposed. Such "signage plan" shall delineate the proposed sign or
signs, all existing signs, and the relationship between all signs on the
premises. Such "signage plan" shall include proposed materials, color
designations, and proposed dimensions of the sign, along with dimensions of the
premises and structure or structures upon which the signs are to be installed
in order to provide sufficient context for the ARC to review the plan.
TREE: Includes both ornamental trees, being a tree thirty five feet (35') or
under in height at maturity (example, crabapple, hawthorn or magnolia, etc.),
and shade trees, being a tree sixty feet (60') or under in height at maturity
(example, ash, maple, oak, etc.).
USE, SPECIAL: As listed in each zoning district, a use subject to special
provisions and which, because of unique characteristics, cannot be properly
classified as a permitted use.
VARIATION: An exception of the literal provisions of this chapter where strict
enforcement hereof would cause undue hardship owing to circumstances unique to
the individual property or which do not occur generally to land or buildings in
the neighborhood. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
10-3-5: APPEARANCE REVIEW COMMITTEE; PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Established; Appointment; Terms: There is hereby established the
appearance review committee (ARC). The ARC shall consist of five (5) members
appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. The
first members of the ARC shall serve respectively for the following terms: two
(2) for one year; one for two (2) years; one for three (3) years; and one for
four (4) years. The successor of each member so appointed shall serve for a
term of four (4) years.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Vacancies And Removals:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the mayor, with the
advice and consent of the city council, for the unexpired term. If any member
of the ARC fails to attend three (3) consecutive ARC meetings, or fails to
attend one-half (1/2) of all ARC meetings scheduled or called during any twelve
(12) month period, such failure to attend shall constitute cause for the
removal of such member of the ARC. Such member of the ARC may be removed either
by a recommendation by a majority vote of the remaining members of the ARC,
which recommendation shall be forwarded to the city council for action, or by
action of the city council without the recommendation or action by the
remaining members of the ARC. Any vacancy created shall be filled by the mayor
for the duration of the term of said member of the ARC, with the advice and
consent of the city council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Further, the mayor may remove from office any member of the ARC
appointed by him whenever he is of the opinion that the interests of the city
demand such removal. He shall report the reasons for the removal to the city
council at the next regular meeting. If the mayor fails or refuses to report to
the city council the reasons for the removal, or if the council, by a two-
thirds (2/3) vote of all of its members, disapproves the removal, the member
thereupon shall be restored to the office from which he was removed. The vote
shall be by yeas and nays which shall be entered upon the records of the city
council. Any vacancy created shall be filled by the mayor for the duration of
the term of said member of the ARC, with the advice and consent of the city
council.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Officers:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â One member shall be elected by the committee to serve as chair for a
term of two (2) years or until his successor is elected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â One member shall be elected by the committee to serve as secretary
for a term of two (2) years or until his successor is elected.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Meetings: All meetings of the ARC shall be:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Held at the call of the chair and at such other times as the
committee may determine; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Announced by posting, and conducted and recorded in accord with the
open meetings act of the state 1 .
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Expenses: Expenses incurred by the ARC are to be itemized and shall be
borne by the city, following approval of the city council. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-
2005)
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Jurisdiction:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The ARC shall be a recommendatory body only and shall have no final
authority notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary. Any
provision of this chapter which states or implies that the appearance review
committee has final authority is hereby superseded. The appearance review
committee shall make a report and recommendation to the city council in all
cases. The city council shall have final authority over all matters covered by
this appearance code. (Ord. 10-O-08, 3-16-2010)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The ARC shall have jurisdiction over:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â All structures constructed or improved in the business districts
of the city (other than existing, legal, nonconforming single-family
dwellings), regardless of the use or purpose of same, pursuant to the
procedures set forth herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â All structures constructed or improved in any zoning district of
the city, used for business purposes, pursuant to the procedures set forth
herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â All structures newly constructed in any zoning district in the
city containing two (2) or more dwelling units (this excludes structures used
exclusively as single-family dwellings), pursuant to the procedures set forth
herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â All signs constructed, placed or erected in all business
districts and all residential zoning districts of the city, regardless of the
use or purpose of same, other than signage within the town of Fort Sheridan
Subdivision, pursuant to the procedures set forth herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Approval of landscaping plans required pursuant to section
10-3-7 of this chapter, pursuant to the procedures set forth herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Approval of exterior facades required pursuant to section
10-3-8 of this chapter, pursuant to the procedures set forth herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â Any other matter provided for herein or referred thereto by the
mayor or city council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The ARC shall not have jurisdiction over:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Structures, buildings, signage, landscaping or otherwise
belonging to, or constructed by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Structures, buildings, signage, or landscaping which would be
subject to the provisions hereof where the Fort Sheridan joint plan commission
has jurisdiction within the town of Fort Sheridan Subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Any matter exempted by this chapter and any other matter not
provided for herein, or matters for which the city council has assumed
jurisdiction.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Procedural Requirements: In order to properly implement the
requirements of this chapter, the following procedural requirements shall
apply:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Prior to each meeting, the ARC shall promulgate an agenda indicating
all items for consideration and approval at said meeting. Such agenda shall
indicate the property address and a summary of each item proposed for
consideration and approval.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A copy of said agenda shall be distributed to the mayor, each
alderman, the city administrator and city attorney, at least forty eight (48)
hours prior to commencement of the ARC meeting at which such item is to be
considered for approval. The secretary of the ARC shall maintain a file of such
agendas with a certificate indicating that such meeting has been posted as
required pursuant to the requirements of the open meetings act and that the
agenda has been distributed as required by the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â In the event an item has not been placed on the agenda which has
been distributed for approval, then the ARC may defer action on same, or make a
recommendation to the city council as set forth in subsection J of this
section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The city liaison or designee shall be designated to attend all
meetings of the ARC.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The ARC secretary shall cause the preparation of agenda, minutes,
reports, and all other recordkeeping as required by this chapter, statute or
ordinance.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Conditions: No proposed improvement shall be erected or altered until:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A permit, where required by this chapter, or any other ordinance has
been applied for by the applicant; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Approval of the proposed improvement by the ARC, as evidenced by a
report or minutes of the ARC; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Approval by the city council, where required by this chapter, of the
proposed improvement pursuant to the following provisions of this chapter; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A permit, where required by this chapter or any other ordinance, has
been issued by the building department. Any improvements requiring electrical
power shall be subject to the provisions of city ordinances regulating the
installation of electrical equipment; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Payment by applicant of the permit fees required pursuant to all
applicable ordinances; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Filing by the applicant and approval of all required insurance
certificates or indemnification agreements where applicable.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Permit Required: Applicants shall not commence construction on any
proposed improvement based solely upon the approval of the ARC. Regardless of
any approval by the ARC, the applicant shall have no vested right to the
issuance of a permit or construction of the proposed improvement until an
application for a permit has been made by the applicant and approved and issued
by the city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Approval By City Council: Under all circumstances, approval by the city
council of a proposed improvement shall be required prior to the issuance of a
permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The ARC's approval for any proposed improvement which constitutes
"new construction", as defined in section
10-3-4 of this chapter, shall be considered only a recommendation. Such
recommendation shall be forwarded to the city council for final approval, by
motion. Only after approval of such recommendation by the city council shall
the building department issue the permit, provided the other conditions of this
chapter have been satisfied.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The approval of any proposed improvement which does not comply with
the enumerated specifications of this chapter and therefore requires a
variation from the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance shall be
considered as set forth in section
10-3-9 of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â a. As to any other proposed improvement which the ARC has approved,
such approval by the ARC shall be forwarded to the city council for
consideration and approval along with the report or minutes of the ARC
indicating its approval of same, if either:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The liaison attending the meeting of the ARC objects to the
proposed improvement; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The mayor notifies the ARC that he objects to the proposed
improvement.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Such objection and determination by the mayor or liaison shall be
made in the sole discretion of the mayor or liaison. However, if neither the
mayor nor liaison interposes any objection at such meeting, the ARC approval
shall be considered final and forwarded for issuance of permits as required
above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â As to any proposed improvement which the ARC has approved, such
approval by the ARC shall be forwarded to the city council for consideration
and approval along with the report or minutes of the ARC indicating its
approval of same, if such proposed improvement was added to the ARC's agenda
(required above) after the distribution of the agenda. (Ord. 10-O-08, 3-16-
2010)
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Appeals, Review And Variations: Appeals, review and variations shall be
conducted pursuant to the procedures set forth in section
10-3-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)

10-3-6: SIGNS:
10-3-6-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this section
10-3-6 is to regulate signs in such a way as to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Ensure that all signs within the city will adequately identify and
promote the use while being compatible with existing land uses and/or other
buildings within the general area of the sign and/or the city as a whole.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Ensure that each business establishment within the city exhibits at
least one approved wall, window, or monument sign that will adequately identify
and promote the use while being conforming with the provisions of this chapter.
Installation of appropriate approved signage shall be a required condition of
any certificate of occupancy issued for a business establishment.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Enhance the appearance of the city and the business.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Provide a review of the sign and signage plan with regard to size,
location, color, message, construction, materials, proportion and manner of
display to fully promote the intent and purpose of this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Promote such signs that will not confuse, mislead or obstruct the
vision necessary for traffic safety or otherwise endanger the public health,
safety, morals or general welfare.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Ensure that materials and finishes shall be selected for their safety,
durability and wear as well as for their beauty. Proper measures and devices
shall be incorporated for protection against the elements, neglect, damage, and
abuse.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Provide a comprehensive signage plan where more than one sign is
requested for a business, building or premises. Toward that end, the ARC shall
consider a balance that will promote the intent and purpose of this chapter
while allowing adequate identification of the business use. The ARC may
recommend approval of multiple signs where the site conditions warrant same.
However, where multiple signs are approved, the ARC shall consider reducing the
maximum permitted size of each sign or sign type.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Provide a comprehensive signage plan for any planned unit development
(PUD). However, any such signage plan may be more restrictive than the specific
requirements provided for individual business establishments. Further, any PUD
signage is subject to review and approval by the city council and/or plan
commission in addition to review by the ARC.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Provide a signage plan that complements and coordinates with the
building, other structures and exterior design features creating a balance that
will promote the intent and purpose of this chapter while allowing adequate
identification of the business use. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-6-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Applicants shall not commence construction on any proposed improvement
based solely upon the approval by the ARC. Regardless of any approval by the
ARC, the applicant shall have no vested right to the issuance of a permit or
construction of the proposed improvement until an application for a permit has
been made by the applicant and approved and issued by the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An application for a permit shall be made by the applicant upon forms
provided by the building department, shall be signed by the applicant, shall
contain or have attached thereto the following information, and shall be
submitted to the building department:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Name, address and telephone number of applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Location of building, structure or lot to which or upon which the
sign is to be attached or erected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Position of the sign in relation to nearby building structures.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Two (2) blueprints or ink drawings of the plans and specifications
and method of construction and attachment to the buildings or in the ground.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If required by the building department, a copy of stress sheets and
calculations showing that the structure is designed for dead load and wind
pressure in any direction in the amount required by this chapter and all other
laws and ordinances of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Name of the person, firm, corporation or association erecting or
designing the sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Written consent of the legal owner of the building, structure, or
land to which or on which the sign is to be erected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â For any structure that overhangs any public property or public right
of way, a hold harmless agreement and insurance policy in a form acceptable to
the city attorney.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The application shall be supplemented by such other and further
materials as required by the building department or the ARC, including a
signage plan. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-6-3: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Amounts: No person shall erect, install, remove, rehang or maintain
over public property any sign for which a permit is required under the
provisions of this chapter until an insurance policy shall have been filed for
public liability in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
accident and for property damage in the amount of two hundred fifty thousand
dollars ($250,000.00) as herein required.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Conditions: Such insurance policy shall name the city of Highwood as an
additional named insured to indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and
all claims or demands for damages by reason of any negligence of the sign
hanger, contractor, owner, or occupant, or agents of them, or by any reason of
defects in the construction, maintenance, manufacture or design, or damages
resulting from the collapse, failure or combustion of the sign or parts
thereof.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notice Of Cancellation: The obligation herein specified shall remain in
force and effect during the life of every sign or structure and shall not be
cancelled by the principal or surety until after thirty (30) days' written
notice to the city. Nevertheless, the city's failure to cite or otherwise
compel performance of this obligation shall not be construed as a waiver of the
city's right to performance of the obligation. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-6-4: MATERIALS FOR SIGNS:
The following shall apply to material for signs:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Signs shall have a surface or facing of durable and long lasting
material. Materials and finishes shall be reviewed for their safety,
durability, and wear, as well as for their appearance and beauty. Proper
measures and devices shall be incorporated for protection against the elements,
neglect, damage, and abuse. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Wood or approved plastic as provided in the applicable section of the
IBC, as adopted by the city, or other materials of combustible characteristics
similar to wood may be permitted for design features, moldings, capplings,
nailing blocks, letters and latticing when permitted in the applicable section
of the IBC, as adopted by the city, and for other purely ornamental features of
signs in accordance with the approved rules. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd.
2009 Code)
10-3-6-5: RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT SIGNS 1 :
No signs shall be installed or permitted on properties which are residentially
zoned except in accordance with the following provisions:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â For each dwelling unit, one nameplate not exceeding one square foot in
area, indicating name of occupant.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For a structure authorized as a "special use", other than a dwelling
unit, one identification sign not exceeding ten (10) square feet, except a
church bulletin board which shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â For purpose of orientation, direction, warning or information, not
exceeding two (2) square feet.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No electrical signs shall be erected on properties which are
residentially zoned. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)

10-3-6-6: REAL ESTATE SIGNS IN RESIDENTIAL AND BUSINESS DISTRICTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Real estate signs shall be professionally done and in all respects
comply with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Hand lettered signs are not
permitted; except, that the address of the property and phone number may be
neatly hand lettered on a preprinted sign.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In any residential district, or for any residential property in the
business district 1 , one real estate sign not exceeding four (4) square feet
per sign face in area and four feet (4') in height to the highest part of the
sign, announcing the sale or lease of a specific property, shall be permitted
on the property but not on the public right of way. Such sign may be two (2)
sided.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In the business district, for any business use, one real estate sign
not exceeding sixteen (16) square feet in area and six feet (6') in height to
the highest part of the sign, announcing the sale or lease of a specific
property, shall be permitted on the property but not on the public right of
way.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A maximum of three (3) open house signs announcing an open house for a
specific property may be placed in the public right of way no more frequently
than two (2) days in any week. However, such sign shall not be affixed to any
utility pole, municipal sign, structure or otherwise. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
