10-3-6-7: BUSINESS DISTRICT SIGNS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required Signage For Businesses:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Each business establishment within the city shall exhibit at least
one approved wall, window, or monument sign that will adequately identify and
promote the use while being in conformance with the provisions of this chapter.
Installation of appropriate approved signage shall be a required condition of
any certificate of occupancy issued for a business establishment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Each business premises shall display its address on the front of the
premises and on the back door of the premises.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Wall Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Permitted Information: The information contained on a wall sign
shall be limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The legal name (or assumed name) of the business establishment,
which shall not exceed five (5) words. Notwithstanding the above, the name of a
legally established franchise may be displayed in lieu of the legal name of the
business establishment. A listing of services or goods is not permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The logo of the business establishment. The logo of the business
establishment shall be displayed so as to be subordinate in size and prominence
to the name of the business establishment. Further, the colors of corporate
logos may be required to be changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose
of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The date the business was actually established (example,
"Established 1867").
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Size, Design And Location: Any wall sign for which a permit is
required under this subsection shall comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Maximum Size:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the wall area of
the front facade of the space occupied by the business or one hundred (100)
square feet, whichever is less.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The size of the wall area used shall be determined by drawing
a square or rectangle around the lettering/logo of the proposed sign which
encompasses the entire content of the proposed sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The size of signs placed in or on windows or canopies shall
be included in calculating the maximum sign area allowed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The building face area of floors which are not occupied by
the business establishment (example, residential areas above the business
establishment) shall not be used to compute the wall area of the front facade.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Orientation And Location:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Shall be permitted only on the front facade of a building or
upon such other facade of a building:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â Which is adjacent to and mainly faces a street,
thoroughfare, or parking lot used for customers of the building, and which lot
is part of a planned unit development for the parcel upon which the sign is to
be located; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â Which is adjacent to and mainly faces a street,
thoroughfare, or parking lot used for customers of the building, and which lot
is under common ownership with the parcel upon which the sign is to be located.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Such sign may not be located on any other facade of a
building, including a facade which mainly faces an alley.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Number Of Facades: Wall signs identifying the business use of a
premises shall be permitted only upon one of the facades as set forth in
subsection B2b of this section unless a variation is obtained.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Preferred Design Criteria: For any premises, the ARC shall
consider the following preferred design criteria in considering the approval or
recommendation for approval of any sign:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Illuminated "box signs" are not permitted. However,
illuminated "box signs" may be approved in certain exceptional circumstances
where they are deemed to be appropriate due to the location of the sign or
unique site characteristics.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Signs with individually cut, opaque, raised letters on
raceways and illuminated through the use of back lighting (reverse channel
letters) are preferred. Internal illumination of individual letters and/or
logos is not preferred, but may be considered where appropriate. However,
illumination levels shall be regulated to ensure that the illumination is
appropriate in light of the proposed signage, site, and adjoining properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Signage coloring shall complement the development and other
signage within the business district. Neon colors and bright colors are not
preferred, but may be permitted where they are found to enhance a design
element or otherwise are found to be appropriate due to unique site conditions.
In general, signage colors shall be complementary with the proposed
development. White, earth, bronze, gold or other subdued color tones for signs,
lettering and logos are preferred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The ARC may consider allowing corporate logos where
appropriate. However, the colors of corporate logos may be required to be
changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose of this chapter and color
requirements set forth above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â While signage identifying the business is limited as set
forth herein, limited additional design elements may be permitted on any
structure where determined appropriate by the ARC, in the exercise of its
discretion, subject to review and approval by the city council. Such design
elements may include decorative murals, which do not specifically identify the
business, lettering, phrases, decorative etchings, woodwork and/or public art
which is intended to enhance the visual appeal of a structure or premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Shape And Color: The shape of all signs shall relate to the
building facade, facade of adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent
buildings, if applicable. The coloring of wall signs shall be consistent
throughout the sign utilizing complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Construction Requirements: Any wall sign for which a permit is
required under this subsection shall comply with the following requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Materials: Shall have a surface or facing of durable material,
and shall otherwise comply with the requirements of section
10-3-6-4 of this chapter. Materials and finishes shall be reviewed for their
safety, durability, and wear, as well as for their appearance and beauty.
Proper measures and devices shall be incorporated for protection against the
elements, neglect, damage, and abuse.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Supports And Anchorage: Shall be attached directly to exterior
walls of solid masonry or concrete, and shall be safely and securely attached
to the same by means of metal anchors, bolts, or expansion screws. No wooden
blocks or anchorage with wood used in connection with screws or nails shall be
considered proper anchorage, except in the case of wall signs attached to
buildings with permitted walls of wood. No wall sign shall be entirely
supported by an unbraced parapet wall but must be attached to parapet walls or
other wall surfaces made a part of the main structure. Signs erected on a
separate superstructure attached to the roof of the building or to any other
part of the building above the roofline shall not be permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Attachment To Wall Surface: If attached to a building or
premises, shall be erected parallel to the vertical wall surface and shall not
project more than twelve inches (12") from the wall upon which it is attached,
nor project beyond the end or top of the wall to which it is attached. (Ord.
2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Illuminated Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â All electrically illuminated signs shall be approved as to
electric wiring and devices by the building department, and all wiring and
accessory electrical equipment shall conform to the requirements of the
national electrical code as adopted by the city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd.
2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Electrical permits are required for the erection or
maintenance of illuminated signs. (Note: No permit is required to replace or
reletter an illuminated sign unless the replacement or relettering requires a
change in wiring or piping.) (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â All wall signs, whether indoors or outdoors, shall be subject
to the following restrictions regarding illumination:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â A sign shall not be illuminated by other than electrical
means, and electrical devices and wiring shall be installed in accordance with
the requirements of the national electrical code as adopted by the city. (Ord.
2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â Any lighting shall be placed on the same property as the
wall sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (C)Â Â Â No LCD/plasma displays, blinking, flashing, fluttering or
other illuminating device, nor any illumination which has a change in light
intensity, brightness or color shall be permitted. (This prohibition is not
intended to apply to any approved time/temperature sign nor to seasonal holiday
lighting.)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Safety And Design Concerns: No sign shall be located, erected,
altered or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, or any window, or
door, or opening used as a means of egress, or for firefighting purposes, or so
as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof.
No sign shall be attached in any form, shape or manner to a fire escape or be
so placed as to interfere with any opening required by law for ventilation.
(Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Servicing Devices: Ladders, platforms, hooks, rigs and all other
devices for the use of servicing personnel shall have safety devices and design
loading in accordance with the safety requirements in the IBC as adopted by the
city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Monument/Freestanding Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Permitted Information: Unless otherwise permitted below, the
information contained on monument/freestanding signs shall be limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The legal name (or assumed name) of the business establishment,
which shall not exceed five (5) words. Notwithstanding the above, the name of a
legally established franchise may be displayed in lieu of the legal name of the
business establishment. A listing of services or goods is not permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The logo of the business establishment. The logo of the business
establishment shall be displayed so as to be subordinate in size and prominence
to the name of the business establishment. Further, the colors of corporate
logos may be required to be changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose
of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The date the business was actually established (example,
"Established 1867").
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Size, Design And Location: All signs for which a permit is required
under this subsection shall comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Monument Signs: Monument signs may be permitted as part of an
overall signage plan and shall comply with the following specific requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â No more than one monument sign shall be allowed per lot or
per development, whichever is less. Further provided, that where a development
or integrated shopping center under single ownership or unified control has
separate and distinct entrance drives, up to two (2) monument signs may be
erected. However, the total surface area of the combined signs may not exceed
three percent (3%) of the front facade, and no sign may exceed thirty six (36)
square feet per sign face.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The total surface area of said sign shall not exceed the
greater of thirty six (36) square feet or three percent (3%) of the front
facade of the building. However, in no event shall any single sign exceed sixty
(60) square feet per sign face.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Said sign shall not exceed six feet (6') in height, including
any foundation and supporting structure.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Said sign shall not exceed eight feet (8') in length,
including any foundation and supporting structure.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Said sign shall be in proportion to the building and
development. The maximum sizes set forth herein may be reduced considering the
size of the buildings or structures and other permitted signage. The design and
shape of any approved monument signs shall relate to the building facade,
facade of adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent buildings, if
applicable. The coloring of monument signs shall be consistent throughout
utilizing complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Notwithstanding the above, the monument sign shall be
planned, constructed and located so as to provide for the safety of pedestrians
and traffic in the areas adjacent to the sign, and such sign shall not obstruct
the view of pedestrian and vehicular traffic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Further provided, that if approval is granted as set forth
above for integrated shopping centers under single ownership or under unified
control, the sign shall contain only the name and location of the integrated
shopping center. However, if requested by the applicant, the ARC may consider
including the name of all of the occupants of the center. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-
2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â As to any monument sign for which a permit was issued prior
to October 1, 2000, and which may be made nonconforming by the size provisions
of this subsection, such sign may be repaired and maintained (subject to ARC
review) despite the fact that the sign may exceed the maximum size provisions
set forth above. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Such monument sign shall not have more than two (2) faces.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Prohibited Types: Pole signs, clocks, or other advertising
devices erected upon poles, pylons, standards or separate supports are
prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Location: Monument signs shall be permitted only in the front
yard of the premises. Such sign may not be located in any other yard.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Preferred Design Criteria: For any premises, the ARC shall
consider the following preferred design criteria in considering the approval or
recommendation for approval of any sign:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Illuminated "box signs" are not permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Signs with individually cut, opaque, raised letters on
raceways and illuminated with back lighting (reverse channel) are preferred.
Internal illumination of individual letters and/or logos is not preferred, but
may be considered where appropriate. However, illumination levels shall be
regulated to ensure that the illumination is appropriate in light of the
proposed signage, site, and adjoining properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Signage coloring shall complement the development and other
signage within the business district. Neon colors and bright colors are not
preferred, but may be permitted where they are found to enhance a design
element or otherwise are found to be appropriate due to unique site conditions.
In general, signage colors shall be complementary with the proposed
development. White, earth, bronze, gold or other subdued color tones for signs,
lettering and logos are preferred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The ARC may consider allowing corporate logos where
appropriate. However, the colors of corporate logos may be required to be
changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose of this chapter and color
requirements set forth above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â While signage identifying the business is limited as set
forth herein, limited additional design elements may be permitted on any
structure where determined appropriate by the ARC, in its discretion, subject
to review and approval by the city council. Such design elements may include
decorative murals, which do not specifically identify the business, decorative
etchings, woodwork and/or public art which are intended to enhance the visual
appeal of a structure or premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Vision Obstruction: In no event shall any sign be placed or
maintained in a location relative to a public or private street, alley,
driveway or other means of ingress or egress such that the sight of oncoming
vehicular or pedestrian traffic is impaired for users of such means of ingress
and egress.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Shape And Color: The shape of the sign shall relate to the
building facade, facade of adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent
buildings, if applicable. The coloring of signs shall be consistent throughout
the sign utilizing complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Construction Requirements: All signs for which a permit is required
under this subsection shall comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Materials: Shall have a surface or facing of noncombustible
material (except as set forth in section
10-3-6-4 of this chapter). Materials and finishes shall be reviewed for their
safety, durability, and wear, as well as for their appearance and beauty.
Proper measures and devices shall be incorporated for protection against the
elements, neglect, damage, and abuse. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Supports And Anchorage: Shall comply with the provisions of the
IBC, as amended, adopted by the city, which provisions are incorporated herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Illumination:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â All electrically illuminated signs shall be approved as to
electric wiring and devices by the building department, and all wiring and
accessory electrical equipment shall conform to the requirements of the
national electrical code as adopted by the city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd.
2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Electrical permits are required for the erection or
maintenance of illuminated signs. (Note: No permit is required to replace or
reletter an illuminated sign unless the replacement or relettering requires a
change in wiring or piping). (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â All monument/freestanding signs within the city shall be
subject to the following restrictions regarding illumination:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (A)Â Â Â A sign shall not be illuminated by other than electrical
means, and electrical devices and wiring shall be installed in accordance with
the requirements of the national electrical code as adopted by the city. (Ord.
2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (B)Â Â Â Any lighting shall be placed on the same property as the
sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (C)Â Â Â No LCD/plasma displays, blinking, flashing or fluttering
or other illuminating device, nor any illumination which has a change in light
intensity, brightness or color shall be permitted. (This prohibition is not
intended to apply to any approved time/temperature sign nor to seasonal holiday
lighting.)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Safety And Design Concerns: No sign shall be located, erected,
altered or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, or any window, or
door, or opening used as a means of egress, or for firefighting purposes, or so
as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof.
No sign shall be attached in any form, shape or manner to a fire escape or be
so placed as to interfere with any opening required by law for ventilation.
(Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Servicing Devices: Ladders, platforms, hooks, rigs and all other
devices for the use of servicing personnel shall have safety devices and design
loading in accordance with the safety requirements in the IBC as adopted by the
city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Window Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â General Requirements: If approved, signs may be placed in or on
windows or glass pane doors. However, the size of such sign shall be included
in calculating the maximum sign area allowed for all other signage.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Permitted Information: Unless otherwise permitted below, the
information contained on window signs shall be limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The legal name (or assumed name) of the business establishment,
which shall not exceed five (5) words. Notwithstanding the above, the name of
any practicing licensed professional or legally established franchise may be
displayed in lieu of the legal name of the business establishment. A listing of
services or goods is not permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The logo of the business establishment. The logo of the business
establishment shall be displayed so as to be subordinate in size and prominence
to the name of the business establishment. Further, the colors of corporate
logos may be required to be changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose
of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The date the business was actually established (example,
"Established 1867").
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the
contrary, any window sign for which a permit is sought may contain one
telephone number and area code of the business establishment; provided, that
there is compliance with the following requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â No more than one telephone number (including area code) and/
or internet address may be allowed for each business establishment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The above shall be in letters or numbers not exceeding four
inches (4") in height.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â If installed on a windowpane, the top edge of the letters or
numbers must be no higher than forty eight inches (48") above ground level on
the first floor and no higher than twelve feet (12') from the bottom edge of
the windowpane on the second floor or above, and if on a glass door, no higher
than forty eight inches (48") above floor level in front of the door.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The above shall be permitted only on a windowpane or glass
door, and is not permitted on any other sign, wall sign, marquee or
freestanding sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Size, Design And Location: Any window sign for which a permit is
required under this subsection shall comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Maximum Size: Window and wall signs combined shall not exceed
fifteen percent (15%) of the wall area of the front facade of the space
occupied by the business or one hundred (100) square feet, whichever is less.
As to window signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The size of the sign area used shall be determined by drawing
a square or rectangle around the lettering/logo of the proposed sign which
encompasses the entire content of the proposed sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The size of signs placed in or on walls or canopies shall be
included in calculating the maximum sign area allowed for all signs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The building face area of floors which are not occupied by
the business establishment (example, residential areas above the business
establishment) shall not be used to compute the wall area of the front facade.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Location: Window signs shall be permitted only on the front
window of a building, unless a variation is obtained.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Preferred Design Criteria: For any premises, the ARC shall
consider the following preferred design criteria in considering the approval or
recommendation for approval of any sign:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Illumination levels shall be regulated to ensure that the
illumination is appropriate in light of the proposed signage, site, and
adjoining properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Signage coloring shall complement the development and other
signage within the business district. Neon colors and bright colors are not
preferred, but may be permitted where they are found to enhance a design
element or otherwise are found to be appropriate due to unique site conditions.
In general, signage colors shall be complementary with the proposed
development. White, earth, bronze, gold or other subdued color tones for signs,
lettering and logos are preferred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The ARC may consider allowing corporate logos where
appropriate. However, the colors of corporate logos may be required to be
changed or subdued to meet the intent and purpose of this chapter and color
requirements set forth above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Shape And Color: The shape of window signs shall relate to the
building facade, facade of adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent
buildings, if applicable. The coloring of window signs shall be consistent
throughout utilizing complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Compliance Required: In all other respects the sign must comply
with all other requirements of this chapter and the ordinances of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Professional Appearance: All window signs shall be professionally
done and in all respects comply with the intent and purpose of this chapter.
Hand lettered signs are not permitted.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Other Signs And Regulations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Neon Advertising Signs: If approved, one neon advertising sign may
be allowed on each building face. Any such sign shall not exceed four (4)
square feet.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Governmental Or Public Utility Signs: Signs erected by the city,
signs for control of or to provide information regarding traffic and other
governmental regulatory purposes (e.g., street signs, danger signs, railroad
crossing signs, and signs of public service companies indicating danger and
aids to service or safety which are erected by or on the order of a public
officer in the performance of his or her public duty) shall be exempt from the
provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Marquee Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Signs attached to or hung from a marquee, canopy or awning may be
permitted to supplement and/or be in lieu of other signage, and shall be
completely within the borderline of the outer edge of the marquee or canopy,
and shall in no instance be lower than eight feet (8') above the ground or
surface over which the marquee or canopy is located.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The shape of all such signs shall relate to the building facade,
facade of adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent buildings, if
applicable. The color of such signs shall be consistent throughout and utilize
complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Awning And Canopy Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Signs on awning(s) or canopies may be permitted to supplement
and/or be in lieu of other signage; provided, that the size of letters on such
awnings shall not exceed eight inches (8") in height.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The shape of all awning signs shall relate to the building
facade, facade of adjacent buildings, and to the awning signs on adjacent
buildings, if applicable. The coloring of awning signs shall be consistent
throughout the awning utilizing complementary tones and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Miscellaneous Signs: Other signs proposed to be erected by any
person, other than the city, in the business district, including parking lot
signage, signs for control of or to provide information to pedestrians, traffic
and other regulatory purposes (e.g., towing signs, parking restrictions, etc.)
are not exempt from the provisions of this chapter, and a permit shall be
obtained for any such sign.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Other Design Elements: While signage identifying the business is
limited as set forth herein, limited additional design elements may be
recommended for approval on any structure if determined appropriate in the
discretion of the ARC, subject to review and approval by the city council. Such
design elements may include decorative murals, which do not specifically
identify the business, lettering, phrases, decorative etchings, woodwork and/or
public art which are intended to enhance the visual appeal of a structure or
premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Preferred Design Criteria: For any premises, the ARC shall consider
the following preferred design criteria in considering the approval or
recommendation for approval of any sign:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Illumination levels shall be regulated to ensure that the
illumination is appropriate in light of the proposed signage, site, and
adjoining properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Signage coloring shall complement the development and other
signage within the business district. Neon colors and bright colors are not
preferred, but may be permitted where they are found to enhance a design
element, or otherwise are found to be appropriate due to unique site
conditions. In general, signage colors shall be complementary with the proposed
development. White, earth, bronze, gold or other subdued color tones for signs,
lettering and logos are preferred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The ARC may consider allowing corporate logos where appropriate.
However, the colors of corporate logos may be required to be changed or subdued
to meet the intent and purpose of this chapter and color requirements set forth
above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The shape of signs shall relate to the building facade, facade of
adjacent buildings, and to the signs on adjacent buildings, if applicable. The
coloring of signs shall be consistent throughout utilizing complementary tones
and shades.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â In all other respects, the sign must comply with all other
requirements of this chapter and the ordinances of the city. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-
1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â All signs shall be professionally done and in all respects comply
with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Except as otherwise expressly
provided herein, hand lettered signs are not permitted. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-
2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Flagpoles And Advertising: No flagpole shall exceed thirty feet
(30') in height, and no advertising is permitted other than a business logo,
where approved.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Temporary Signs And Regulations: The following temporary signage is
permitted and regulated as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Event Signs: A sign not exceeding sixteen (16) square feet in total
surface area and six feet (6') in height announcing a drive or event of a
religious, civic or philanthropic organization may be permitted on the premises
of said organization; provided, that the sign shall be used for not more than
fifteen (15) days prior to the event; and provided, that said sign shall be
removed within two (2) days after the completion of said event.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Project Identification Signs: One sign not exceeding sixteen (16)
square feet in total surface area may be placed on the premises of a business,
project or building under construction facing each right of way.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Temporary Advertising Signs: Temporary advertising signs are
permitted as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The sign is permitted only for the announcement of a grand
opening sale, special offering or event; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The sign shall be contained entirely within the lot or premises,
and specifically, no such sign shall be posted or placed upon any sidewalk,
parkway, or public right of way; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The sign shall be used for not more than fifteen (15) days prior
to the event, and the sign shall be removed within two (2) days after the
completion of said event; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The sign shall bear the date it was posted and may not be reused
or the event or offering reposted within forty five (45) days of the initial
posting; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â If the sign is posted in or near a windowpane or glass door, any
sign shall not exceed four (4) square feet, nor shall the total of all signage
posted in the windowpane(s) or glass door area exceed twenty percent (20%) of
the glass area of the windowpane(s) or glass door; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â No such sign shall be illuminated; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â The occupant of the premises shall keep a log of all temporary
advertising signs posted at the premises. Such log shall include the date of
posting, the event or offering posted, the date of removal, and the
identification of the employee making the posting. Such log shall be exhibited
immediately upon request to any agent of the city for inspection and copying.
Signs announcing charitable, civic, philanthropic or community sponsored events
and event signs are not subject to the log requirements hereunder; and (Ord.
2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â The sign shall be professionally done and in all respects comply
with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Except as otherwise expressly
provided herein, hand lettered signs are not permitted. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-
2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Valet Signs: The mayor may authorize temporary signs designating
approved valet parking services. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Political Signs: Political signs are only regulated by this chapter
if the political candidate has opened a physical office or location within the
city of Highwood. All political signs shall be removed by any candidate or any
political committee within five (5) days after the election in which the
political issue is decided. Failure of any candidate or political committee to
remove a political sign shall make both liable for violation of this chapter.
However, no such sign may be placed or erected upon any public way or place
except as herein provided. (Ord. 17-O-2, 1-3-2017)
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Prohibited Signs: The following signs are prohibited:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No banners, flags, pennants, ribbons, streamers, spinners or helium
filled balloons used as a sign shall be located, erected, altered or maintained
in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Pole signs, clocks, or other advertising devices erected upon poles,
pylons, standards or separate supports are prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Portable signs are not permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Any open spark or flame shall not be used for display purposes
unless specifically approved by the building department and fire department.
(Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Except as otherwise expressly provided herein, hand lettered signs
are not permitted. All signs shall be professionally done and in all respects
comply with the intent and purpose of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005;
amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Neon signs not specifically permitted herein are prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â No LCD/plasma displays, blinking, flashing or fluttering or other
illuminating device, nor any illumination which has a change in light
intensity, brightness or color shall be permitted. (This prohibition is not
intended to apply to any approved time/temperature sign nor to seasonal holiday
lighting.)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â No sign with changing messages or content, revolving mechanisms,
including alternating slats which change the message or signage content, shall
be permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â No light or string of lights shall be illuminated except during
holiday seasons and then may only be illuminated during such holiday season.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â No sign may be placed or erected upon any public way or place
except as herein provided.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Except as specifically permitted herein, no person shall post,
stick, stamp, tack, paint or otherwise fix, or cause the same to be done by any
person, any sign, notice, placard, bill, card, poster, advertisement or other
device calculated to get the attention of the public, to or upon any sidewalk,
crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of any
public way.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â Illuminated building faces are prohibited unless submitted for
approval; however, if approved, shall be only such faces as do not front a
residential district.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â Illuminated box signs are prohibited both as wall signs and
monument/freestanding signs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â Signs, lettering and announcements on trucks and delivery vehicles
shall not be used to circumvent the signage regulations of this chapter. Trucks
whose primary purpose is the display of a billboard or display are specifically
prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â Other signs not permitted by this chapter are prohibited. (Ord.
2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Sandwich Board Signs: Businesses may have one sandwich board sign which
shall be no larger than two feet (2') wide and three feet (3') tall which is
not calculated against the total surface area of allowed signage. Sandwich
board signs may be placed on the public way provided the following requirements
are met:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The owner of the sandwich board sign pays the fee set forth in title
3 of this code, obtains a permit as required in this chapter, and executes a
license agreement indemnifying and holding the city harmless from liability and
naming the city, its officers and employees as an additional insured on a
general liability insurance policy. Such license agreements shall be approved
and signed by the city manager or his/her designee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Sandwich board signs may be displayed during business hours only and
must be removed each day.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Signs may be placed on sidewalks only and in a location where the
unobstructed paved area for pedestrian passage is not less than sixty inches
(60") wide.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Sandwich board signs shall be constructed of wood, metal, or durable
plastic.
Notwithstanding the requirements of section
10-3-5 of this chapter, neither an ARC recommendation, nor city council
approval shall be required for a sandwich board sign permit unless a variation
from the provisions of this section is sought. The city manager or his designee
is authorized to issue permits for sandwich board signs which conform with this
section. (Ord. 10-O-09, 3-16-2010)
10-3-6-8: NONCONFORMING, OBSOLETE SIGNS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nonconforming Signs: Nonconforming signs may remain so long as the use
which they advertise or identify remains, and so long as they remain undamaged
and in a good state of repair, and so long as they remain safe and structurally
sound as herein provided. Provided, however, as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Nonconforming signs shall not be changed, repaired, reconstructed,
or modified in any manner whatsoever. However, routine maintenance such as
painting and changing of lightbulbs is permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Once a nonconforming sign becomes damaged, falls into disrepair, or
is no longer safe and structurally sound, or such nonconforming sign becomes
obsolete and no longer advertises or identifies an existing use, such
nonconforming obsolete sign shall be removed, including the sign face and all
poles, bases, supports, braces, guys, anchors, and any other supporting
structures, within thirty (30) days of the date the nonconforming sign becomes
obsolete. Further, the premises to which the sign was attached shall be
restored to a good and safe condition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â If any nonconforming sign does not comply with this chapter and all
other applicable ordinances, rules and regulations in effect at the time that
the nonconforming sign becomes damaged or falls into disrepair, then, and in
that event, the owner shall remove or cause to be removed such nonconforming
sign in its entirety, including the sign face and all poles, bases, supports,
braces, guys, anchors and any other supporting structures, within thirty (30)
days of the date the nonconforming sign becomes damaged or falls into
disrepair. Further, the premises to which the sign was attached shall be
restored to a good and safe condition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The above shall not apply to nonconforming monument signs covered
under subsection 10-3-6-7C2 of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Obsolete Signs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Within thirty (30) days after any building, development or portion
thereof is vacated, or any time that a sign shall cease to advertise or
identify its original use, the owner shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â If said sign in all respects complied with this chapter in effect
at the time that the sign became obsolete, and all applicable ordinances, rules
and regulations in effect at the time that the sign became obsolete, the owner
shall remove or cause to be removed:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Such obsolete sign face within thirty (30) days.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Such obsolete sign, in its entirety, including all poles,
bases, supports, braces, guys, anchors and any other supporting structures,
pursuant to subsection B2 of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â If said sign was a nonconforming sign, did not comply with the
code in effect at the time that the sign became obsolete, and all applicable
ordinances, rules and regulations in effect at the time that the sign became
obsolete, then, and in that event, the owner shall remove or cause to be
removed such obsolete sign, in its entirety, including the sign face and all
poles, bases, supports, braces, guys, anchors and any other supporting
structures, within thirty (30) days of the date the sign became obsolete.
Further, the premises to which the sign was attached shall be restored to a
good and safe condition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The above shall not apply to obsolete nonconforming monument
signs covered under subsection 10-3-6-7C2 of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â a. For a premises containing a conforming obsolete sign, within
sixty (60) days of the date the sign became obsolete, the owner shall remove or
cause to be removed such obsolete sign, in its entirety, including all poles,
bases, supports, braces, guys, anchors, and any other supporting structures.
Provided, that the ARC may recommend to the city council a further extension of
such time period. An application for such extension shall be submitted to the
ARC by the applicant showing good cause why such conforming obsolete sign ought
not be removed within the time period provided herein. The ARC may, in its
discretion, recommend such extension, and further recommend such further
conditions as are reasonably required to implement the intent and purpose of
this chapter. The report of the ARC recommending the granting or denial of such
extension shall be forwarded to the city council for consideration and approval
or denial. The city council may impose such further conditions as it determines
are reasonably required to implement the intent and purpose of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Thereafter, a further extension of time may be granted by
application submitted to the city council by the applicant showing good cause
why such conforming obsolete sign ought not be removed within the time periods
granted above. The city council may grant such extension, and further may
impose such further conditions as are reasonably required to implement the
intent and purpose of this chapter. In its discretion, the city council may
refer this matter back to the ARC for further consideration for any further
extension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Upon expiration of the time periods set forth above, and
provided, that no permits have been issued for the modification and maintenance
of said sign and structure, the owner shall remove such obsolete sign in its
entirety, including all poles, bases, supports, braces, guys, anchors and any
other supporting structures.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â For integrated shopping centers under single ownership or under
unified control, which maintain a sign erected showing the name of the
integrated shopping center and the name of the occupants of the center,
whenever such sign, or portion thereof, ceases to advertise or identify a
business or use within such shopping center, the owner shall remove or cause to
be removed such obsolete sign, or portion thereof, within thirty (30) days
after such use ceases.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Removal Of Sign:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any sign face which is required to be removed pursuant to the terms
of this chapter shall be considered removed either when the sign, in its
entirety, has been removed, or when the sign face, lettering, graphics or other
information identifying the obsolete use has been fully removed. Provided, that
all work shall be professionally done and in all respects comply with the
intent and purpose of this chapter. In no event shall the sign face be simply
covered or any interior areas of a sign receptacle or box remain exposed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whenever a sign is removed from a building facade, such facade shall
be restored following removal of the sign.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Lien Provisions: If signs are not removed within the time period
provided pursuant to the terms of this chapter, the city may have such signs
removed at the expense of the owner. The expense of such removal shall
constitute a lien upon the premises until paid. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-6-9: ALTERATIONS, RELOCATION, MAINTENANCE AND REMOVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Alterations: A sign shall not be enlarged or relocated except in
conformity with the provisions for new signs, nor until a proper permit has
been secured. The changing or movable parts of an approved sign that is
designed for such changes, or the repainting or reposting of display matter,
shall not be deemed an alteration, provided the conditions of the original
approval and the requirements of this section
10-3-6 are not violated.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Relocating Signs: Any sign that is moved to another location, either on
the same or to other premises, shall be considered a new sign, and a permit
shall be secured for any work performed in connection therewith when required
by this section
10-3-6.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Maintenance Of Signs: All signs, together with all their supports,
braces, guys and anchors, shall be kept in good repair and shall at all times
be maintained to conform to at least the minimum standards prescribed by the
ordinances of the city. Further, provided that nonconforming signs shall not be
so maintained and shall be removed once they become damaged or fall into
disrepair. Notwithstanding the above, the changing of bulbs is permitted
without ARC approval, and painting of sign poles and boxes is permitted,
following ARC approval.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Maintenance Of Premises: It shall be the duty of all persons holding a
present possessory interest in a lot or premises and the owner thereof having a
sign, to at all times maintain said lot or premises in the vicinity of such
sign in a neat, clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition and to keep the same
free and clean of all debris, junk and other materials and substances which
would tend to create a condition detrimental to the appearance of the property
and the city, or the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Removal Of Dangerous Signs: When any sign becomes insecure, presents a
danger of falling, or is otherwise unsafe, or if any sign shall be unlawfully
installed, erected or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, the persons having a present possessory interest in the lot or
premises upon which the sign is placed or the owner thereof shall, upon written
notice of the building department, and in the case of immediate danger
forthwith, but in no event no more than ten (10) days, make such sign conform
to the provisions of this section
10-3-6, or shall remove it. The persons having a present possessory interest in
the sign or the owner of the lot or premises shall be afforded a hearing before
the ARC to show cause why the sign shall not be removed. If, within ten (10)
days after the ARC finds that the sign is unsafe or is not maintained in
accordance with this section
10-3-6 or was unlawfully erected or installed, the building department may
cause the removal of the sign and charge the cost of removal to the persons
having a present possessory interest in the sign or the owner of the lot or
premises concerned. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-6-10: NOTARY PUBLIC DISCLOSURE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary,
any sign approved for a notary public who is not an attorney, which is in a
language other than English, shall contain the following disclaimer, in
accordance with 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 312/3-103:
Â Â Â Â Â Â I AM NOT AN ATTORNEY LICENSED TO PRACTICE LAW IN ILLINOIS AND MAY NOT
GIVE LEGAL ADVICE OR ACCEPT FEES FOR LEGAL ADVICE.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The above disclaimer shall be of a conspicuous size and shall be in the

10-3-6-11: TEMPORARY SIGNS ON RIGHT OF WAY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Conditions: In conjunction with a special event occurring within the
city of Highwood and subject to the permitting requirements contained in this
section, temporary signs shall be allowed within the right of way subject to
the following conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Up to ten (10) signs shall be permitted per approved special event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Individual signs shall be limited to four (4) square feet;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Signs shall be erected up to one week prior to the special event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Signs shall be removed within two (2) days after the special event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Signs shall be affixed directly to the ground, shall not exceed
thirty six inches (36") from the ground to the top and shall not be attached to
any street sign, utility pole, light pole or fire hydrant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â No signs shall be placed in such a manner as to obstruct safe
passage on any right of way, or to endanger the public health and safety;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The city reserves the right to remove or relocate a sign as it deems
necessary.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Permits: All temporary signs authorized by this section shall be
subject to the following permit requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An application shall be filed with the city manager at least
fourteen (14) days prior to the advertised special event, and shall contain the
following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Name, address and telephone number of applicant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Date of special event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Location of special event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Number of temporary signs requested to be placed in right of way;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Proposed location of temporary signs;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Proposed drawing and specifications of temporary signs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All applications for temporary sign permits shall also include a
deposit in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), which shall be returned to the
applicant provided all permitted temporary signs are removed from the right of
way within two (2) days after the special event.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The city manager shall grant the temporary sign permit provided all
provisions of this section have been complied with. (Ord. 13-O-36, 6-4-2013)
10-3-7: APPROVAL OF LANDSCAPING AND EXTERIOR AREAS:
10-3-7-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this section
10-3-7 is to enhance the appearance of properties and the city in such a way as
to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Ensure that all properties other than single-family dwellings or duplex
dwellings substantially remodeled, substantially renovated or developed
(including additions) within the city are reviewed for landscape design
elements both on the property and adjacent public ways by promoting enhanced
landscape opportunities.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Enhance the appearance of the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Provide a review of landscape plans with regard to design elements,
planting materials, proportion and manner of display to fully promote the
intent and purpose of this chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Promote such plantings and landscape design elements that will not
obstruct the vision necessary for traffic safety or otherwise endanger the
public health, safety, morals or general welfare.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Ensure that plantings and landscape design elements are selected for
their durability as well as for their beauty.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Enhance architectural features, strengthen vistas and important areas,
and provide shade. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-7-2: APPLICATION FOR AND CONDITIONS OF APPROVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Form Of Application: Where a property is substantially remodeled,
substantially renovated or developed (including additions) within the city,
other than a single-family or existing duplex dwelling, an application for
landscape approval shall be made by the applicant to the ARC upon such forms as
may be provided by the building department.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Contents Of Application:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Such application shall contain or have attached thereto the
following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Written consent of the legal owner of the building or structure.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Location of the building or structure to be constructed or
altered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Site plan - two (2) drawings of the project including
specifications, elevations and methods of construction, including a scaled
drawing appropriate to the project with sufficient detail to clearly convey the
form and nature of all site improvements and modifications and their
relationships to adjacent properties. Documentation may be required to include:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â General Requirements: Project address; graphic scale, north
reference; square foot area calculations for building, pavement and
landscaping; dimensioned property lines, easements and building setbacks;
adjacent streets, alleys and sidewalks; parking spaces including handicapped
spaces; trash/refuse location and enclosures; proposed equipment (generators,
compactors, transformers, HVAC, etc.); and existing and proposed contours at
two foot (2'0") maximum intervals (if applicable).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Landscape Plan: A landscape plan rendered in color and
including depiction of existing vegetation noting species, size and driplines
of trees two and one-half inch (21/2") caliper and larger, with a distinction
shown between vegetation to be retained or removed; new plant material noting
quantities, species (botanical and common names), and size (in caliper or
height at time of installation), and graphically distinguishing between new and
existing plant material and between species of new plant material; site
furnishings and specialties; paving materials; height and locations of
flagpoles, signage, light standards and fences; screening, noting materials
used as screen, height of screen material, device or area which requires
screening and height of device to be screened (exterior areas which require
screening include parking, refuse storage and mechanical equipment); and
stormwater retention/detention areas.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Lighting Plan: A separate overlay to the above referenced
site plan with site and building lighting highlighted. Documentation to include
photometric documentation or separate printout showing compliance with the
zoning ordinance; reference code keyed to light fixture catalog cuts; and lamp
types.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Building Plan (Minimum Scale, 1/8" = 1'0"): Documentation
shall include grade level plan which indicates openings and articulation of the
exterior wall and the relationship of this level to the project site; floor
plans of all levels on separate drawings; roof plan with equipment, skylights
and other appropriate features; and graphically distinguish between new and
existing construction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Building Elevations (Minimum Scale, 1/8" = 1'0"): A drawing
which provides exterior views of all new and existing building facades and
indicates the relationships of all visible building features and color
rendering of significant views.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Site Section: A section through the site at appropriate
locations indicating buildings, trees, light standards, grade variations,
fences and other critical structures. Reference plane of section cuts to site
plan.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Scale Model Or Building Perspective: A scale model or color
rendering of significant views of the building and its surrounding area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Material Samples: A display board which illustrates actual
site and building materials. Samples shall provide an accurate representation
of color, texture, finish and range variations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Photographs: Current color photographs of the site showing
all building elevations, surrounding properties and landscape views. Format
shall be a minimum four inch by six inch (4" x 6") size color print. Panoramic
studies are preferred.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The application shall be supplemented by such other and further
materials as required by the building department or the ARC.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Appearance Before ARC: Upon such application, applicant may be required
to appear before the ARC for clarification of the proposed landscape plans.
Approval must be secured from the building department, a certificate of
approval from the ARC and final approval from the city council before any
permit is issued.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Conditions Of Approval: After review and consideration of the material
presented, the ARC shall move approval if it finds that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The applicant's plans are substantially consistent with this
chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The proposed exterior design features of the development are
consistent with the intent and purpose of this chapter, and suitable and
compatible with the character of neighboring buildings and structures existing
or under construction and with the character of the neighborhood and zoning
district, and contribute to the favorable environment of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The exterior design features of the development will not be
detrimental to the harmonious and orderly growth of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The exterior design features of the development will not cause a
substantial depreciation in the property values or taxable values in the
neighborhood. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-7-3: LANDSCAPING APPROVAL REQUIRED:
No building permit shall be issued for any new construction nor for any
premises which is substantially altered, remodeled or improved within the city
(except single-family or existing duplex dwellings), unless the applicant shall
provide and obtain approval of a landscape plan showing the premises (in
addition to the parkway and off street parking area requirements herein) to be
treated with decorative elements, plantings, berms or other innovative means as
required in this chapter. The following specific provisions shall apply
wherever practicable. Any construction, addition, or enlargement for all uses,
except single-family or existing duplex dwellings, shall be permitted only upon
compliance with the following at a minimum:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Shade trees of not less than two and one-half inch (21/2") caliper
shall be planted within or surrounding the proposed construction, addition or
enlargement, at a rate and spacing determined by the ARC, based upon the
proposed use and the intent and purpose of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each area abutting a public street (other than approved driveway cuts)
shall provide approved landscaping of hedges, shrubbery or evergreens, a
planted earth berm, or a combination of both, as approved by the ARC.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Planting islands of shrubs and/or trees, and decorative berms shall be
implemented into landscape plans for screening or outdoor areas, including
areas of congregation of individuals such as patios, outdoor service areas and
service yards, and other places in which individuals, patrons or employees tend
to congregate. This shall be accomplished by use of walls, fencing, plantings
or combinations of the above.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Unity of design shall be achieved by repetition of certain plant
varieties and other materials and by correlation with adjacent developments.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Plant material shall be selected for interest in its structure, texture
and color and for its ultimate growth. Plants that are noninvasive, hardy,
harmonious to the design, and of attractive appearance shall be used.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Each area in the business district, for which a landscaping plan is
required, which abuts residential property shall provide a sight screen
approved by the ARC such as a solid fence or wall, not less than five feet (5')
nor more than six feet (6') in height, or a continuous dense hedge of shrubbery
or evergreens, a planted earth berm, or a combination of both, at least five
feet (5') high. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-7-4: PARKING LOTS:
To achieve attractive landscape transition between off street parking areas and
adjoining properties or public streets, all such areas shall be treated with
decorative design elements, plantings, berms or other innovative means as
required in this chapter. The following specific provisions shall apply:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any construction or enlargement of off street parking and loading areas
for all uses, except single-family or existing duplex dwellings, shall be
permitted only upon compliance with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No permit shall be issued for construction of any new parking area
(except single-family or existing duplex dwellings), unless the applicant
agrees that plantings and trees as determined sufficient by the ARC shall be
planted therein, unless the ARC shall show good cause in writing that such
planting will not be in the best interest of the city. At a minimum, shade
trees of not less than two and one-half inch (21/2") caliper shall be planted
within or surrounding any parking area at a rate of not less than one tree for
the first five thousand (5,000) square feet of parking and loading areas, plus
one tree for each additional five thousand (5,000) square feet or part thereof
of parking and loading area, but not less than one tree for each such area. The
applicant shall provide bond or other surety in a form acceptable to the city
attorney for same.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All such trees shall be of a caliper specified by the ARC and of
such species, quality and placement as may be approved by the ARC, taking into
account cleanliness, ease of maintenance, resistance to disease and adverse
conditions and the avoidance of concentrations of single species.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No tree, shrub or plant shall be planted or maintained within any
parking area where the lowermost branches of any tree extend over the adjacent
pavement maintained for vehicular traffic or parking at a height of less than
nine feet (9').
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The planting of any low hanging trees which might impair vision is
also prohibited. No person shall plant any tree in a parking lot without first
obtaining approval from the ARC.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Unity of design shall be achieved by repetition of certain plant
varieties and other materials and by correlation with adjacent developments.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Plant material shall be selected for interest in its structure,
texture and color and for its ultimate growth. Plants that are indigenous to
the area and that will be hardy, harmonious to the design, and of attractive
appearance shall be used.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Parking and loading areas abutting any street or abutting residential
uses shall also comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Each such area abutting a public street (other than approved
driveway cuts) shall provide a buffer strip of five feet (5') minimum width for
the entire length of the property line abutting such right of way and
landscaped with a continuous dense hedge of shrubbery or evergreens, a planted
earth berm, or a combination of both, of appropriate height as determined by
the ARC considering the site. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Each such area abutting residential property shall provide a sight
screen such as a solid fence or wall not less than five feet (5') nor more than
eight feet (8') in height 1 , or a continuous dense hedge of shrubbery or
evergreens, a planted earth berm, or a combination of both, at least five feet
(5') high. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Planting islands of shrubs and/or trees within parking lots or
loading areas shall be encouraged.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Parking areas and related trafficways shall be enhanced with
landscaped areas, including trees or tree groupings.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Unity of design shall be achieved by repetition of certain plant
varieties and other materials and by correlation with adjacent developments.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Plant material shall be selected for interest in its structure,
texture and color and for its ultimate growth. Plants that are indigenous to
the area and that will be hardy, harmonious to the design, and of attractive
appearance shall be used.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Parking areas shall be treated with decorative elements, building
wall extensions, plantings, berms or other innovative means so as to largely
screen parking areas from view from public ways.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â In locations where plants will be susceptible to injury by
pedestrian or motor traffic, they shall be protected by appropriate curbs, tree
guards, or other devices.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Trees, plantings and improvements placed or authorized by the city
shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)

10-3-7-5: PARKWAYS AND PUBLIC WAYS:
No building permit shall be issued for any new construction nor for any
premises which is substantially altered, remodeled or improved within the city
(except single-family or existing duplex dwellings), unless the applicant
agrees that grass, plantings and trees, as required in this chapter and as
determined sufficient by the ARC, shall be planted in the public parkway
adjoining the premises to be improved. The following specific provisions shall
apply, unless the ARC shall show good cause in writing that such planting will
not be in the best interest of the city:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Trees shall be planted approximately forty feet (40') apart at a rate
of not less than one tree for any frontage of less than forty feet (40'), two
(2) trees for any frontage of forty feet (40'), and two (2) trees for each
additional forty feet (40') of frontage or part thereof. The applicant shall
provide bond or other surety in a form acceptable to the city attorney for
same.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All such trees shall be of not less than two and one-half inch (21/2")
caliper and of such species, quality and placement as may be approved by the
ARC, taking into account cleanliness, ease of maintenance, resistance to
disease and adverse conditions and the avoidance of concentrations of single
species.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The following trees shall not be used for street for parkway plantings:
poplar, cottonwood, box elder, willow, dwarf catalpa, soft maple, elms,
hawthorn, birch, spruce, pine, fir, or any type of bearing fruit/nut tree or
any variety thereof.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to plant, set
out, grow or maintain any tree, shrub or plant in and upon any public street or
parkway in the city except in the manner herein specified.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place or
maintain on any such street or parkway gravel, stones, boulders, fences, rock
gardens or ornamentation within two feet (2') of the public roadway.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to remove,
damage, or deface any improvements (including landscaping, grass or plantings)
installed upon any right of way, the public parkway, public parks, city
property, parking lots maintained or managed by the city, or any landscaping
and/or plantings required by this chapter.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â It shall be the duty of the person, firm or corporation owning or
occupying the property adjacent to the public parkway to maintain the parkway
by trimming/mowing any grass thereon. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm
or corporation to allow such grass to grow in excess of the limitations imposed
by city ordinances.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Unless approved by the city, no tree, shrub or plant shall be planted
or maintained upon any public street or parkway at a distance of less than two
feet (2') from the established curb line or at a distance of less than two feet
(2') from the established sidewalk line, nor shall the lowermost branches of
any tree extend over the adjacent pavement maintained for vehicular traffic at
a height of less than nine feet (9'). No shrubs shall be allowed to grow higher
than three feet (3').
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â The planting of any low hanging trees which might impair vision is also
prohibited. No person shall plant any tree on any parkway without first
obtaining permission from the ARC.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Trees, plantings and improvements placed or authorized by the city
shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
10-3-7-6: REFUSE AREAS AND MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In the B-1 zoning district of the city, and in all zoning districts in
which a business, commercial, or multiple-family use exists (a property
containing more than 3 family living units), a refuse enclosure area is
required as follows: All garbage and refuse receptacles, garbage and refuse
bags, recycling containers, and all other items of garbage, trash, refuse,
brush, cuttings or any other matter enumerated in the city scavenger ordinance
1  for collection (hereinafter "refuse"), shall at all times be kept in the
enclosed and screened area designated for same (hereinafter "refuse enclosure
area") except when the refuse is actually being collected. The refuse enclosure
area shall consist of a paved, dustless surface surrounded by an approved
screening fence or landscape screening of a height sufficient to screen such
refuse and containers from view from adjoining properties and public or private
ways. The refuse enclosure area shall be designed with a gate or gates to allow
access by the scavenger service for removal of the containers and/or refuse,
and a separate entry to the refuse enclosure area for depositing of refuse by
users of the enclosure (hereinafter "manway"). The requirement of a manway may
be waived by the ARC if not practicable in a particular application or
premises.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The ARC may promulgate certain approved refuse enclosures and screening
devices to be implemented for the purposes set forth above. Such preapproved
screening methods and designs may be implemented by the building official and
permits issued for same without the necessity of the applicant appearing before
the ARC, provided the proposed enclosure or screening device fully complies in
all respects with all other applicable ordinances. Where convenient for the
administration of this chapter, the building official may solicit such
approvals from time to time from the ARC on behalf of the city or on behalf of
an applicant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, or section
11-3-3 of this code, approval by the city council is not required for the
issuance of permits for refuse enclosures in any business district. However, at
the next regular meeting of the city council, the building official shall
report to the city council the nature of all permits issued pursuant to this
chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Refuse and waste removal areas, service yards, storage yards, and
exterior work areas shall be screened from view from public ways, using
materials as stated in criteria for equipment screening. Further, to the
greatest extent practicable, they shall not be located in front yards or
adjacent to any public way. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Mechanical equipment or other utility hardware on the roof, ground, or
buildings shall be screened from public view with materials harmonious with the
building, or they shall be so located as not to be visible from any public
ways. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Screening of service yards and other places which tend to be unsightly
shall be accomplished by use of walls, fencing, planting, or combinations of
these. Screening shall be equally effective in winter and summer. (Ord. 2005-O-
6, 2-1-2005)

10-3-7-7: FENCES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Anyone wishing to erect a fence within the city shall obtain a fence
permit from the building department. However, no permit shall be issued for any
fence (other than a temporary construction site fence) to be constructed within
the business district until the ARC has reviewed same and issued its approval.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All fences shall comply with the following regulations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No fence shall be erected or maintained in a front yard of any lot
adjoining a public street in any district, except in the B-1 retail business
district, to a height greater than four feet (4'). Only open fencing is
permitted in a front yard.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No fences shall be erected or maintained in a side yard or a rear
yard in any district (except in the business district) to a height greater than
six feet (6').
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No chainlink type fencing (with or without filler strips) shall be
erected or maintained in a front yard of any lot adjoining a public street in
any district. Existing chainlink fences shall be removed when they fall into
disrepair.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Fences in any business district shall comply with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â No fence shall be erected or maintained in the business district
to a height greater than five feet (5'). Further, only open wrought iron
fencing is permitted in any yard in the business district. Exceptions to the
requirements of this subsection B4a are set forth in subsection B4b of this
section. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â In areas of the business district in which a fence for screening
purposes is required by any ordinance of the city, such screening fence shall
not be less than six feet (6') and shall consist of a decorative "board on
board", brick, other fencing or other material approved by the ARC. Further
provided, that same is structurally sound for the proposed application (i.e.,
supported by metal poles and framing) 1 . (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005; amd. 2009
Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Regardless of the above permitted heights, in no event shall any
wall, fence or other structure or planting be placed or maintained in a
location relative to a public or private street, alley, driveway or other means
of ingress or egress such that the sight of oncoming vehicular or pedestrian
traffic is impaired for users of such means of ingress and egress.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Chainlink type fencing, with or without filler strips, is
prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â All fence materials shall be new and of good quality acceptable
for exterior use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Upon good cause shown by the applicant, the city council may
grant a variation to allow an applicant to erect a fence which is required for
screening purposes other than as permitted above. Such approval shall be in the
sole discretion of the city council. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â In all zoning districts the finished side of the fence (side without
fenceposts) shall face the adjoining property or public way. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-
1-2005; amd. 2009 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The use of barbed wire or electrically charged fences is prohibited.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any fence (whether or not required by this chapter) and/or any
landscaped screening used to satisfy the requirements of this chapter, or
required as a condition of approval for a special use permit, or for which a
permit is issued shall be continually maintained for the duration of the use
involved. (Ord. 2005-O-6, 2-1-2005)
